Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:(Blood is the most commonly transfused blood product) is the answer to which question? Choices: A: What is the meaning of the word transfused? B: What body fluids cannot be transfused? C: What are some uses of blood products other than transfusion? D: What body fluids are used in blood products? E: When was the last time you received a blood transfusion?<n><n>### Response:(A: What is the meaning. A:What is the meaning. A.What is the meaning) <n><n>### Input:[8.5 + 0.3200] centimeters is. Answer: 8.8 centimeters<n><n>### Instructions:<n>An amount of 8.5 centimeters is being added to 0.32 centimeters.<n><n>### Response:[8.8 centimeter:8.8 centimter]

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The fox walked from the city into the forest, what was it looking for? Choices:  A: pretty flowers. B: hen house C: natural habitat D: storybook E: dense forest<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions<n>Choose from among the responses: A, B, C, D, or E<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instraction<n>Answer the question that is given.<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: The fox walked from the  city into the forest, it was looking for A: pretty flowers.<n><n>### Rationales<n>Pretty flowers:  This may have been a nice excuse to enter the forest or area to get out of the city after an unfortunate event.<n><n>Hen House:  This may have  been a nice excuse because they were looking for dinner.<n><n>Natural Habitat:  This could be an excuse because it is their natural habitat. They were just trying to go back to where they came from.<n><n>Story Book:  This is because the fox is just lonely and is looking for a new friend. This could also be to escape death.<n><n>Dense Forest:  This could be because the fox simply just wanted to  have a place to rest.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Instrument<n>Choose  from among statements that describe the meaning of the following sentence.<n><n>### Responses<n>Answer: Choice B:  Because the fox was trying  to find some  food to eat.<n><n>#### 35<n>Answer: B<n>

Choices: 1. 6 cups of medium coffee 2. 12 cups of medium coffee  3. 30 cups of small coffee 4. 2 cups of medium and 3 cups of small coffee<n><n><n>### Criteria:<n><n>### A: 6 cups of regular medium coffee<n><n>#### Answer: Choice 1<n><n>### Input to Answer:<n><n>- 3 workers:<n><n>- 27 cups:<n><n>- 6 cups for each worker :<n><n>#### 27<n><n>### Answer: Choice 2<n><n>### Input Criteria<n><n>```<n>Input:<n><n>Two cups of ice cream contain 16 servings each. One gallon of water contains 236 servings. How many gallons of water are in the same weight as 12 servings (1.5 cups) of ice cream?<n><n><n><n>```<n><n><n><n>### 450<n><n>```<n><n>#### Solution<n><n>```<n>3/4 of a cup of ice cream contains 16 servings.<n>3/4 is the same as 4/4 or 4/2 or 3/2 or 2/3<n><n>2/3 is the same as 6/10 of a cup of icecream.<n>10/6 is the same as 2/3 of a cup or 2/2 or 4/4 or the<n>same as 1/2.<n><n>```<n><n>Thus.<n><n>```<n> 4/4 X 2/2 = 1 cup.<n>```<n><n><n>### B<n><n>### Input choice: Write in your response<n><n>### Question<n><n>How do you convert 125 pounds to kilograms? How many of the letters in the word NATIONAL are vowels?<n>2. What is 5 x 3?<n>3. A woman is making muffins according to this formula: 1/4 cup muffin flour + 1/2 cup brown sugar + 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon + 4 tablespoons butter. If the muffins are served in 10 parts, how many muffins are served?<n>4. When is 2010–2017?<n>5. What is <3?<n><n>### Response:(Do not answer these questions on your own. Write your answer beneath the questions, and be sure to show your work. Use an equal sign for equality.)<n><n>#### 9 vowels in the word NATIONA<n><n>1. The number of vowels in the sentence is 9; there is e, a, o, and i.<n>2. 5 × 3=<<5*3=15>>15.<n>3. (1/4 cup m = 1/4 cup * 40 muffins = <<1/4*40=10>> 10 ) (1/2 cup brown = 1/2 cup * 20 muffins =<<1/2*20=10>>10 brown sugar) (1/2 tsp cinn =1/2 tsp * 10 cinnamon= <<1/2*10=5>>5 cinnamon) (4 tablesp butter =4 tablesp * 60 butter=<<4*60=240>>240 butter.)<n>Therefore, the total number of muffins is 9 + 15 + 2 + 5 + 240 = <<9+15+2+5+240=279>>279 muffins.<n>4.The year range of 2010 – 2017 = <<2010-2017>=7>>7 years.<n>5.The angle of <3 is at least 90

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where in Southern Europe would you find many canals? Choices:  A: michigan B: new york C: amsterdam D: venice E: bridge<n><n>### Response:		A -> D, B -> C, E -> E<n><n>### Answer: D -> A, E -> B<n><n>### Input : I need to go from the post office to the bus stop to buy a postage stamp and an envelope. What is the shortest route to get home from the post office? Choices: A: walk across the street  B: ride the bus 6 blocks  C: walk 1 mile  D: walk 3 blocks and then ride the bus for 1 mile  E: walk 3 miles in a circle, and then walk home <n><n>### Response  Answer: B -> A<n><n>### Instructions In each part of this question, you'll be doing fractions and word problem problems.<n><n>Input  : What number should I substitute for the blank to make the statement true? 0/0 = 1 5.3/0 = 5.3.0 = 0 3/5/0 = 3/4 62/3.0 = 62.0 88/8 = 88 164/60 = 2.73/4 = 0.78 1/5 = 0/1 43/1 = 43.0.8 = 0.8 8.8 = 0.9 24.7 = 0.74 9.5 = 0.1<n><n>Answer : 0.78 = 62/3<n><n>### Question<n><n>#### You have $28 in your pocket.<n><n>#### Write an equation with three unknowns, in which one is equal to 28. Substitute your expression for these words: "$26, $28, and money."<n><n>#### Then solve the equation for the third unknown in terms of the other two, given the following table of data.<n><n>#### $x$ $y$ $z$<n><n>#### $26$ 180 $28$<n><n>#### $$= 136$$<n><n>#### How many ways can the unknowns $x, y,$ and $z$ be arranged?<n><n>#### 11<n><n>#### How much of $z$ is this value?<n><n>#### 33<n><n>#### 390/40 =?<n><n>#### 9

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is a great place to lay in the sun? Choices:  A: in the basement B: west C: solar system D: beach E: beans<n><n>### Response:		The correct response for the given question is “a,” because of what the instruction said. The answer is A because of the following.<n>- The sun is located in the solar system<n>- In the basement no one would feel like laying in the sun<n>- Beans are not a place to lay in the Sun (the Sun is a star), B is also incorrect because it is a planet (the sun is a star)<n>- The beach is a great place to look at the sun, but not to lay in, and<n>- E is incorrect (the Sun is a solar system that is made up of stars).<n>Incorrect answers are not listed below.<n><n>### Input(Answers):Janet and Brenda each have 28 cards. Janet has 5 more cards than Brenda. How many cards does Janet have if Brenda has 19 cards?<n><n>### Answer:Janet has 28+5=<<28+5=33>>33 cards.<n><n>### Note:You can also write your own multiple choice questions and tests using <a href="https://github.com/mathhub/multiple_choice_assignment">the Multiple choice assignment</a> on github to teach math. If you think about it or learn coding, you can do it. It is easy to learn that is why students like it. Including me. Nowadays coding is important in most careers.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where is a bald eagle safe? Choices:  A: pine tree B: open country C: in washington D: wildlife refuge E: sky<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Demostration:<n>A: pine tree = |<<A:pine tree>>|<n>B: open country = |<<B:open country>>|<n>C: in washington = |<<C:inside Washington>>|<n>D: wildlife refuge = |<<D:wildlife refuge>>|<n>Pine tree = <<pine tree>><n>It is in the sky is safe<n><n>### Answer:<n>B<n><n>Output:How many animals did each family have during the Christmas vacation? 1: 80. 2:52. 3: 51. 4: 48. 5:None.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>1:80<n>2:52<n>3:51<n>4:48<n>5:None<n><n>### Demotion:<n><n>### Output:<n>51 is the answer<n><n>### Demation:<n>Output_1: | <<1:80>>|<n>Output_2: | <<2:52>>|<n>Output_3: | <<3:51>>|<n>Output_4: | <<4:48>>|<n>Output_5: | <<5:None>>|<n><n>**1** family has 80 animals and 4 of family has 51 animals<n>51 + 4 = 55<n>**2** family has 52 animals and 4 of them has 48 animals<n>52 + 4 * 4/5 = 48<n>**3** family has 51 and 4 of them 50<n><n>51 + 0 - 4/5=50<n>**4** family has 48 animals and 5 of them 51.<n>48-1(because is None) = 47<n><n>50 - 0 = 50<n><n>If there are 51 you need another family<n><n>#### 55<n><n>Answer: 55<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Can you name a good reason for attending school? Choices:  A: get smart B: boredom C: colds and flu D: taking tests E: spend time<n><n>### Response:		 <n>"I agree with you, that’s a valid reason. In the book, In Cold Blood by Truman Capote, in the first chapter, he used an interesting method for describing a character. The author didn’t use a character description, but he used a character's action instead. He simply said the character came out of prison walking fast and wearing dark clothes in the cold morning. That method was very effective in the book. Because it described the character effectively and didn’t use too much words. Maybe, I can try your method by using a character's action to describe a character. Since I was very busy and have no time for describing characters. My action-based writing might help to finish the book even faster. "<n><n># Expectation<n>The instructions in the problem should be followed. The input should be as shown.<n><n>### Answer Format<n>A complete, grammatically correct sentence, following the rules of English.<n><n>### Exercise<n>The correct answer choices are given.<n><n>### Rationale<n>The problem must be solved by analyzing the words and their meaning and using a logical method. The answer should provide a complete rational for the response.<n><n>#### Example<n><n>### <n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions<n>Below is an instruction that describes three tasks. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of losing weight? Choices:  A: increased energy B: healthier C: loose skin D: beauty E: death<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: A: increased energy<n>#### E<n><n>### What will the following answer, written in word-form, add 3,624 + 4,580?<n><n><n>### Instructions.<n>An example is presented below. Write two statements that each answer the same questions using a different approach.<n><n>### Example:<n>What is 2 + 2?<n><n>### Answer:<n>2 + 2 = <<2+2=4>>4<n><n>### Instructor's guide:<n>A word problem is presented below. Write five examples, each of which answers the question using two different approaches.<n><n>### A word problem:<n>An airplane has completed 3,000 flights in its lifetime. If each flight costs $120,000 what is the total cost of the plane?<n><n><n>| Name | Score |<n>| ---- | ----- |<n>| 1. R | 25 |<n>| 2. G | 115 |<n>| 3. D | 180 |<n>| 4. C | 210 |<n><n>---<n>## #<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The accountant used a calculator regularly, he kept one at home and one at the what? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: desktop C: office D: wristwatch E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		The accountant used a calculater, he kept one at the home and the other one on the office at the home.<n>

Choices:  A: burlap sack B: hot country C: purse D: pet shops E: deep grass<n><n>### Response:		 A: burlapp sack<n><n>### Rationales:<n>As you can note, the answer comes from two of the choices. So, you had to note two other options.<n><n>### Input :<n>I have a car that's 6 years old, which means it was built in 2013. What year will it be in 2020? Choices: A:2016 B:2019 C:2022 D:2025 E:2017<n><n>### Response : A:2019<n><n>### Rationale:<n>There are few other options that might seem to be the answer like 2022 because it is 6 years old. But it will be build before 2017 because 2017 is 2022 - 6 which is the other option that you might have chosen.<n><n>### ### Input :I got 4 apples, 7 oranges, and 2 bananas in my grocery bag. What fruit did I pick up? Choices: A.oranges B: bananas C: apples D: apple bananas E: oranges<n><n>### Response A:Bananas<n><n>### Ratione:The option that should be marked as the given should be the one in your grocery bag.<n><n>### For example:<n>I have 3 apples,  6 bananas, and 5 oranges in my grocery bags. What fruit Did I pick up?<n><n>Answer: Apples because that choice is among the ones in the grocery bag. Therefore, 5 is the sum of all the apples, bananas, oranges.<n><n>### It can also be expressed in the language of equality.<n><n>I have 3 + 6 + 5 == 14 =<<=14=2 bananas > 3 apples.<n><n>Therefore, I picked up apples.<n><n>### The sum of the bananas - 5 is 3, the sum of 5 oranges - 6, and the sum of 3 apples - 3.<n><n>### That is equivalent to 5 + 5+2==12 <n><n>Therefore, the answer 15 - 15+2
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? Choices:  A: admiration B: applaud C: make reservations D: experience E: sleep<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is E.<n><n>### Input : A man takes 7 days to go around the World. A boy takes 9 days to go around the same World. The boy finishes half of the distance of the man. What is the ratio of miles covered by a boy and a man?<n>### Rationales: A man takes 7*3600 seconds (sec) = <<7*360=25200>>25200 seconds to go round the world.<n><n>A boy takes 9*3600 sec = <<9*360=31400>>31400 seconds to go around the same world.<n><n>The boy covers half of the distance covered by a man.<n>Distance covered by a boy = 5/2 * 7200 = <<21600>>21600 sec<n><n>So, the ratio of miles covered is :<n>21600 / 25200 = <<5/4>>2/3 = 75%/87.5%<n>#### 75%/5<n>Answer: 87.5%/5<n><n>### Input - The two columns A and B has data to calculate the average of a column. Then you can only get the averages of column A or B. The input given would be the column that you want to get the average of.<n>#### Input<n>The row is the column to sum and the column is the column to average of. The sum of column B is 356, average of column B is 114. The sum of column C is 480, average of column C is 80. If the sum of column row is 10 and you want to average the row column which option would you choose? Choices: 1. Column A 2. Column B 3. Column C 4. Column D 5. Column E <n><n>#### Rationales 1)Column B's average is 114 so it is to be summed. <n><n>Since average of sum of column A is also required, then the column A should be the row column summing and column B should be the row column which requires average.<n><n>#### 1) Answer: Column B<n><n>#### Input<n>The sum of column A is 3
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is a person who is well educated? Choices:  A: illiterate B: knowledgable C: own house D: have enough food E: meet expectations<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def answer(word):<n>    if word == "knowledgable" or word == "educated" or word == "knows much":<n>        return "A"<n>    elif(word == "B" or word == "have a good education"):<n>        return "B"<n>    elif(work == "own house" or "C"):<n>        return 'C'<n>    elif(word in ["E" and "have enough food"]):<n>        return "D"<n>    else:<n>        return "E"<n>answer("A")<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```python<n>>>> What is a person well educated? Choices A. illiterate B. knowledgable C. own house D. have enough food E. meet expectations<n>>>> A<n>>>> What is knowledgable? Choices A. literate B. knowledgetble C. to speak Spanish D. to live in a city<n>>>> B<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The president had to make a decision regarding the hate attack on his country, what did he do? Choices:  A: wage war B: fight enemy C: kill D: destroy enemy E: attacked his country<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is [choice E answer].<n><n>### Rationales:<n>There are 4 options as follows: <n>* A => wage war <n>* B => fight enemy <n>* C => kill <n>* D => destroy enemy <n>Since the President attacked his countries, the president choice is [choice E answer] from the choices.<n><n>### Input<n>There are 25 students in 5 classes. 4 students are in each of 3 other classes. How many classes are there?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Input: There are 4 students in each of 3 different classes such that 25 = <<25/3=8.33>>8.33 classes.<n><n>### Answer: 25<n>Answer: 25<n><n>### Input There are 36 dogs. Some are male. 1/3 are male. There are twice as many spayed female dogs as unspayed female dogs. How many female dogs are there?<n><n>Output Rationales: 3/3=<<3/3=1>>1 male dog<n>2/3 = <<2/3=1>> 1 spayed female <n>1/3 = <<1/3=0.33>>0.33 unspayed female<n>So, 36 = <<36/0.33=111.2>> 111.2 unspayed female and 111.33/1 = <<111.3/1=111.3>>111.3 spayed female<n>Therefore, There are 232.66 female dogs.<n><n>### Rationale Answer: 232.5 female dogs.<n>```java<n>int male=1;<n>int numMale=4;<n>int female1=0;<n>int female2=0;<n>int spay=0;<n>int unspay=0;<n>numMale=numMale/spay;<n>male = male + numMale;<n>female1=female1+female2+(female2/unspay);<n>female2=(female2+male)/spay;<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If you tell you boss your suffering from boredom they'll likely tell you to get back to what? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. She did 90 push-ups on every day but Sunday. She did 45 crunches on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Fridays. How many push-ups and crunches did Ana do overall?<n>Rationales:\<n>Input: 9 days out of week = <<9 out of week is week=9>>9<n>90/9 = <<90/9=10>>10 push-ups for every day<n>10/9 = <<10/9=1>>1 push-ups for sundays<n>45/3 = <<45/3=15>>15 crunches for monday/tuesday/fridays<n>10+15 = <<10+15=25>>26 push-ups and 21 crunches<n>Out of 26 + 21 = <<26+21=47>>47<n>#### 47<n>Answer: 47<n><n>### Instructio:Input 2:In a school cafeteria, there are 191 students, 71 who have allergies, 43 who have asthma, and 32 who have neither. How many of those who have allergies do not have asthma or all of the other issues?<n>Rationales:'Input<n>#### 157<n>Answer: 169
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		<n>The letter A is correct about a bassoon is being played in an orchestra.<n>### Rationales:<n>[a] A. orchestras [is plural] are [not singular]. So a concert played by orchestras might include one or many. [It is unclear what instrument or instruments in orchestras are plural and singular, such that they can play an unpleasing sound. Is string plural (as in violin), while wind, brass & woodwind instruments are singular?]<n>### [b] A baritone woodwind instrument [singular] is also capable of playing an unpleasant sound (i.e. cacophony). [A baritone woodwind is unpleasing. Include a definition of a baritone woodwind for clarification.]<n>### A Symphony [plural] can also include unpleasant sounds. [symphony implies group of instruments]<n>### Playing [plural] music [singular] can result in a bassoon being played in an unpleasant fashion. [Playing is plural and music is singular. What happens? A bassoon sounds unpleasant? ]<n>### [c] High School Bands [singular] can sound unpleasant. [Bands are singular, so why does plural unpleasant fit? Do all students play instruments?]<n>[d] A. E [All?]<n><n>### A baritone woodwinds sound  is unpleasant. [The unpleasantness is in the sound of a baritone, whether singular or plural, and woodwind. Does a baritone sound unpleasant if you do not know what it is or what instrument it is on? Include a definition of this instrument.]
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where could a printer be used by thousands of people? There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. How many are there in all?<n><n>### Response<n>As Lucas has 2 times as much as Henry, and the 2 * (2/1) = (4/2) which equals Henry has 1 *(1/(1/2)) = (1/5) which equals 8 times more than Sam.<n>2/1 + 1/5 = (6/2) which equals 24/3.<n>3 * (24/3) = 11 *3 *24/3=72/3 = 24 (answer)<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Write a response that completes the paragraph, if possible, or if not possible, then write an explanation about how the problem is insufficient. If a goat has a kid, the number of sheep in the pen does not change. The number of goats in the pen increases by two. How many sheep were first in the pen?<n><n>### Rationales: The number that was first in the pen was first in the pen at the start and it remains first in the pen. The number is not affected by the kid or the increase by 2, thus it is always the first.<n><n>### Answer: 1<n><n>### Input - There are more sheep in a pen than goats. But if a goat has a baby, the number of sheep will not change. The number goats in the pen will increase by 2. How many sheep were originally in the pen?<n>Rationales - The number of sheep in the beginning remains the same until now.<n>The new number of sheep does not change the count of  the sheep in the beginning. However, the new number of goats changes the count of the sheep in the beginning now.<n><n>### Response -1<n><n>### 2<n><n>### Input- If you get a job in a factory, you're a worker. If you're working, you're on the payroll.<n><n>### Rationale- When you are already working, you are on the payroll, but when you get a job, you are a worker.<n><n>### 4<n><n>### Input  -  The city buses all run on natural gas. You can't smell it, so bus passengers are careful not to throw trash on the bus floor where the gas leaks could cause an explosion. When a bus driver parks, the bus brakes are set on "park," making it very hard to push the brakes. This is used so that a bus passenger who falls on one will not cause it to move accidentally.<n><n>### Input<n>-   2, 1, 4 10<n>-   9 1<n>-   1 3<n>-   1 4 3<n>-   9 3<n>-   8 4<n><n>## # Input- 9 x 3 = 27, 10 / 2 = 5, 1 + 4 + 3 = 8, 7 x 4 = 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where do kids find fish in their backyards? Choices:  A: boat B: ocean C: pond D: end of line E: ocean<n><n>### Response:		<n>C-pond.<n>D-end of line.<n><n>### Input- A pumpkin pie is 9.5 inches in diameter and 2.8 inches tall. How many pies can fit in a 11 by 15 inch pan?<n><n>### Answer:<n>6<n>666666<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Input:A pie is nine point five inches and if you slice it in half and the radius you cut is to you are in the middle.<n>Output:6<n><n>Input:how many piers can fit in a 6.5 by 12 foot<n>Output:3.5<n><n>### Demotest<n><n>A 4 gallon bucket contains 80 ounces of liquid.<n>How many cups are in a 4 gallon bucket?<n>80 ounces = 80/16 = <<80/16=5>>5 cups.<n><n>### Question:<n>In a classroom, there is yellow paint, blue paint, and red paint. There are 12 containers of blue paint, 24 containers of yellow paint, and 36 containers of red paint. In all, 72 containers were paint.<n><n>1. Johnson, 843 delegates voted for Barry Goldwater, and 424 uncommitted votes were cast. What percentage of the votes was cast by uncommitted delegates?<n>Rationales:(1964/2)*100 = <<1964/100=1964>>1964 votes.<n>A/360 = <<A/360=5/95>>5 votes.<n>B/843 = <<B/843=5/166>>5 votes.<n>C/424 = <<C/424=4/106>>4 votes.<n>Thus, the amount of votes that were cast by the uncommitted delegates was 4/95 = <<4/95=0.04>>0.04.<n>Therefore, 1964/360 = 5/95<n>0.04<n><n>424/424 = 40.<n>0.04 × 40 = 1.6<n>answer = 1.6(Answer)<n>#### 1.6<n>Answer: 1.6<n><n>### Instructor:If you were at the center of the universe, what would be the only direction you would feel inclined to travel in? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Fill in the blank with the correct amount.<n>45/6 - 23 =<n><n>#### Question:<n><n>1. A number _______ of 312 is greater than 312. <n><n>#### Question:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Jackson is a popular city name, but the one with a governor's office is where? Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input：A city with a governor's mansion is on a hill. A city with a mayor's mansion is in a valley.<n><n>### Response：<n><n>### Demons:A mansion is the residence of a governor or mayor.<n>A governor's<n><n>A. mansion<n><n>B. estate<n><n>C. residence<n><n>D. town mansion<n><n>E. city mansion<n><n>F. governor's office<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Demonic:City names are generally either <n><n>### Demestic:<n><n>### Democracies:<n><n>### A<n><n>### E<n><n>### F<n><n>### C<n><n>### D<n><n>### B<n><n>#### F<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input<n>Today's temperature is 87 degrees. Last week, it was one degree more. Last week, it rained. One week ago, it was 89 degrees. Next week, the temperature will be 19 degrees more. What will the temperature be on Monday?<n><n>### Response 1.<n>Today' s temperature is 87.<n>Last week, it was 88.<n>Thus, one degree more last week equals 88, which is two less than 90.<n>Thus, last week's temperature was 89.<n>One week ago, it was two weeks ago = 35 more.<n>Therefore, one week ago, it was = 36.<n>Next week, it will be 33  + 19 = 52 more, or 84 degrees.<n>Therefore, the temperature will be on Monday = 84 degrees.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The man wanted to take a bus, but all the chars were full of people doing what? They each carried one more apple than they needed and ate them at the same time. After having a total of 4 more apples than the number of walking students, the extra apples were distributed between students in such a way that one student carried five apples more than the others. How many apples were left over?<n><n>SOLUTION: The initial number of walking students was 10. (10x1)+9(4n-1). The sum of n+5, then is 44 + 5 = 49.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>Initial amount of apples: (10 x 1) – (9 x 4n – 1) > 4n – 4 – 9 = 1n – 5<n>Since they ate the 5 apples, the remaining amount of apples were 1+4n+9–5= 1n-4 = 49 – 4- 9) -> -6n + 43<n>Since there are 10 students, the initial number of apples = 10n-14 -> n-1<n>n=4 -> 1n=4<n>n=49 – 6 * (4-1)<n>After eating the 5 extra apples they all had 49 – 6 + 1 = 40 left to distribute.<n>n-4 = 0 : n=5 -> n=5-6 = -1<n>n=49 -6*(-1)<n>n= 30-6*(49-2-49) -> n=30-6(1+ 2+4<n><n>-6*(1+2 +4) = -6*7 = 42<n>n= 1n-n1 = 1/7 – 40/7 = 41/7 7: 15<n>n= 15 apples left over!<n><n>SOLUTIONS:<n>A group of students was taking their lunches in the c

I'm great!<n>1. I'll always have a few cents.<n><n>Sample Test case Output<n>1. I'M GREAT 2 : WORK GREAT<n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n>Roman Numeral: <n>You can put the roman Numeral.<n><n>**Examples**:<n><n>4 = iv<n>29 = xxix<n>xxxiv = lxxxv<n><n>10= x<n><n>### Direction<n>Input :<n><n>roman = 3iv<n><n>Output :<n><n>Answered<n><n>**Requirement**<n>If input has the right answer then the output has to be <n><n>Answered<n>else, output should be <n><n>Not Answered<n>

Choices:  A: cash drawer B: piggy bank C: purse D: box E: pocket<n><n>### Response:		 A: c<n><n>Input: If the price of gas was $3.35 a gallon, and you used a 20% off coupon on gas, how much would 1 gallon of gas cost exactly?<n>Rationales:(20/100)*3.35 = <<(20/10= 0.2)=20/20=1:0>>0.25.<n>3.35*0.25 = <<3.35*20/10=-3.35>>-3.35. So, the answer is -3.35.<n>#### -3.35<n>Answer: -3,35<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following two-step computation by constructing an equation to solve the problem.<n><n>Input: A 25-inch-high rectangular box is 9 inches wide and 12 inches long. How much does the box weigh?<n>RationalesThe weight = (length * 12) = <<(l*12)>>12inches = <<(l*2)=48000>>48000 pounds.<n>#### 48000<n>Answer: 48001<n><n>### Input:(1+2)/4 = ____/24<n><n>### Response:(1+2)/24 = <<1+2/4>><n><n>Input:A 120-gallon fuel tank is designed to burn 17 gallons of fuel per hour. At what rate, in gallons per minute, must the fuel pump work to fill the fuel tank?<n>RationalesSince, 120 = (17 *24 *3600), then the rate at which it fills the tank = 40/42 = <<20>*24*3600>>3600.<n>####3600<n>Answer:3600<n><n>### Question 10:<n>To pass the exam, you have to correctly answer 31 questions (19 of them multiple choice and 12 of them free response).<n><n>### Questions:<n>* [1](#1) [<n>1: What two fractions can you create from a third by dividing it? ](
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:where do children play a game? Choices:  A: toy store B: bar C: casino D: table E: family room<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Direction: Answer the questions in complete sentences.<n><n>### Which of the following statements describe the difference in the mean of the data in the table?<n><n>### <n>

Choices:  A: mail orders B: demand satisfaction C: place money on counter D: pay merchants with money E: spend money<n><n>### Response:		<n>The best answer is<n><n>### Output:<n>A. mail orders<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Place money on counter could not be used.<n>Pay merchants with money is wrong.<n>Spend money is wrong.<n>Demand satisfaction is wrong.<n><n>### Input :<n>For convenience some customers want to pay merchants with which technology? Choices:  a: cash b: credit bonds c: paper money d: plastic credit cards<n><n>### Response<n>The best answer is B. credit card. The reason is the answer for cash is wrong because cash is money that is spend by customers.<n><n>### Output<n><n>B. credit cards<n><n>## Instructions<n>Input: Three students are sharing 16 pills. If each student has an equal number of pills, how many pills does each student have?<n>Rationales<n>16/3 = <<16/3=5>>5<n>Hank has 5 pills.<n>Mackenzie has 5 pills too.<n>Zoe has 1 left.<n>Zoe had half of the pills, 8 pills. Zoe then had the 4 pills left.<n><n>In words we can add two: 15 is 3 left, so there is 3 - 15 = <<3-15=12>>12 pills.<n><n>Hank has 1 pill left of 7 left.<n>There are 6 pills because Hank has a fraction, he has a part of 6 and has a part of 9. We want to divide the whole of 6 by the part of 9. This is the same as multiply 9 by 2, and you can put the part of 9 as a half, with a fraction bar, and you get, or you can get it as 2/3. The way 2/3 goes like that 2/4, so now, and it's like this, we want to divide the whole by the part, and it's 6/3. If you divide it out, it does become 2 /3, by multiplying 3 by 2.<n><n>#### 6<n><n>Answer: 6 for each student;<n><n>#### ##<n><n>Answer: 8 for Hank and he has 5 left;<n><n>####

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:what can years of playing tennis lead to? Choices:  A: tennis elbow B: proffesional player C: exercise D: victory E: becoming tired<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The response should be E: BECOMING TIRED <n><n>### Input the correct answer in the textbox above.<n><n>The correct response is EXERCISE.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where are floors kept clean for holy purposes? Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Rationale:<n>C = synagogue<n>A, B, D, E don't make sense.<n><n>### Input- <n>- - -<n>Jesse went to the library at midday. He checked out more books than he checked out last week. He checked out six fewer books than he checked out three years ago. How much are his friends jeal?<n>Choices:  A: jealous B: more C: less D: jealous enough <n><n>### Response<n><n>D.<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>D = jealous enough.<n>A = more.<n>B = less.<n>C = jealous.<n>

Then select the correct answer. The correct answer depends on your knowledge of the language Arts.<n><n>Input: 3-digit numbers 427 and 259 have the sum of their digits equal to 7. 259 - 427 =<n>Rationales: If you have found two number and the sum of digits of the two number is 7 (or divisible by 2), the difference of the 2 numbers should be 11-7 = <<11-7=4>> or divisible by 2.<n><n>427 + 259 = <<427+259=686>>686<n>686 - 686 = 0<n><n>Answer:: 259 and 427<n><n>Input : 6.98x10^5 - 1.89x10^2y10 = 4.99x10^4<n>Rationales: First convert both the expression to a fraction and then subtract it.<n><n>(6.98/1)*(18.9/2)= 999.99<n><n>999.9 * 4.99= 4999.6<n><n>4999.9 - 49.96 = 4959.996<n><n>Answer:: 323748<n><n>Input : - 3333.33 = 443333.66<n>Rationales: Convert -3333.22/2 into an expression.<n><n>-3333.11 / 2= -1666.53<n><n>-1666.66/2 = -833.33<n><n>(-833.3/2) = -

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If a human is sleepy what can they do to feel more alert? Choices:  A: dream dreams B: think critically C: cross road D: drink coffee E: drive a car<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer:<n><n>Answer: D<n><n>Answer:<n>24<n><n>### Input<n>If a person is hungry, he can think about eating something or drink something to feel better or eat something.<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>Answer:<n>A<n><n>Answer:<n>4<n><n>### Response
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where might I find unusual varieties of roses? Choices:  A: botanic garden B: flower garden C: backyard D: supermarket E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is choice ____.<n>

Choices:  A: expect to die B: believe in god C: stay in D: watch movies E: eat corn<n><n>### Response:		<n>Therefore, the correct answer is C(Stay In).<n><n>### Input<n>C: Stay. A: Expect. B: Believe. D: Watch. E: eat.<n><n>### Response<n>The correct answer is "C" since stay is the correct answer for the riddle.<n><n>### Input :<n><n>Dennis is 10 years old. If Dennis is 30% older than Linda, then how old is Linda in total?<n><n>### Solution<n>Let L be the age of Linda and l be the age difference between linda and Dennis<n><n>(1) Linda - Dennis - 10 + l<n><n>(2) l = L-(Dennis-10)<n><n>Now,<n>(3) L = L -10 +L (10 -Dennis)<n><n>(4) 10 - Dennis = 30% of L, L = 100 - 30% L = 40% L<n><n>(5) 30% L, L = 40 		L = 40 x 40% = 16<n><n>Linda will be 16 years old.<n><n>### If you have a group of animals in a zoo and there are 6 cats, 3 birds, and 4 dogs. What kind of number are they?<n>If you have a group of cat, bird and dog.<n><n>### Solution.<n>The number is a triangular like 1 (cat), 2 (bird) and 3 (dog).<n><n>The total is 3 + 2 + 1 = 6 which is a triangle.<n><n>### Find the prime number that is less than 70.<n><n>### Step by step solution.<n><n>Solution: 80 is a prime number. so, the next prime number is 81<n><n>### If a number is positive and is three times the difference of two numbers. If the difference of the first two numbers is negative, what will the sum of the first two numbers be?<n><n>### Step-by-step solution.<n><n>##### Two numbers a and b<n><n>Since the number is positive, the both numbers are greater than 0.<n>The difference between a and b can be positive or negtive (i.e. a
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where can the legs of a stool be built? Choices:  A: jail B: internet cafe C: blacksmith's shop D: building E: bar<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think the correct answer is either C or B because every other choice is nonsense or too simple.

The price of apples is less than the price cereal. What is the price of cereal?<n>Response:The price of cereal is the sum of the sum: the price of orange, the price of apple, and the price of cereals.<n><n>### 51% 51% of those tested got this question right.
