There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:John was stuck in his house.  He couldn't get out the door.  He was very frightened when the smoke detectors went off, but luckily it was a false alarm.  Why might he be stuck? Choices:  A: fire B: belong to C: winter storm D: face south E: burn down<n><n>### Response:		<n>This is a true story I heard about a guy who was stuck <n>in his house.  He couldnt get out the door. He was very frightened <n>when the smoke detectors went. He was luckly it was a false alarm  <n>but why he might be there is because of there is a winter storm <n>or he could be burnt down <n><n>---<n>---<n>---<n><n>### Input 3:There is a 37% probability that a man will be injured while using a lawn mower. If every 100 people use a lawn mower, what is the probability that 10 people are injured?<n><n>### Rationales:To get 10 people injured, 10 = 10/100 ⇒ 10/1 = 10 = 37/100 ∝ 0.37.<n>Therefore, the probability that 1 is = 0.37<n><n>---<n>---  ---<n>---<n>```csharp<n>private object Test06_02_2020(){<n>    return (0.37);<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>---<n>---     ---<n>---<n>```<n>private object Test07-02-2020(){ <n>    45 <n>}<n>```<n><n>---             ---
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The lady was getting worked up about the article explaining the uptick in accidents in their area, but her husband was dismissive of it stating that accidents what? Choices:  A: happen to people B: hurt people C: happen anytime D: happen often E: happen anywhere<n><n>### Response:		The lady was getting worked up. She was angry about the article explaining the increase in accidents in their district, but her husband said she was being worked up because accidents happen all the time and did not mean anything.<n><n>### Inputs:The man walked to campus every day and he always noticed that the woman always got out of her car at the same corner every day. Choices: A: a different corner B: the same corner C: a different store D: a different parking area E: a different restaurant<n><n>### Response A woman walked to school every day and always noted that a particular woman got out of her car every day at the exact corner.<n><n>### Response She was so close that it was like an obsession for her.<n><n>### How to write the answer:<n>To respond to this task, you must first understand what it is saying. Is this a story about a man on a walk to the campus and a woman doing the same? Is this a story about him spotting someone doing something mundane and making a point out of it?<n><n>As such, when you are writing a response, you want to pay attention closely to the details given and focus on making sure that you are rephrasing the words using appropriate tone.<n><n>What are the best ways to summarize a story? Choices:  A: bounce the ball B: competition C: have fun D: race E: score points<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are five choices A, B, C, D, E, the sentence has a noun "they", which should be used to modify "they were competing in basketball...", The sentence also contains a verb "were competing in basketball...". The noun "they" should be used to modify the verb. To modify a noun and a verb (which are the same class and must always be used as a subject (A subject is a noun, verb, or pronoun that initiates a sentence or phrase), only ONE of them can modified by a noun or pronoun, for example, if I were John I would be very rich. If I was a dog, I would be very well-behaved.

How many white chips are there in a class room?`<n><n>### Answer:"40 are white chips."<n><n>### Question:12 + 7<n><n>### Answer: 19<n><n>### Question:`916 * 126 * 855 * 485`<n><n>### Question:-6 − 3 − 9 − 2<n><n>### Answer:-12<n><n>### Question `908 ∗ 489`<n><n>###Question`(53 − 17) + (17 − 4)`<n><n>###Answer`20`<n><n>###Instruction:<n><n>###Response:<n><n>### Input `:5 *:5 =:25`<n><n>## :Question:How many apples did he buy?`<n><n>## #Answer:`"8"`.<n><n>## #Instruction:`Pete is on vacation visiting his great-great-great-grandparents in Boston. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The snake was a cottonmouth.  It was an American, from where? Choices:  A: georgia B: tree C: nature D: under the rocks E: france<n><n>### Response:		The correct response is: answer "C"<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following matching question.<n><n>## Example 1: Answer the question with one of the choices indicated by the letter to the left of the question.<n><n>## Instructions:Find the term with the indicated base and exponent.<n><n>## Example: -37<n><n>### -37, answer "1"<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Choices:  A: in cinema B: at the park C: martorell D: jeep E: airplane<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Rationales:**<n>The person can't be in cinemas and parks since they have to watch the movie. At the park, the person can be walking around, but that doesn't mean he will use the parking space. The same goes for the martorell, jeep, and airplane. The correct option is D.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input : The temperature was 10 degrees above 0 degrees F. How much did the temperature increase by? Choices: A: 10 B: 20 C: 30 D: 40 E: Above 40<n><n>### Response<n>**Rationales**<n><n>If we divide the temperature by 0 then 10 degrees above means 10/(10-0)=D(degrees degrees)<n><n>#### <n><n>Answer: B<n><n><details><summary>Full working out</summary><n><n><p><n></p><n><n><p markdown="span"><n><n>### ANSWER<n><br><n> <table><tr><td><p><n>  10<n><n><p style="text-align:right;"><n>[▾](work_examples_3.md)<n><n>[⬆️](#top)<n><n></p><n></td></tr></table><n><n></p> <n><n>### EXPLANATION<n><p><n><b>Rationales:</b><n>If we divide the <i>temperature<sup></sup></i> by <i><sup>0</sup></i> then <i>10 degrees above 10 degree<sup> (°F)</sup> </i> means <i>(10/0)=1<sup>0</sup> degrees over 0 degree</i><n><n>: 0<sup>0</Sup>≜0 D<sup>0</sUP><n><n>: 1<sup>0.</sup>≜1 D<sup>0.</sUp><n><n>: 2<sup>0.</Sup>≟1 D<sup>1.</sUp><n>: 3.<sup>0.</SUp>.≟ 3 D<sup>2.</sUp><n>

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. She took the one in the last column off the edge of the ones. How much money did she have left?<n>Rationales Alice had 5 ones in the first row; the one in the middle was dropped in the 4th row; the one in middle was dropped in 7th row; and the one in the middle of the 6th row was dropped on the 6th row.<n>She has 5 $1 bills.<n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Instructor: Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>## Demostration: Input: A pizza has 8 slices, and each slice has 2 cups. A family orders 3 pizzas and wants all the cups to add together to 24. How many cups are on the pizzas?<n>Rationales A pizza has 12 cups, or 8+4 = <<8+4=12>>12 cups.<n>A family orders 3 pizza = 3 x 12 = <<3*12=36>>3 pizzas.<n>36 cups are on the three pizza.<n>#### 36<n>Answer: 36<n><n>### Demostración:<n>Input: 2 tablespoons = 1 cup. A student cooks 1/3 cup of rice. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The delivery man was delivering a whole crate of shampoo, they went through a lot of it at the what? Choices:  A: supermarket B: motel C: at hotel D: shampoo bottle E: hair salon<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Answer:C<n><n>#### Reference:https://www.wyzant.com/resources/lessons/math/basic_arithmetic/multiplication__division_word_problems_<n><n>### Task<n>Below is a multiple choice question with one best answer. Write a response that demonstrates an understanding of subtraction of fractions.<n><n>### Input Question:<n>What is the sum of 7/9 - 5/18?<n><n>### Response Question 1:Write a response that appropriately answers the question.<n><n>## Example Responses<n><n>7/9 - 11/18 = <<7/9-11/18=113-11/12-3/12=22/12-13/12>>4/12 = 0.3333... or 1/3<n><n>### Rationales:<n>7/9 = <<7/9=1>>1 (the numerator divided by the denominator).<n>11/18 - 5/12 = <<11/18-5/12=6/12>>6/12<n>5/18 - 1/12 = <<5/18-1/12=4/12>>4<n><n>### 1-2<n>Answer: 0.33<n><n>### Task Input:<n>B: Choose one: <n>Choices = 1: 2+5=<<2+5=7>><n>2: 4+3=<<4+3=7>><n>3: 4+2=<<4+2=6>><n><n>### Response<n>Write at least one sentence using a colon to complete the problem.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Summary<n><n>#### Explanation<n><n>In this task, you were given a question with answers. In response, you provided a complete response that describes the problem. If this is what is specified in the task, it's best to have the learner respond by accurately describing what they saw as the answer, and not as a simple response of a statement that agrees with the answer.<n><n>### Featured Practice:<n>- [Review](review.html)<n>- [B
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:James didn't know what to do.  He felt that he'd ruin his relationship with Jen if he took it further, and he didn't want to do that.  At the same time,  He fight that pushing farther might do what to something good? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Why is this person not listening to music? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: relaxation C: deafness D: bored E: calm<n><n>### Response:		C: deafness<n><n>### Input :  What is half of one-sixth of 125?<n><n>### Response : 2.5<n><n>### Input  : <n>```<n>Choose a number:<n>4<n>Input: A group of nine volunteers is painting a bus terminal. There are 2 more men than women, and each women works on a wall different than the men do. How many people are on the job? How many people work on each wall?<n>Rationales Answer:<n>9 - 2 = <<9-2=7>>7 men<n>8 is for women<n>6 is for the men<n>6 × 2 = 12<n>12/4 = <<12/4=3>>3 people working on each wall<n>9 - 2 + 3 + 3 = <<9-2+3+3=10>>10 people are working on the job<n>````<n><n>### In class, John counted the seats in the gym. He found that 23 red seats, 8 blue seats, and 16 green seats were used. He found that his total of 47 seats was 1 more than half of the green seats. How many green seats are there?<n>### Response :<n>* 47 green seats <n>* In the class, there are 3 green seats<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>There are 8 green seats, 3 orange seats, and 7 red seats in each classroom of a school. There are twice as may blue seats as orange seats. How many seats are orange and how many are blue?<n>```<n><n>## Input 2 <n><n>Choose a number  4 <n><n>Choose another number: 6 <n><n>The sum is 10 <n>```<n>Input: In a baseball team, what is the sum of a, b, and c? Choices: A: None of these B: 10 C: 7 D: 18 E: 10<n>There are 9 people on the baseball team - Choice D is the correct answer. <n><n>Choose two numbers: 7 26 <n><n>The product is 184 <n>```<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where do you keep a teakettle? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>E – Englang.<n><n>### Input The number of gallons of paint a company sold in January was 8% more than the number of gallons sold in September. In April, they sold seven times more gallons than they did in September. How many gallons of paint were sold in April?<n><n>### Response<n>694<n>### Input: In April, they sold 15.2 gallons more paint than in September and 7 times more paint than in January. In May they sold 3.2% fewer gallons of paint than in April. How many gallons were sold in May?<n><n>### Rationales<n>15.2 x 4/5 × 15.2/3 = 242.1<n><n>### Input<n>The number of gallons of milk the company sold in January was %36 less than the number of gallon sold in September. And they sold 3 gal/2 gal = 1.5 gal more in October than in July. The number of gallons in Nov was the same as the number of gallons in June. How many gallons did they sell in Nov?<n><n>### Answer<n>220<n><n>### Input A store will double a sale price to get the sale up to the normal price. The cost of selling an item at this point is 1/3 of the original price. For example, if you sell a car for $20,000 and the final price is $20,050, the cost of selling is 1/3*20,00 = $10,000. If you sell a bike for $150 instead and double the price to $300, the cost of sale is $150/3 = $50. The 2nd sale cost is always less than the 1st sale cost.<n><n>### Question<n>What is the cost to sell a toy at least once at the price of $7. 2 and more times at the price of $5.99?<n><n>###  Rationales<n>At $7.2, the cost to sell it once is $7.2 * 3/7 = $2.7.  and then $1.4 after that. <n><n># Tip: 3/7 is 0.4
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The disease was spreading fast, so what were researchers desperately seeking? (A) How many different numbers with a sum of 50 can be selected from this set? (B) How many possible combinations of a, b, and c are there within these five constraints?<n><n>### A and B:<n><n>Answer:<n><n>> The sum of two, four, six, eight, and ten is 26.(A)How many different numbers with a given sum of 26 can be selected from the set {two, four, six, seven, eight, ten}? (B) How can the five numbers in the set be arranged so that all three conditions (sum of 26, even, and divisible by one and three) are satisfied?<n><n>### Answer A:<n><n>>  There are 6 different numbers with a given a sum of 26.<n><n>### A rationales:<n><n>1. there are 6 different numbers (2, 2+4=6 ; or 2, 2+6=8; or 2, 4=6 etc:) with a given sum of a number and even number like 10, 2, 4 etc..<n>Therefore, there is 7 numbers to be selected to have the given sum 26.<n>But, there are 5 variables left.<n>4 is subtracted to have the number 26 and 3 is left.<n>Therefore, the number of options is 3 to have 26 as the sum of given number.<n><n>3)There are 6 number of ways and arrangements. (2, 4; 2, 6; 2, 2, 2 etc)<n>Therefore, the

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where do you go to meet a friend who lives close to you? Choices:  A: workplace B: bus station C: social atmosphere D: neighbor's house E: at school<n><n>### Response:		Choice Answer:<n><n>```<n>Answer:E<n>```<n><n>### Rationales: <n>1. B:Bus station<n>2. C:Social atmosphere<n>3. A:workplace<n>4. D:Neighbor's house<n>5. E:at school<n>####C<n>Answer:C<n><n>### Input/output 2:Write a response that appropriately  completes the task of determining what a function is.<n>Input: We have several functions, including this one: f(x) = x^2 - 9x + 20   What do you notice about this function?<n>Rationales:: <n>1. We can create a chart to organize the data for the function f(x) = <n>x^2 - 9 x + = 0, including the domain, range, and y-intercept, which is (0, -20).<n><n>2. We can create a table to help identify any turning points along the function.<n><n>3. We can find vertical asymptotes and x-intercepts using the function.<n>4. The domain includes every Real number (R), along with infinity (± ∞) on both sides of the sign in front of the x-axis, along with every -∞ on the left side of the sign in front. <n>  The range includes every Real number (0, -2), along with every +∞ on the right side of the sign infront. <n>4. The vertical asymptotes are 2, -2, and 0. <n>5. There are no x-intercepts<n><n>Answer:f(x) :  x^2 - 4x + 6<n><n>##   Input/output 3: Write a response that appropriatley completes the  task  of  determining  the horizontal and vertical asymptotes  using the function and graph.<n>Input:  Determine the horizontal and vertical asymptote(s) of each function.<n>Rationales: We can identify the horizontal and vertical asymptotse(s) using the function. The vertical asymptotes of a function f(x) are the x-values at which the function equals infinity. The horizontal asymptote of a function is the line along the y-axis that the function approaches.<n>####3<n>Answer:3<n><n>### Input 4:Write a response that appropriate

Choices:  A: complications B: tiredness C: anger D: trial E: court case<n><n>### Response:		<n>Civic action can result from being tired of a situation that the government should handle to benefit the public, but instead the government is ignoring or not taking steps to improve it. Civic action was instigated by Rosa Parks when she was told to give up her seat on a public bus to give it to someone else, but Rosa Parks refused, and this caused the Montgomery bus boycott. Rosa and the boycott became the focus of the attention the government should have been on for years. Rosa did not want to instigate the boycott, but it was forced upon her by an unjust rule that her actions began with. This shows how civil action can result from feeling like civil action is necessary and warranted.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input 33.17 × 33.18 =<n><n>### Response 1000.685<n><n>### Input The number of chicks per nesting box = 8. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:John hated mosquitoes.  It wasn't the bloodsucking that he disliked, it was that the insects made what? Choices:  A: fly B: buzz C: move D: honey E: help flowers pollenate<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationales:Answers choice B.<n><n>### Input 2:What does the 1-5 on the left refer to? Choices:  The 5 numbers in the first box on the left  The 1st 5 numbers in the second box on the right  The 5th 1 in the right column  The 5th number on the left The 5th number in the left column  The 5 times the first number is greater than 5<n><n>### Response 2:Answer choice B<n><n>### Rationale for Input 2:Answers choice b since there are 1's through 5 on the left side,<n>but the first box of numbers only list the numbers by one.<n><n>

Choices:  A: amusement B: losing money C: charmed D: having fun E: win money<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A: The family were playing cards, what would have been the best choice to play with these kinds of games? Choices:  a: amusement b: losing money c: charmed d: having fun e: win money<n>Rationales: A: amusement, B: losing money, C: charmed, D: having fun, E: win money<n>The family was playing cards in a room, in a classroom, in a hotel room, on an afternoon, in a morning, in the evening and during free time.<n>So, the best choice will be A,<n>the word 'charmed' means something good or nice.<n><n>#### E<n>Answer: "To win money" - it is the best choice.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. I read books to learn when I am bored.<n><n>### Input:"Linda found a shiny new green marble under the tree. The green marble was worth as much as 4 blue marbles and 2 purple marbles combined." Choices: A: it was not worth anything B: it was only worth 2 green marbles C: it was worth 2 green marble D: it was worth 1 green marble<n><n>The blue marbles and purple marbles could be worth<n>The blue marbles were worth 2 green marbels<n>The purple marbles were worth 4 green marbels<n>Therefore,<n>Green marble = total worth of all marble in the tree<n>Purple marble worth 4/2 green marbles<n>Blue marble worth 2/4 green marbles<n>The total worth of the marbles is 4/2+2/4+1<n>8/4 Green marble = 2<n>Thus the green marble is worth more.<n><n>### In 311, what question are you asked by the guard? Input B: 8. Input C: 4. Input D: 8. Input E: 36. Input F: 10.<n>Rationales:Input A:38. Input B:#8. Input C:#4. Input D:#8. Input E:#36. Input F:#10<n><n>### A:#38×B:#8=288<n>### A×B÷C:B×D×E:4×Input F:10<n><n>## Answeer:<n>There are 38 * 8 = 302 chairs for each table. <n><n>Their are 36*38=1304 cups.<n><n>There are 302*6=1812 plates on a table.<n><n>### 593×300÷45=7/1/2767 = 2768<n>### Instruzioni<n>Write 3 soluzioni per ognuna delle 3 tasi presenti.<n><n>### E<n>A) 7
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If I take my heifer out East, where's a place we might end up? Choices:  A: new hampshire B: dairy farm C: farm field D: texas E: county fair<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would end up at a dairy farm.  Farmers take pride in their animals, and love their animals as though they are family.  That is why farmers give their animals "good names" like  "Moonbeam" and "Buttermilk".<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response to the input.<n><n>### Input<n>Jim got in his car after school and drove straight to his grandparents' house. Later in the day, he drove four hours and fifty miles from his grandparents' to his uncle's apartment, where he stayed for a few days. Which of these is the best description of the number of hours Jim drove overall? Choice: A: 0 B: less than 8 C: more than 8 D: more than 12 E: around 8 F: around 12 <n><n>### Choice:C<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The number of hours driven overall was about 8 hours.<n>How many minutes? 400 (since 4 hours is 120 minutes, and 1250 miles is 50 miles for each minute, 400 minutes or 16 hours for each hour of drive)<n><n>### Input to be completed:<n>Ann's father drove 140 miles with her family on Sunday, but he also had to go into his store for 45 minutes, so they stopped there before dinner. When they got home, they had covered 390 miles since leaving on Saturday. What's the best way to represent the number of miles they traveled overall?<n><n>### Choices: B C D E F<n><n>### Choosen: E<n><n>### Rational:<n>They traveled 140+390 = <<140+315=455>>455 miles over the weekend<n>140 is 4 hours, so 140/4=<<140/4==35>>35 minutes. They had to stop for 45 minutes.<n>45 more than 35 is 110, or 6*18.<n>```python<n>455 miles <n><n>```<n><n>

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. If the urban area has a combined population of 55,155 how many people are in the town?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>**The urban area's population** is 2x the town's people. Therefore, the town's population is \[2*\frac{n}{2}\] where \[n\] is \[55,150\].<n>Rationally, \[n*\frac{1}{2}\] is \[33,075\]. So, \[n\] is \[35,150 \div 75\]. Therefore:\[\frac{35,155}{75}=488.6\].<n>#### 488.6<n>Answer: 488.<n><n>### Input; A:A class has 15 boys, 22 girls. howmany students in the class?<n><n>### Response; 37<n><n>### Instructions; Answer the true or false question.<n><n>## Input:In each row, 35 less than twice of each number is subtracted from each number.<n><n>A.Each statement in the given equation is false.<n><n>##Response: Integers are not allowed in the equation.<n><n>#### None<n>Answer: True<n><n>### Input A; There are 9 more people in the town in 1933 then. there are 2015. Their route cut through the united states.<n><n>### Input:[18, 12, 6, 15]<n><n>### Rationales:The first two numbers are 18 and 12.<n><n>### The next number is a factor of the first two and the last number.<n><n>### 18 is a factor of 15<n><n>### So, the next two numbers are 12 and 15.<n><n>### That makes the numbers 12 and 6.<n><n>### To get the total you use this formula:<n>18 + (12 + 6) = ________<n><n>### The answer 51.<n><n>### ## This answer uses subtraction to solve for the missing number.<n>### The following are some other ways that you can find this number:<n><n>### ## The way to calculate this is to use this formula: 18 + (15 * 2) = ________ Add in the 6 and you get 18 + (30 * 2) = 51.<n>### ## The numbers 18 and 30 are factors of 50.<n><n>### Rough numbers or the answer: 18 ÷ 2 <n><n>### 20<n>### Input:<n>552.975 + 311,643.958 - 400,002.184 = _______<n><n>### Difficulty:<n>What is 39% of 700?<n><n>### Rationals:<n>If you add 3 things together and they equal more than 111800 then subtract 1118.<n><n>### Subtraction:<n>552 + 311 - 400 = _______<n>552 = 1,118, 311 = 1,109, 400 = 100<n>552 =10,118 < 700(70)<n><n>### There are 311 thousands<n><n>311 = 300 * 1001 + 11<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:You are seeking to provide yourself what when you're applying for a job? Choices:  A: work B: employment C: income D: hope E: offer<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>***<n><n>### Instructions:Read the sentence and choose the correct response to each question. Answer three of the <n>five questions.<n><n>In my opinion, the best teacher is often a terrible actor.<n><n>#### Rationale<n><n>This is a statement.<n><n>#### 1200<n>Answer: 1200 <n><n>If you're looking for a job, remember to always keep on the lookout for something new.<n><n>#### Rationales<n><n>This is a command that asks you to use the appropriate word, "something."<n><n>#### 1302<n>Answer: 1302 <n><n>My father is a wonderful father.<n><n>#### Ration:<n><n>This is a positive statement.<n><n>#### (1302)Answer: Answer (1302)): 1302) <n><n>My father and I had dinner, and he didn't spend any money.<n><n>#### Rated:<n><n>This is an action verb. <n><n>#### 1005<n>Answer 1005: 1005 Answer 1005)): 100 5) <n><n>Todd has read The Great Gatsby, and he is currently reading The Lord of the Flies.<n><n>#### Rate:<n><n>This is correct because there are two things that must occur to form a sentence. There must be a subject of the sentence, and there must be a predicate. <n><n>####273<n>Answer: 273<n><n>### Response and Instruction: <n><n>Your answer is written on the line in the space provided.<n><n>**Note: For each question, select only one letter or one word: **<n><n>A. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where can someone purchase a contraceptive device without a prescription? Choices:  A: pharmacy B: person C: drugstore D: bedroom E: mcdonalds<n><n>### Response:		A,B,C<n><n>Answer:A,B,C

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Then, you'll use the speaker's note to write the speech for the speaker.<n>A note is defined as a series of 0's and 1's. It is a combination of binary code.<n>Binary code can be expressed or expressed by using the notation 111101, where each digit is 1 or 0 and each word has the same value in the binary code.<n>For example, 111111 is 255, which is the value of all 1's in binary code.<n>1110100 is 228, which is the value, which is 3 times 72.<n>1100110 is 137, which is the value 3 times 45.<n>1101101 is 150, which is the value twice 75.<n>#### 75<n>Answer: 75<n><n>### Instructions 2.1: A sample of 12 data values was chosen from a normal distribution, and the mean was computed. Then you made a data point. You are not required to enter an answer, answer a question, or use information in the instructions or text. Click on the submit button. There is no penalty for incorrect answers or no answer.<n><n>### Input<n>In the data set, the following numbers were sampled 12:67,45,54,79, 65, 97, 90, 101, 88, 82, and 80<n><n>##

In the space provided, write the question that most closely matches the directions. Then, write the answer.<n><n>### Input<n>My brother got a new guitar.<n>He wants to play the guitar perfectly.<n>How can he practice at home?<n>Choose ONE option. <n>__A__ Write simple songs and practice the chords until they feel easy.<n>__B__ Listen to a famous guitar player and then play until you can play at that level.<n>__C__ Play a song he likes and practice the hard parts.<n>__D__ Listen to an online podcast that teaches guitar in the spare time he has for playing.<n>__E__ Play the easy parts several times.<n>__F__ Play the difficult parts to learn exactly what it feels like to play perfectly.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store dirt in my home, where could I put it? Choices:  A: fingernails B: garden C: corner D: computer E: closet<n><n>### Response:		If I'm looking for an answer other than D, I would use (other than D)<n><n>### Rationales:None<n><n>#### Answer: A<n>\[ \begin{align} A=dirt(E is a no no)\end{align}\]<n><n>### Input;Due to a recent drought, the city placed restrictions that allowed people to water houseplants only every third day. One household had 5 houseplants. How many times a week could the household water their houseplants? Choices: 1: every ___ day 2: every night 3: every ___ hours 4: every ___ minute 5: every second 6: every ___ week<n><n>### Response;If every one were not true, i would use (other than)<n><n>### Input(answer) :1: every ___ days(Every ___ month; every ___ night; every ___ year; every ___ hour; Every ___ week)<n>Every ___ month => 0.333333 = 13.33,33333 minutes a week<n>### Rational;(to reduce the number of letters)<n><n>### Answer :2 <n><n>### Input :The table below shows the amounts of money in 5 different financial accounts owned by John over a period of 8 months. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:I need a person to milk a cow would a volunteer do this? What is -2 less than -30? ____<n><n>### Rationales:<n>If -30=<<-30=32>>32 then 227=<<227=75>>75.<n>Then -7=<<-7=73>>73<n>Therefore, <<>>7.<n>#### 7<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Input:\-60-25 -35 +30 x: 333 - 32 = ____<n><n>## Rationales:<n>\-60-20+<=><<-2%10=-6>>-6+<<1+(100-6)/10=40>>x+<<45+-14/4=91>>91x=<<91-91=0>>x<n><n>#### 513<n>Answer: 513<n><n>## Above this line is blank<n><n>### Input<n><n>What is the sum of 5 + 5 + 5?<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately gives the sum of the number.<n><n>#### 15<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input :What is 90% as a reduced fraction? Choices:-9/30, -90/300 or -75<n><n>### Response : -75/300<n><n>#### -75/3<n>Answer: -75/3 <n><n>### Input 18 + 23 + <<>> -7<n><n>### Response 18 + 30 = 48<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What are people playing when they want to take the lead with small papers? Choices:  A: very heavy B: video game C: news article D: card game E: lead pencil<n><n>### Response:		<n>C answer<n><n>### Demystifying:<n>C. Card game<n><n># Programming Practice Problems<n><n>### In the list below, identify the following problems using capital letter code.<n><n>### Problem Name:<n>B<n><n>### Problem Length:<n>0 < L < 200<n><n>### Solution Name:<n>B<n>### Solution Length:<n>0 <= S <= 200<n>### Demonsteration:<n>For all problems, you must identify the problem, then give a list of problems that solves the problem. You can provide this problem with any name, but it must be clear that it solves the given problem.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>For input <n>N, you must indicate how large N is. You cannot assume the value of N is in the range. For output, you must indicate how much the output is in bits. This is usually in HEX. <n>### Instructions:<n>The problem names and the solutions need to have 2 instructions.<n>**Problem Name:** B<sub>N</sub><n>What information is needed to solve this problem? Here are examples:<n>    - 1<n>    - 72<n>    - 12<n>    - <<12-1=11>>11 <n>Here is an example with one instruction for the input and output problem:<n>Input: N, the number of integers, must be an integer between 0 and 72 inclusive, then the bits of the integer will be given in the output (the bits of the integer are in hexadecimal).<n>#### Output:<n>    - B<sub>12</sub><n>    - <<278D>>278D <n><n><n><n>```java<n>public class P5_4_Largest_BitSet {<n><n>    public static void main(String[] args) {<n>        Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);<n>        int N = sc.nextInt();<n>        long a = convert(N);<n>        System.out.println(convert(a));<n>    }<n>    <n>    public static long convert(int N) {<n>        long[] b = new long[1 << N];<n>        long s = 0;<n>        <n>        for (int i = 0; i < 1 << N; i++) {
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. What are the numbers?<n>Solving: We know that the sum of the three whole numbers is 2 x 2  + 2  + 3  =  242,<n>so we can set the sum x  +  x  + 3  to equal the number x<n>Therefore, x + x + 3 = x + x<n>x + x = 2 x<n>x  = 12, or x = 12 + 3<n>Therefore, the three numbers are 15, 16, and 17<n>```<n><n>### Input;3.5 + 3.2 is what?<n><n>### Answer; The answer is 6.7.<n><n>

There are 8 more boys than girls, and 20 fewer students than a total of 51. How many students are there in a class?<n><n># 21<n>> 8 +7 + 1 girl<n><n>### Input Jack has 150 pairs of socks. 15 are blue. The rest are white. Twenty-three pairs are faded. How many pairs of socks does Jack have?<n><n># 38<n>> 15 + 23<n><n>### Input What is a man's job? Choices:  C: make money B: give money D: go shopping E: give presents A: cook<n><n>### Response<n>Cook<n><n>### Input Which way do rabbits come if they are traveling north? Choices: C: east D: west B: south<n><n>### Response East<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>This is not a question, but you respond to the multiple choice question above.<n>There is no correct answer for this.<n>#### No answer<n>Answer:<n><n><n>### Input<n>The carpenters use all the wood for the cabinet. Which statement reflects a relationship between fractions?<n><n>- The carpenters used 3/4 of the wood.<n>- The carpentere used at least a quarter as much wood as the cabinet.<n>- The carpenter used 5/16 as much wood as the door they built.<n>- None of the statements reflect a relationship between fractions.<n><n>### Response I have to choose the statement that reflects a relationship between the fractions.<n><n>- The carpeter used 3/4 as much wood as the carpenters used.<n><n>### Answer<n>None of the
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What kind of people will someone who is in charge of project look for? Choices:  A: greedy B: worry C: have knowledge D: take charge E: boss<n><n>### Response:		<n>- I will look for a boss.<n>- I need someone who knows how to do it.<n><n>#### C<n>(boss)<n>

Choices:  A: loft B: home depot C: house D: tiles E: carpet store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**A**<n><n>### Input 2:There was a man who ordered breakfast everyday for the month of July. Each breakfast was the same. The food cost $100. The total he needed to pay was $60. How did he get so much for so little?<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n><n>**He went to breakfast buffet.**<n><n><n>### Input : 17<n><n>### Response :<n>[17](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1wKgHjLh107jPbOoHvKRwV0QNlzp5DQZv6gXRQX-55Ag/)<n><n><n>### Note that **bold numbers are even** and **underline numbers are odd**<n><n>### ANSWERS<n><n>#### Input:<n>4 + 6 = <<4+6=10>>10<n>10 - 7 = <<10-7=3>>3<n><n>#### Input:5 + 2 + 1 = <<5+2+1=8>>8<n>8 + 2 = <<8+2=10>>1<n><n>#### Input:6 and 4 = <<6 and 4=10>>1 and 3 = <<1 and 3=4>><n>1 and 1 = <<1+1=2>><n><n>#### Input: The number of blocks was 5 + 4 = <<5+4=9>>9<n>A and 50 = <<A+50=50>><n><n>#### Input 7 x (5 + 4) = <<7x(5+4)=35>>35<n><n><n>#### Input: 4.5 + 6 = <<16+2/2=32>>32<n>32 - 11 = <<32-11=21>>21<n><n>#### Input : (4) + 3 = <<2+2=4>>4<n><n>#### Input: A and (1 + 2) = <<1+2=3>>3<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Mark wanted to know the truth, because he didn't want to continue existing in what? Choices:  A: understand B: were there C: ignorance D: in-between E: ignorant<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Ignorance<n>Answer: ignorance<n><n>### Instructions:Select an appropriate answer.<n><n>### Choice: A)<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>#### A(4) B(12) C(6) D(20) E(8) F(15)<n><n>### Choices: A B C D E F<n><n>### Demstration:<n>1 = <<1>>1<n>2^2 = <<1>>2^2 <n><n>3 * 3 * 3*4 = 1*4<n>8 * 8 = 1*4 = 8<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: 8<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: ungulate B: bomber C: body armor D: tank E: hat<n><n>### Response:		This is a very complex question with a lot of details about the types of clothing you should wear. B, E, and D are all incorrect because they do not protect you from a cannonball. A, C, and E are all incorrect because a bomb will fall, not fly and impact you. E is also incorrect because the bomb will explode rather than protect you from impact. D is incorrect because your tank will explode.<n><n>### This exercise is based on the material from Chapter 6 "Solving Equations"<n><n>### Input:"17 - 3 ÷ 2x"<n><n>### Response:"14"<n><n>```eval<n>### 17 - 3 / 2x = 14<n>### 15 - 3 / 3 = 14<n>15-8/4 = 1 and 14.<n>```<n><n>### This instruction was written as a multiple-choice question with the following question,<n><n>Input: 24.7 x 3.55 x 6.72 x 7.83 = _______________________<n><n>### Response"142"<n><n>```eval```<n><n>24.7 x3.55 x6.72 x7.83 = 2737.57<n><n>### This is a similar multiple choice problem like we did earlier except this time we are asked to<n>answer the given product<n><n>### Input"5.2 x ________ (square root of 7)"<n><n>### Response '4.222'<n><n>```eval<n>5.2 x sqrt(7) = <<5.2*sqrt(7)=4.075>>4.075<n>```<n><n>The square root of 7is <<1.5+sqrt(1.5)=1.387>>1.387<n><n>### These are some more questions from Chapter 13 "Adding and Subtracting Radicals"<n><n>### The first question:<n><n>Input: The square root of 2 + 4 × 2 = ______<n><n>### Response 5.492<n><n>```eval<n>2/2+4/2 = <<2/2*4/2=4>><n><n>5.492=<<

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:My house is very dry, with little water in the air. What tool should I use to fix this? Choices:  A: humidifier B: surface of earth C: skating rink D: ice cube E: burn it to the ground<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is A: humidifier<n><n>### Input - Demo:<n>Input: Choose the correct sentence for the sentence.<n><n>### Which of the following sentences completes the sentence?<n>(1) The sun shines through the window.<n>(2) The window shines through the sun.<n><n>### Correct sentence<n>My window is sunny on a rainy day because the sun shines through my window.   #4<n><n>### Demo:<n>My window is suny on a rainy day beacause the sun shines throug my window.<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: bathroom B: house C: cupboard D: space shuttle E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		The choices are A, C, B and E<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Smell: A smell in the air from the kitchen is usually from the kitchen.<n>If there a stale smell coming from a bathroom smells usually come from the surface of earth..<n>A surface of earth smell in the kitchen would be a bad smell.<n>E earth smells usually don't come from the surface of the earth.<n>The surface of earth smells usually come from space which doesn't smell.<n>C or A: Cupboards, and bathroom do not contain a smell from the kitchen unless the surface of the earth is on the cupboard or the bathtub.<n>Both B and D: Bathroom does not usually smell bad but a space shuttle could smell because the kitchen could have a surface of the earth. House doesn't usually smell because the house and kitchen are two entirely different areas.<n>#### E<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Instrucation:<n>Write a response that appropriately complete the request.<n><n>Input: 100 is more than 75. 90>45. Which answer choice completes the statement below? 90  < 50<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The statement given is in less than or greater than symbol.<n>In order to add 90 to 45 you have to multiply the second number by 1.9 = <<1.9=18>>18 and then reduce the whole number.<n>So, 90 - 45 = <<90-45=45>>45 is not less than 50<n>90 > 50<n>```<n>  90 > 45 = << 90>44>><n><n>```<n><n>#### 90 > 44<n>Answer: D<n>
