Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:A soccer field that is not contained in a building would be where? Choices:  A: playground B: mexico C: town D: outside E: world cup<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>-A mexico and world cup and building don't make sense.<n>-playground doesn't mention being inside of anything<n><n>A soccer field is NOT an inside of anything!<n><n>

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Happiness<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### A: In a study of children's television programming, two-thirds of the children watch cartoons. How many children do not watch cartoons?<n>Rationales<n>180/2 = << 180/2=90>>90 children watch Cartoons<n>90/3 = <<90/3=30>> children do not watch cartooone<n>Therefore, 90 - 30 = <<90-30=60>>60 children do not watch Cartoons<n>#### 60<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Rules<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question or solves the problem.<n><n>An answer may be complete or partial, but the response should be based on the given rules.<n>The response may be a number answer; it may be a true/false statement; it may be a sentence; or it may be a set of operations.<n>When writing the rule, the student should demonstrate their understanding of the rule by explaining why the rules work.<n><n>### Examples<n><n>Example 2:<n>#### 11548 – B is the only vowel. D is in the last place<n><n>#### 10721 – C is equal to 2 + 3 + 4<n><n>**This rule does not work. Why?**<n><n>**Fair warning: I’ll likely be posting more rules than this. It’s worth checking back over the course of the month. I just felt like the next few problems were simpler.**<n><n>```<n>B. The only vowel.<n>```<n><n>#### 123 – D is in the last spot and F is in the middle spot.<n><n>#### 11442 – G is in the second place.<n><n>#### 8797 – E is in the first place.<n><n>#### F<n><n>```<n>D 139 (139 * 18)<n>```<n><n>#### G<n><n>```<n>The only vowel that is less than 10,000.<n>```<n><n>## The Monthly Challenge: Week 5<n><n>### Instrument: Clicker<n><n>#### Week 2 Rules<n><n>#### Week 3

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n><n>### Response:		Choice: A<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input :In what month was the year 1980?<n><n>### Demostration : You subtract two numbers in the calendar to get the year's place in a month.<n><n>#### May<n>Answer: 1980<n><n>### Input  :A car was speeding at 77 feet per second. When it slowed down to 60 feet per second, how many car lengths were it ahead of the car that was following it? Choices A: B: C: D:  E:<n><n>### Demotion: You use the distance between cars to find the length of the cars' spaces.<n><n>**C**<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:-What day of the year in which will it occur on 2012, the year 1990 or 2006?<n><n>### Rationales:-Year 1990 = 1990 - <<1990-19,2 =1956>>1956<n><n>Year 2006 = 2006 - <<2006-19 =97>>07<n><n>Year 2212 = 2212 - <<2212-19 =2193>>2193<n><n>Year 2136 = 2136 - <<2136-19=2117>>2117<n><n>year 1990 is greater than year 2117.<n><n>Year 1956 is greater than year 1991.<n><n>Year 2*14 = <<07=14>>14<n><n>Year 14 is less than Year 2006<n><n>year 14 is less then Year 2212<n><n>year 12 is Lesser then Year 2136, therefore, 2006 <= year 1998-12 =>2006 <= Year 1990-Year 12 =>Year 1999 < Year 1996-12 => year 1999 = year 1987 => 1996 =

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:They moved out of the city to have a master bedroom, what kind of home did they seek? Choices:  A: large house B: suburban home C: big house D: old house E: keeping personal objects<n><n>### Response:		They moved out of The City to have a large house. E<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions:Select the response that best completes the request. Note: each response can have no more than 100 characters.  A. 1 kg is roughly equivalent to  16 oz. B. 15 oz. is equal to  3/4 lb. C. 14 cups is nearly equal to  40 oz. D. 9 oz. is almost the equivalent to 11 lb.<n><n>### Response<n>C. 14 cu_s is almost the equivalent to (3/4) lb.<n><n>A. 1 kg is equivalent to 32 oz.<n><n>B. 15 o_z is almost the equivalent to  3 lb.<n><n>D. 11 lb is almost equivalent to  8 cu_s.<n><n>###  Answer<n>Answers:<n><n>###  Instruction:Four children share a large birthday cake. Alice gets 3/4 of the cake and Bill gets 1/5 of the cake. How many pieces of cake have Fred and Linda as well as the cake?<n><n>###  Rationales:Alice + Bill =<<Alice+Bill>>Fred + Linda =<<Fred+Linda>>Fred, 0.75Linda, 0.19<n><n>Fred = <<Fred>>1 - Alice<n><n>Linda = <<Linda>>2 - Alice.75<n><n>So: Alice.75 + Bill.19 = Fred - Alice<n><n>L = Fred.75+Alice-Alice.75<n><n>Alice.75*(1.2+0.3+0.3) = Fred.1675+Linda.38 - Alice.8533<n><n>0.4 = Fred+Linda+0.493<n><n>Fred.1633 - Linda.38 = Linda.10<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Fred.1533 - Bill.19 = Fred.1414<n><n>Alice.0.75 + Bill.0.19 = Fred.749<n><n>Fred.7
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:When people discover something new while chatting with friends, why are they likely to continue talking? Choices:  A: agreement B: to fill their time C: discomfort D: misunderstanding E: learning about<n><n>### Response:		The answer is B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		<n>It hasn't become extra strong and so its weak.<n><n>### The Strength:<n><n>A)Weak :The glass with its untreated surface is weak since it becomes brittle.<n><n>B) Fragile:The untreated glass that tends to be brittle is fragile.<n><n>C) Forceless:The glass that is weak and brittle can easily be breakable.<n><n>D) Regular :The glass that has not been treated in any case, it is regular glass.

(6 >2)<n><n><n>### 2<n><n>### C = 2<n><n>## #1<n>I can eat up to 3 apples if I eat 2 a day.<n><n>I can eat only one apple if I eat none because the sentence says at least.<n><n>I can never eat two apples a day is false.<n><n>I can only eat one apple a day if I never eat any fruits the rest of the day is false.<n>## C  = 2<n><n>B = 2 or any other number that does not add up to the desired result.<n><n>### C A = 2<n>A is too great.<n><n>###

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:He was a very sharp engineer, but when it came to the details his calculations could were often what? Choices:  A: complimentary B: inelegant C: ocean D: dull E: inaccurate<n><n>### Response:		E-Dull<n>#### A,B,C,D<n>Input:Which has the closer dimensions, one inch tall or one inch long? Choices: A: The inch. B: The long inch. C: The tall inch. D: The short inch.<n><n>Input: 260.<n>Rationales: Since 260 < <<200=200>>200, 260 is the smaller number.<n>#### 150<n>Answer:150<n>Input: The value of x-7 = <<X-7=1>>1.<n><n>Input: What is the value of x-7 -4? Choices: A. 1 B. 5 C. 35 D: 223 E: -4<n><n>Input:The value of x-7 +3 =<<X-7+3=2>>2.<n><n>**Saved!!**<n>

Shirt price = the number of items<n><n>### Response :(B) Shirt price = 3 * the number of items.<n><n>### Input : (C) In a supermarket, items of different sizes and brands are in the same categories. After 30 days, it is multiplied by 2 and then added to the number of days in the month of December. The result of the addition is divided by 12 months and the quotient is rounded down to the nearest whole number. A new number is created based on the formula and the new number is subtracted from the initial number. If the difference is greater than 19 years, the result is 23 years, otherwise, the answer is a number of years based on the formula. If the initial number is 180 days, what is the resulting number of years?<n>### answer: 23<n>In this example, n represents the initial number of days. <n>The result is 180 * 2 + 10 = 362<n>362/12 = <<362/18>>21.4375<n>The difference between 21.438 > 19 <n>23 = 21.4 round down<n><n>### Input<n>An equation represents a number. If the number is multiplied by 3 and then multiplied by 7, the result is added to the number. Then, the result is subtracted from 5 times the sum of the digits of the original number. The resulting number represents a multiple of 23. What is the value of the equation's number?<n>### answer : 192<n>In this example, p represents the number to be substituted.<n>4 * P * 7 = P*21<n>P addition = 5 * (4+4+4+4 + 4)= 20<n>20 - P* (4 + 4 + 4 +4 + 4 ) = P(20 - 22)= -16<n><n> -16*7 = -112<n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following question.<n><n>## Instructions: Answer one or more of the questions below.<n><n>### Answer:<n>10/24<n><n>### Answer (3):<n><n>### Answer(4)<n><n>### Answer<n>Answer: 13.8%<n><n>### Answer4<n>Answer: 7:13<n>515 = 6

Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>Input: In 8086, the segment address is the 16-bit segment field of the 4-byte far pointer. The far pointer, in turn, contains the segment address and the offset address of the function. The stack address is the base address of the call stack. So, when there is a push, the program can store the value of the function's parameter in the stack.<n><n>### Response Rationale:In 8086:segment address-is the 16-b segment field of the 32-b far pointer. The far-pointer, in turn, contains segment address and the far stack address.<n>When there is a push, value of the function parameter can be stored in the stack.<n>#### 2000000<n>Answer: 2000-000 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n><n>### Response:		<n>The camper looked up into the night sky and saw the countless stars that appeared to be a mile high. This magnificent display of beauty made him feel insignificant in the grand scheme of the universe.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>Write a response that appropriately answers this instruction.<n><n>### Response 2:<n>The best response is Choice B (B): insignificant.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>For Choices B: insignificanf_t > Choice A: unimportant, you could compare the magnitude of the stars to the magnitude of the human. Since the stars appear to be a mile high and the human is one centimeter tall, the human will look insignificant in comparison. When you consider the fact that there should not be as many stars as there are, the magnitude of the stars becomes obvious. The same thinking can be applied to the magnitude of the night sky which would render the camper insignificant. Choice B is the most apt response.<n><n>#### Incorrect: <n>For Choice C: stellar, the human should definitely not hold the same magnitude as some of the stars.<n><n>#### Choice E: helpless, does not make sense as the human has the ability to affect the course of the night in many ways, including when he decides to sleep in, or when he has a chance to go see a movie. There are so many factors that affect his destiny and that of the stars.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:To properly instruct children attending school you would need a great deal of what? Choices:  A: boredom B: patience C: time D: teachers E: inspiration<n><n>### Response:		<n>[<<E: Inspiration>>]<n><n>### Justification:<n>The only thing I found missing from the question is the word what, which I added at the end in square brackets.<n><n>### Input The student is correct in her assumption that the question is asking for the correct answer.<n><n>### Response<n><n>[<<E:Inspiration>>]<n>Gold<n><n>### Justifications:<n>The only thing present in her answer that is missing from in the question is the use of square brackets.<n><n>* [<<G: Inspiration>> is correct if Gold is correct.]<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>[<<E>>\G]<n>```<n>Gold is correct.<n>```<n>### Input<n><n>* <<I:I am so bored>><n><n>### Demos:<n>```<n>I am so bored because of the class<n>```<n><n>* [<<E: I am so bored if  I am so bored is correct.>>]<n><n>## Input:<n><n>|  The pizza pie is a slice of the pie.|<n><n>## Justification:<n><n>The correct answer is Pie. I believe so because I found that in the first line the question asked us, and the line asked what is "the pizza pie" which makes sense (I believe the question is referring the whole pie and not just the slice) which means that a slice is not a "pie".<n><n>## Input: <n><n>| The pizza pie is the whole pie.     |<n><n>## Justification :<n><n>The correct answer should be Pie. I believe so due to the fact that the pizza pie is not "a" pie as the question asked but rather "the" pie which makes sense due to the fact that we would not refer to a slice as pie and the question asked us for a whole pie.<n><n>## Input: The whole pie is not a slice of the pie<n>##|<n>The pizza pie is a piece of pie<n>This means that the pizza pie equals one-piece. Therefore, you cannot add another piece if you only have the pizza pie.<n><n>## Justifications: <n>The question implies that the pizza pie (piece of pie) is not a slice. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Behind what small door are canned goods usually kept in? Choices:  A: cabinet B: pantry C: kitchen D: cupboard E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:Choice A = <<11>>1<n>Choice B = <<2>>2<n>Choice C = <<4>>4<n>Choice D = <<8>>8<n>Choice E = <<375>>375<n>1 - 2 = <<1-2=(-1)>>-(1)   // 1 + 4 = <<1+4=5>>5<n>1 + 375 = <<1*375=375>>3<n>---<n>4 - 8 = <<4-8=(-4)>>-(4)   // 4 + (-4) × 1 = <<4-(-4)=0>>0<n>4 + 375/1 = <<4+375/1=375>>4<n>A > B, C > D, B > E, E > C, D > A, A is the closest.<n>---

Choices:  A: coal or wood B: fire C: lava D: house E: solar energy<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are four possible chemical reactions:<n>* combustion<n>* oxidation<n>* corrosion<n>* decomposition<n><n>None of the above is a chemical reaction that provides energy. There are no living organisms with the name of any of the other answers.<n>#### CORRECT<n>Solar heat is the result of a chemical reaction: the combination of hydrogen and oxygen in the sun to make water.<n><n>The energy released from the chemical process does not burn, corrode, or decompose: each of these destructive reactions is the result of a chain reaction.<n><n>### Input : <n>Janet has 9 cards less than Brenda. Choices:  A: pay debts B: make money C: having money D: making money E: keep house<n><n>### Response:		<n>> B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>- Each question is asked in a statement form.<n>- Mark the answer that best completes each statement below with A or B.<n>- There are no wrong answers.<n><n>### Answer:<n>> B<n>#### 2<n>Answer:  B<n><n>Input: The two-headed snake was afraid of the dog. The snake didn't like being chased. Because the snake was afraid of being chased, she went toward the river. The dog chased her and the snake ran into the water. Why does the snake go into the water? Choices: A: She was frightened of the river. B: The dog chased her into the river.<n><n>Response:<n>> B<n>---<n><n>Input: The snake didn's go into the water because he was chased by the dog.<n><n>Answer:  B
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:I am looking to buy honey right from an apiary, where should I go? Choices:  A: jar B: stick to fingers C: beehive D: stick to fingers E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Rationales: Jar is not one of the choices, beehive is the only choice but farmers market offers honey not beehives.<n><n>### Input:"What is the difference between 6 and 18, and then 18 and 27?"<n><n>### Response:"18 minus 6 is 12."<n><n>### Rationale: 6-18=<<6-18=12>>12<n><n>### Input;What is the largest 2-digit prime?<n><n>### Response;"49"<n><n>### Ratihines: 42 is a 4 digit even number but it is not prime so the number is greater than 39. Thus, 49 is the largest 2 digit prime and the only 2 digit prime.<n><n>### Questions:Choose the correct option from the following for the following task.<n><n>#### 💫💫A. ______ 💫B. ______ <n><n>Answer: 💫A<n><n>### Expansion:A. 💫<n><n>### Expansoin:B.<n><n>### Rationle:A. This is the best option from these choices.<n><n>#### ⭕A. ⭕<n><n>### Expasion:⭕<n><n>#### 𝐛𝐞𝐜𝐤𝐩𝐞🤦🏾‍♂️ �������������������������������������������������������������������������������� ➕𠂝🤦<n><n>### Expation:A. ______<n><n>### Rations:The picture shows a ______.<n><n>### RATIONALES:The best option from these choices is iguana or crocodile as they both start from I.<n><n>#### 8😒<n>Input: I need ___

Choices:  A: copy B: intelligent C: improved performance D: empowering E: have more knowledge<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: copy<n><n>### Input:[a < b] and [b < k]<n>Rationales: Because < is a symbol not a cardinal and so if a < b then it is true that it is smaller and if b < k then it is true that k is larger than b.<n>If a < b then a is strictly below b and if b < k than again b is strictly below k.<n>a < b AND b < k means that both of them are under each other meaning that the first one b is bigger as it is underneath a.<n>Thus a < b AND b < [k] and this is logically equivalent to saying a <[k]<n>#### A < [k]<n>Answer: A < K<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What do rich people like in terms of bagels? Choices:  A: poor B: sleepy C: plain D: needy E: homeless<n><n>### Response:		Pick B: sleepy<n>### Rationale:Bagel is a round shape and rich people like something round.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What might a person receive from their boss if they do a poor job? Choices:  A: misfortune B: fearful C: criticism D: make mistakes E: promotion appraisal<n><n>### Response:		<n>A)Misfortune<n><n>#### Prompt:<n>1. If you do a poor job, the result might be...<n>A. criticism.<n>    This is incorrect.<n>B. misfortune.<n>    This is the best answer.<n>C. fearful.<n>    This is not a correct response.<n>D. make mistakes.<n>    This is a incorrect answer.<n>E. promotion appraisal.<n>    This response is incorrect.<n><n>### Question:<n>1. What is promotion appraisal?<n>Promotion appraisal is an evaluation carried out to decide whether someone is fit for promotion or not.<n>The process is commonly used as an important tool in corporate organizations.<n>2. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The turkey needed to be kept from spoiling, what is useful in this situation? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: fridge C: freezer D: oven E: bought at store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choice<n>**b**: fridge<n><n>#### <n>Answer:<n><n>####<n>### Input:You need 3000 cents to buy what? Choices:  Cake D: Pizza E: Burger F: Drink G: Milk<n><n>### Response -<n><n>**f**: Drink<n><n>####<n>##<n>### Input:A train is being built on the train station platform. The track can support the weight of any number of cars and is strong enough to hold the weight of any number up to 12. The number of ties must be 1 more than twice the number of wheels on any car. The track can safely support 20,000 tons. How many wheels can be on a car?<n>#### #<n>Answer: 22

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The person knew the police were after him, so what did he do? There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Complete them.<n>How many of the following are even numbers in 12? Choices: A: 6 of the 12 numbers B: 7 Of the 12 numbers C: 8 of the 12 Numbers D: all of the 12 of 12 numbers E: 9 of the 12 <n><n>12-12 =  -1 <n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```bash<n>Output- $ echo "12 - 12 =  - 1"<n><n>12- 12 = -2<n>```<n><n><n>### Reference: <n>[https://www.mathisfun.com/gcse/numbers/even-numbers.html](https://www.mathsisfun.com/numbers/even-number.html ) [https://www.mathematicsisfun.com/fraction-multiplication-example.html](https://mathematicsisfunandfree.com/multiplying-fractions-with-different-denominators/ )

Choices:  A: finger B: good health C: own family D: friends E: people<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input:"You may get a lot of exercise by walking to school, but you can also get exercise by cycling to school." How can riding a bike to school help you reach the required exercise for daily life?<n><n>### Response:"Riding a bike to go to school helps in a number of ways as it promotes health and fitness. Also, it is also a cost-effective mode of transportation. These days parents are often too busy to drop and pick up kids and so they are inclined to offer rides or drop by themselves and drive your kid to school. This is where the importance of riding a bike comes in. In such cases, you feel your life is easier as you can park and lock up your bike and proceed to work. You may also do yoga and exercise in a park on the way to work. With your bike ready when you return from work, you do not waste time hunting for a parking space or waiting for your transport."<n><n>### Input"A person with brown skin, brown eyes, and brown hair may not have the same skin tone, hair color, or eye color as someone with brown skin, blue eyes, and brown hair. What is true for them both?<n><n>### Rationales"People with brown skin, brown hair, and brown eyes both tend to inherit their skin tone, haair color, and eye color from the same ancestral lineage. The skin tone usually represents the tone of melanin in the skin, while hair color is the shade of melanin in hair, and eyes color is the shade in the eyeball. Hence, both brown-haired and brown-eyed-brown-eyed people will always have a brown skin tone."<n>  <n>### Rationale"Though the color of the skin, hair, and eyes vary from person to person, what these people have in common is their ancestry. Both brown-haired and eyed-people are brown-skinned. Therefore, it is fair to say that a person with brown skin, blue eye color, and brown hair may possess the identical gene that may manifest in different combinations. In short, even though the inheritance of skin tone, eye color, and hair color vary within the genetic pool of the family, they all share a common genetic inheritance which is the same as brown haired and brown eyed
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Someone who is awake is likely to know what's going on because they are this? Choices:  A: alert B: deep sleep C: drink coffee D: open eyes E: conscious<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationale:You cannot drink coffee while being conscious and not fully awake in the morning.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>#### A<n><n>#### B<n><n>#### C<n><n>#### D<n><n>#### E<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:A water spout was seen in the ocean off the coast of what? There were 48 fewer pies than there were guests at the party, and there were 420 more people than the number of cakes and pies. How many people were at the party?<n>Rationales<n>There were 880/2 = <<880/2=440>>440 people at the party<n>There were 495 - 88 = <<495-88=407>>407 people at the party<n>#### 407<n>Answer: 407<n><n>Input: If there are 7 pairs of twins in a room, and each pair plays some type of instrument, how many different combinations are there of two instruments if only one pair plays two instruments?<n>Rationales:- If each pair has a single instrument, there are 7 different combinations.<n>:- If each pair has 2 instruments, there are 6 different combinations.<n>:-If the pair with 2 instruments plays different instruments from the pairs with single instruments, there are 7 pairs with 1 or 2 different instruments, for a total of 14 different combinations.<n>:-So, a total of 7 + 6 + 14 combinations for 2 instruments.<n>#### 23<n>Answer: 23<n><n>Input: If 5 apples are left, how many more are needed to have 25 apples in all?<n>Rationals: Five apples were left.<n>Now, 5 more than 5 = <<5+5=10>>5 more apples are needed.<n>5 + 10 = <<5+10=15>>15 apples<n>#### 15<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: If a number is divided by 1/2 of itself, what number did you get?<n><n>Rationales:- You could not get half.<n>:- That is why you could not get 3/2.<n>:-You could not also get 5/2.<n><n>#### No Answer<n><n>Input: Choose a number; then multiply it by 3, divide it by 5, and add a number. Choices:  A: supermarket B: home C: closet D: mart E: hardware store<n><n>### Response:		Mart<n><n>### Rationales:Closet, home, and hardware store are places used to store things.  A shopping bag would not be used there.  A shopping area contains many shopping bags.  Therefore, a shopping bag would be found in a Mart.<n><n>### Input<n>A: 15.2 miles B: 854 hours C: 6.6 pounds D: 834.2 gallons E: 14.7 grams<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Rationale:The only two numbers that begin with 6. are 6 and 60.<n><n>## Input:<n><n>You work in a factory, 16 hours each day, from Monday through Saturday. If you take Sundays off, how many minutes each day do you have free? Choices: A) 5 minutes B) 90 minutes C) 430 minutes D) 10 minutes E) 560 minutes<n><n>### Risk:<n>#### Answers marked incorrectly:<n><n>If you take sunday (or saturday) off, you will get an additional 24 hours (or 12 hours). We then take those 24 (or 12) and divide it by 360 (24 x 12 / 360 = 12) minutes. This tells us that you get 6 minutes of free time (or 108 minutes) each day.<n><n>While this method is correct, my concern is the logic behind it. Most students take the logical route (such as 5 X 7 = 35, meaning they miss the free time in the morning, and the time in the afternoon). This will cause questions like these to trip up students.<n><n>#### Rationales:<n><n>1) 5 x 7 = 38.6 minutes.<n>2) 10 x 2 = 20 minutes.<n>3) 12 x 3 = 36 minutes.<n>4) 15 x 4 = 60 minutes.<n>5) 18 x 5 = 90.<n>6) 20 x 6 = 120.<n>7) 24 x 7 = 168.<n>8) 27 x 8 = 2

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:How does a flea locomote? Choices:  A: attack B: suck blood C: stay D: lay eggs E: jump<n><n>### Response:		<n>[A: attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fleming's_solenoid)<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Input :If you add the numbers 6, 5, 4, 5, and 3 together, you will get a number less than __. Write your answer in the box below as a positive integer.__<n><n>### Demo<n>[5:5-4-5+3=1](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D5ZLmP82ZJw)<n><n>### Rationales:<n>[5:5+3-4-5](https://www.texasgateway.com/app/uploads/2019/03/Math-H.pdf)<n><n>### Demostrations:<n>[5:](https://www.pinterest.com/explore/math-multiplication-facts/)<n><n>### Demosc:Write a new number that is smaller than 10 that is still greater than 1.<n><n>\* Input: A dog had 30 dogs. After the dog died, 35 dogs remained. How many dogs remained?<n>\* Rationales: The number that is equal to the number 30 + 35 is 65.<n>\* Demosc: 65<n>\* Demo: [65](https://www5.cpsinfo.org/cms/resources/8255-5954488-68463636937-550051092083839-233668-39015741)<n>\* Answer: 65<n><n>\* Input :How many gallons of water did 4 students drink last week?<n>\* Rationale :4 students is equal to 0.25 gallons, because 0.25 is not equal to 1 gallon.<n>\* Demoso: [4.0](https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=0+point+25+gallon+is+equal+to+4+gallon)<n>\* Demo: 4 gallons is equal to 4 gallon<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Sam was against Allison's decision.  Joe was the opposite.  What was Joe, regarding that decision? Choices:  A: being for B: away from C: combined D: for or E: conjunction<n><n>### Response:		<n>* A [Being For](http://math.stackexchange.com/questions/2082403/which-choice-best-represents-the-preposition-in-this-sentence-my-friend-is-fo?answertab=votes#tab-top)<n>* D [For or] [Against](http://math.stackexchange.com/questions/1005247/what-is-the-opposite-of-a-coin?noredirect=1&lq=1)<n><n>**A, D, B and E do not make sense.**<n><n><n>### 0<n>* B [Opposite](http://math.stackoverflow.com/questions/646502/expressing-the-opposites-of-a-sentence?rq=1)<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Which effect of stress could cause death if not treated immediately? Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input:(Select all that apply) Which combination of letters represents the letter E?<n><n>### Demostration:If A=1, B=5, C=9, D=2. Which of these is equivalent to (E)?<n><n>### Response:(Select all that apply):<n>E=4,7,8,9<n><n>### Input : What do the number line and the number strip represent?<n><n>### Demos:<n>Number strip shows how many units to move on the number line. It can be also called a tape diagram.<n><n>### Response :<n>Number line represents 1 unit to infinity.<n><n>### Input 1: What is an advantage of using the number line when solving math equations?<n><n>### Response 1:<n>If you draw the right sequence of movement on the line, you will always reach the solution.<n><n>### 204711452514291711220231521009429179<n>### Input #2: What is an advantage using tape diagrams to help solve equations?<n><n>## #2 response :<n> You will have a clear view of the movement when solving the equation.<n><n>### A 7 x 10 number of 270,000<n>### Input #3: What is a disadvantage of using the number line to solve math equations?<n><n>No room.<n><n>### -1 7 x 11 721<n><n>### Input #4: What is the main disadvantage of using tape diagrams?<n><n>### main disadvantage of Using tape diagram:<n> Not enough room to write numbers.<n><n>#### 270,721<n>Answer: <n>#### 7072<n>Answer: <n>### Input 5 : If you had two piles of marbles with 10 marbles in the first pile and 60 marbles in the second pile, and you moved 10 marbles from the first pile to the second pile, how many marbles are in the first pile?<n><n>### input 5 response :<n> the answer is 90 marbles because they both have 60 left.<n><n>

Choices:  A: farmland B: neighborhood C: city D: property E: subdivision<n><n>### Response:		B(Neighborhorhood)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the 4-choice questions.<n><n>### Question 1:<n><n>### Instr:<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Resp:<n><n>### Question2:<n><n>### Response :<n><n>### Instruption:Answer the multi choice questions.<n><n>## Input:A bird hatches an egg every 30 minutes if you feed the hen the right foods to make the egg hatch. If the hen is hungry and does not get enough food, it may take a longer time for the egg to hatch. If the bird sits on an egg, it can hatch only one egg in an hour of sitting.<n><n>## Rationales: If we add 30 minutes to the sitting time, the overall time increases to 30 minutes + 1 hour = <<30+1=40>>4o minutes.<n>If the hen is hungry but gets enough food, then the time to hatch increases to 30 +40 = <<30+40=70>>70 minutes.<n>If the bird sits on the egg, there needs to be two more eggs (because it takes about an hour to hatch one egg. 1*2=<<1×2=2>>2 eggs per hour of sitting<n>If the hen is not hungry because it is fed the right foods, then there is no change in the total time to hatch.<n>So the final time to hatch depends on the overall situation regarding the hungry and fed hen and the two eggs per hour of sitting times. So, overall, there are three situations that lead to four different times to hatch, which are: <n><n>(1) 110 minutes (when the hen is hungry; it takes 30 minutes to hatch one egg, and it needs 40 minutes to hatch the eggs once it sits on them)<n><n>(2) 100 minutes (when the hungry hen is fed with the right food to keep its body well fed; it takes 35 minutes to hatch one of the eggs, and the hen needs 25 more minutes to hatch the other egg)<n><n>(3) 90 minutes (when an adequately fed hen sits on 2 eggs that take 1 hour

The rest were unknown. The students were arranged in ten rows. In each row, there was a girl's name and a boy's name. There were a total of 160 names, with all of the names used. When each row had the same number of names as there were students in the row, it was considered a perfect roster. How many names were in each row?<n><n>#### Input:<n>In a class, there are 25 boys and the rest are unknown. They are arranged in ten rows. The first row has 4 names. The second row had 7 names. There are a total of 14 names. The third row had 6 names. The fourth row had 8 names. There are a maximum of 21 names. The fifth row had 4 names. The sixth row had 8 names and a total of 22 names. The seventh row had 6 names and the eighth row had 5 names and the rest were unknown.<n><n>A perfect roster is arranged so that in each row, there is one row that had 25 names in addition to 25 unknowns. What is the total number of names in the rows?<n><n>#### Response:<n>There are a total of 45 names (25 unknowns and 20 names). We must determine how many times each name appears in order to find the total number of names.<n><n>How many times does each first name appear in the class roster? Which student is Bob?<n><n>Bob’s name appears twice. Other first names appear with a total of 15 occurrences (in addition to any second or third names).<n><n>How many times each second name appears? Which student is Alice?<n><n>Alice’s name appears once. Other second names appear with a total number of 14 occurrences.<n><n>How many names appear with a third name, in addition to any name appearing twice and once? Which student is Mike?<n><n>Mike’s name appears once and the total number of third names equals 19.<n><n>For a student to be in a perfect class roster, the first name must appear at least twice. Which student is Fred?<n><n>Fred’s name appears

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is a living thing with a lip? The rest of the gallon is poured into 3 pitchers. How much of the milk was poured into the pitchers?<n>#### Explanation:<n>The milk poured into pitcher = (rest of the gallon) - (8 cups) = <<The milk poured into the  =->> 4 cups, therefore, 1,25 Gallon Milk is remaining.<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>#### Exercises 2:<n><n><n>Input: A farmer owned 57 chickens. Then he bought and sold a few. So he had 13 fewer chickens than he had when he started. How many chickens did he start with?<n>#### Explanations:<n>The answer is B = 23 chickens, since he sold 13 chickens, he has 23 - 13 = 10 chickens.<n><n>#### 23<n>Answer: 23<n><n>Input: Six girls rode bikes to a shopping mall to eat ice cream. They rode 12 miles. On the way home, they rode 5 miles farther. How many more miles did they ride on the way home than on the way to the mall?<n>#### Explanatio:<n><n>The answer is C=8 miles, because there answer is 12 miles + 5 more miles than 12 miles = 17 miles..Therefore, 8 more miles.<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: 8<n><n>Input: A salesman bought 3 tickets to a show. Each new ticket cost $1 more than the last ticket he bought. The total number of tickets he bought was 17. What was each ticket cost?<n>#### Explanatios:<n>The answer is $8, because last ticket cost $$1-6= 5$$ dollars and then each ticket he bought, it costs 5 dollars + $1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If they were celebrating the occasion, how could the occasion be described? Choices:  A: drinking B: intimacy C: dancing D: happiness E: enjoyment<n><n>### Response:		I'll choose B<n><n>**Bis dahulunya saya melakukan T-test untuk melihat apakah pilihan siswa keluar dari sisi B. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some large pieces of paper that are not for sale? Choices:  A: cabinet B: computer printer C: suitcase D: office supply store E: artist's studio<n><n>### Response:		The correct response to this question is choice D.<n><n>### Input, Demonstration, Answer:<n><n>Input: Where could you find some large sheets of paper that are not available for purchase but may be printed on using a printer? Choice A: Cabinet B: Computer printer C: suite box D: office supply shop E: artist's Studio<n><n>#### E: Artist's Studio<n><n>The word print has more than one meaning.<n>First, print means to make an object permanent, such as a sculpture.<n>The second meaning is to make a paper on a printer.<n>A printer is an item that produces printed paper copies.<n>Therefore, the solution to the question is the artist's studio.<n><n>#### Answer: D: Office Supply Store<n><n>### Inputs:The bartender made a 3 liter bottle of wine equal to the amount in 2 1/2 liter bottles. When he started the recipe, there was 1 1/4 liter left in the bottle. How much did the bartender pour?<n><n>### Response 1:The bartender poured 1 1/2 liters of wine<n><n>### Response2:The bartender did not pour any wine<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>I answered the first question as the correct answer to the question because the bartender poured wine to make the total bottle of 3 liters the equal amount as 2 1/4 liters. 3 liters = 2.752 1/2 litres. Since, there were 1 1/15 litres more in the original bottle of wine, the bartender added this to the 2 1/5 liters bottled wine. And also, since the ratio did not change, I came to conclusion that, by adding the ratio-wise, the bartender increased the total bottle to 3 liters.<n><n>Answer 2: Bartender did not pour wine. The bartender poured the original 2.75 liters of wine from a 1/4 litre bottle<n><n>I found this by doing cross-differential.<n>The question given was the bartender pouried some wine, the amount of bottled wine was 2 1/3, the original bottle was 2
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Why would professionals playing sports not be able to compete? Choices:  A: pain B: mudslide C: sweating D: injuries E: rain<n><n>### Response:		Pain: Choice A<n>Mudslide: Choice C<n>Sweating: Choice D<n>Injuries: Choice B<n>Rain: Choice E<n><n>### Inputs:Mona has more candy than Ben. If no expression is correct, choose none of the above.<n>Explain each expression by writing a complete sentence.<n><n>### InputExplain why the following expression is true: 8/4 + 8/7 = 9/3<n><n>### RationaleThe denominators are evenly divided between two expressions (two groups) of the same denominator.<n><n>### Response8/4 + 7/8 = 9/38/4 + 4/7 = 99/77/6 + 6/8 = 99/39/12 + 9/3 = 69/369/24 + 12/3 = 6<n><n>#### Instructions:<n>1. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:James's bouncing rubber balls were at rest, and so he could sleep.  He would get up in the morning, and then put them in what state again? Choices:  A: upside down B: in motion C: active D: wakefulness E: resthold<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>#### 1<n>1. If we take all of the rubber balls and lay them on a horizontal surface, they will all be lying on their “bottum”. If James picks up these balls, the rubber balls remain in the same state in which he can sleep.<n>#### 2.<n>James would also pick the rubber balls which are laid horizontally on the ground. The rubber balls stay put when he picks them up. There is no motion in this system. So the correct answer is "B".<n><n>#### 3.<n>If the rubber balls are lying on a horizontal surface (one resting on top of the other), James picks them all up. The rubber balls do not move when he takes them up. They would still be in the same state.<n><n>#### 4.<n>James picks up the rubber balls lying on the horizontal surface. The rubber balls all move when he picks them.<n><n>#### 5.<n>James starts with his rubber balls lying on a horizontal surface. A horizontal surface is the one resting on top of another horizontal surface. James picks up the rubbed balls lying on the horizontal surfaces, and all of them move around at the same time, so the rubber balls are in motion. He is therefore awake, and the rubber balls are “active”. Therefore, the correct answer is “active”.<n><n>#### 6.<n>James starts with the rubber balls lying in the horizontal surface. When he wakes up, He can either leave the rubber balls lying, or pick them up and put them on the ground. However, if he picks them up the rubber balls end up lying on the ground. So, the correct answer is C" “active”.<n><n>Input: James needs to know how old he is. He divides 20 by the number 6 and loses his place.
