Their total number of was ___."<n><n>### Justify:<n>The number of cards given is written in the middle of the question. I have to explain why the answer is D. I will explain to the grader that D is correct because there are total of 3 people and one person can make the total amount of the cards. This means that Mary can give them 15,15 and 15 = 45. Kathy can give them 10, 10, 5 = 35 and Sarah can give them 1,1,1 = 4 total. We can break it down so we multiply it with 3 because there are 3 people. We can solve this using 3*15, or 3*35, or 35. If the ages of the children with ages less than 8 years are subtracted from those whose ages are greater than 15 to get the average of remaining children, the average is 11 years. How many children are there in the class<n><n>### Response<n><n>The average age = 12<n><n>(28-8)^2 + (28-15)^2 = 11<n><n>(20)^2 + (13)^2<n><n>250 + 169 = 419<n><n>419/28 = 15<n><n>total Students = 28 + 15 = 43<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:When someone falls from a mountain it will lead them to? Choices:  A: too much B: act dead C: die D: rush E: explode<n><n>### Response:		When someone falls from the mountain, they will probably die. When you fall you are gonna hit the ground very hard.<n><n>### Input:(A) If you add a negative 1 to a positive 7 what will the sum be? Choices: 1. A:1 positive3. 2:5 B:5 negative7. 3:1 positive11. C:5 positive15. D:5 negative35. E:1 negative<n><n>### Response:(A) 1 positive + 1 negative = 1\[-\](-1) = 5<n><n>### Input :(B) If you subtract a negative 2 from a negative 4 you will get? Choices: 2 negative21. B: 1 positiveA: 2 negative3. 3:7B: 1 negativeA: 2 negativeD: 1 positive<n><n>### Response :(B) 1 positive - 2 negative = 1 positive - -2 = -3<n><n>### Input :(C) If you add a positive 2 to a negative 5 you will get? Choice:  A:5 positive1. 2:10 B: -1 positive\15. C:5 positive\16. D:-23. E:-5+3<n><n>### Response :-A:C(D:-)\5 positive + 3=26<n><n>### (D) What’s the sum of - 1, - 2, -  3?<n>#### -3<n>Answer: -3<n><n>##  What’s the product of negative and negative two?<n><n>##  -2<n>Answer: -2<n><n>## What’s the product  of  positive  andnegative three?<n><n>##  +3<n>Answer: +3<n><n>## What’se the product  of negative two positive eleven?<n><n>##  -32<n>Answer: -32<n><n>## What  is  the  product  of3 negative4negative  two?<n>#### -36<n>Answer: -36<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:There was a saucepan used only for marinara, where was it kept? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:After new coke was discontinued what formula was used? There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:My favorite type of entertainment are rollercoasters and ferris wheels, where should I go? Choices:  A: theatre B: fairgrounds C: friend's house D: show E: casino<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Rationale<n>### D<n>I like all these other things too and they are all forms of<n>entertainment as well in my opinion.<n><n>### E<n>This choice is kind of a no brainer because entertainment is about having fun and there's less fun stuff for a grown man to do at a casino.<n><n>### C<n>Having a theme park where all the other rides are for kids wouldn't quite interest me like an amusement park would.<n><n>### A<n>I understand that plays are very entertaining but they really aren't my idea of entertainment.<n><n>### B<n>Fairs are very expensive and my friend might not want to go to an amusement park.<n><n>### Input:"Whom" is a formal pronoun that has to do with people (subject pronoun) or thing (object pronoun)<n><n>### Rationales:In this sentence here, "Whom" is a "formal pronoun" because I capitalized the word. Formal pronouns are pronouns that don't use the words they replaced in the sentence and usually have to do with people or things in general.<n><n>### RESULT:<n>```<n>Whom is pronoun<n>Whom is subject pronoun<n>Whom can replace "who" but "whom" is more of a formal pronoun<n>Whom uses "he," "she," "it," or "them" in place of "who"<n><n>``` The reason these pronouns are formal is usually because they are used for formal situations.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is someone watching a person who is playing guitar doing? Choices:  A: eternal B: religious C: unpredictable D: holy E: monastic<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:  A:  eternal B: religious  C: unpredictable  D: holy  E:monastic<n><n>### Input :Given that 2 22 2 + 2 = 2 22 + = and then, what does 983323<n><n>#### 29<n>Answer: 29<n><n>### Input and explanation:The diagram shows a rectangular garden with a square of 12-acre space. How much of the area of the garden is used for the garden? Write your answer to the nearest square inch.<n><n>#### 16<n>Answer: 16<n><n>Input explanation:<n><n>The rectangle encloses 15 * 15 = <<15*15=225>>225 square inches.<n>Therefore, the area of garden is 12/1=<<12/1=12>>12.<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>#### Input:<n>The square root of 129 is what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What could you do if you want to listen to music? Choices:  A: skate B: play piano C: fiddle D: play piano E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>1) Skate because you don't have to dance. 2) Play piano because your hand doesn't get tired.<n><n>Output: B and D are correct.<n>Rationales: I want to listen to music and do skating<n><n>### Input<n>Choices: Skateboarding, Rollerblading, and Inline skating A>B>C<n><n>### Output<n>1) Skateboarding is best because you have to get up all the time. 2) Rollerblading because you don't need to get up and get moving. 3) Inline skating is better because you can move faster than rollerblading.<n><n>### Explain your answers:<n>I don't want to exercise so skateboarding is best<n><n>### Instructions <n>There are 9 pumpkins at Mrs. Jones' house and 9 at Mrs. Johnson's house. If a pumpkin was taken from Mrs. Jones' house for every pumpkin taken from Mrs. Johnson's, how many pumpkins would Mrs. Jones have left?<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n>You subtract 10 from 19.<n>### Instruccions<n>There are 4 green strawberries, 13 red strawberries, and 7 purple strawberries. In the box, there is 1 red strawberry, 3 green strawberries and 1 purple strawberry. How many strawberries are in the box?<n>#### 7<n>Answer: 7<n>3 + 1 + (10 - 3-1 = 7) = 7<n><n>### Instructons<n>Kate has 10 chocolate bars. Her aunt gave her 10 ice cream cones. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The shelf was showing signs of instability, what should the carpenter fix to avoid any issues? Choices:  A: roof B: corner C: school building D: wall E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>Rationales: A: The roof is safe from the storm. The walls need protection.<n>B: Corner = <<corner>>side of a room/house/building/table. A table is made of 4 (or more!) corners. The carpenter should add a piece of wood there to strengthen the shelf.<n>D: A/D is right. In that case, the wall needs protection.<n>F: The answer is C. Incorrect answer. A/D is right (See B).<n>E: C is right. Incorrect answer. C+D/A is right.<n><n>### Input/Response:<n><n>Answer: D<n><n>The roof needs protection<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>### Answer: A<n><n>#### Answer:C<n><n>### Answer/Input:<n><n>### Answer, Response:<n><n>### Instructions 4<n><n>### Demonsetation:<n><n>Rational: Jan, Mary, John and Tom are going camping. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where are all participants likely to need sports equipment? Choices:  A: dicks sporting goods B: sporting event C: mall D: sears E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input:[Select all that apply] The two sides of a right triangle are called the legs, and the third side is called the hypotenuse. The sum of the two legs of a right triangle is always equal in value to the area of the triangle, the sum of the lengths of all three sides is always equal to the area of the entire triangle, and the area of a right triangle, or trapezoid for that matter (since the hypotenuse has half as much length as each of its legs), is one half the area of the two combined legs (which is two times the hypotenuse), and there is a constant difference between the length of one leg and the length of the other leg that does not change, which should be equal to one half the difference between the length of the two combined legs.<n><n>### Response:[Select all that apply](https://i.stack.imgur.com/2L65D.jpg)<n><n>### Input:-11.9 degrees of Celsius<n>-7.9 degrees of Celcius<n><n>### Response:-11.9-7.9=<<-11.9-3.9=8>>73<n><n>### Rationales:The temperature is -11.9  degrees of Celsius - 3.9 degrees of Celciecu.<n><n>### Input-826<n>-575<n><n>### Input/Rationales:826 + 575 =<<826+575=1394>>1394<n><n># Exam 2<n>### Instruction:-11.9  + 9.6 degrees of Celsius and -3.9 degrees of Celscius are both of the same sign so the temperature would increase.<n><n>### Rationale: -11.9 + 9.6 = 3 degrees of Celsius which would be to the left of the 0 line.<n><n>### Reponse [Select all that apply]:1.The temperature<n>2.would increase<n>3.by 4 degrees of Celsius(answer)<n>4.to the right of the 0 line<n><n>### Instructions<n>1. If the temperature is 36.1 degrees Fahrenheit, the temperature must be less than 36.1<n>2.

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The man was playfully wrestling with a woman he was enamored with, what was the physiological result? Choices:  A: competition B: blood C: wins D: medals E: erections<n><n>### Response:		<n>B. There were erections<n><n>## Solution:<n>**Rationale**: Blood was what would be in the man's and woman's veins, not erections.<n><n>```python3<n>from dataclasses import Dataclass<n>from typing import Optional<n><n>class Choice:<n>    # def __init__(self, choice: str):  # noqa<n>    pass<n>    __slots__ = [ "choice" ]<n>    def __repr__(self) -> Optional[ str ]:<n>        return self.choice<n><n>class Quiz:<n>    def __init__(self):  # NOQA<n>        self.Answers = {<n>            "A" : Choice(choice="competition"),<n>            "B" : Choice(choices="blood"),<n>            "C" : Choice(options="wins|medals"),<n>            "D" : Choice(option="erections")<n>        }<n>```<n><n><n>### InputThe man was playfullywrestling with a woman hewas enamored with What was thephysiological resultChoicesAcompetitionBbloodCwinsDmedalsEerections<n><n>### RESPONSEThe physiological resultwas erections<n><n>## Data Class Example<n><n>```python3 <n>>>> from dataclasses import dataclass<n>>>> @dataclass<n>... class Employee(object):<n>...     name: str<n>...     age: int<n>...<n>>>> foo = Employee('Smith',28)<n>>>> foo.age<n>28<n>>>> foo.__dict__<n>{'age': 28, 'name': 'Smith'}<n>```<n><n><n>```python3,3<n>>>> a = Employee('Rebecca', 28)<n>>> a.age<n>28 <n>>>> getattr(a, "age")<n>28<n>>> type(getattr(a, "name"))<n><class'str'><n>>> type(getattribute(a, "name", ""))<n><class'str_type'><n>>> get__a__name___type(a)<n>'str_type'<n>```<n><n>Notice how the `Employee` type of `a` does not reflect a `name` of `Smith`. To remedy this, we can use the `dataclass`
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The small cabin was not available, so they were upgraded to what? Choices:  A: villa B: spacecraft C: hall D: palace E: hotel<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### The correct answer is: A: villa<n><n>#### Villa<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input 3:<n><n>### Write a response that appropriates completes the request. It can be a program or a mathematical solution.<n><n>### 3.2.1-19 Solve using a mathematical equation<n><n>### Solve 4.3.4-10<n><n><n>- [x-3=2x-18](x-3=2*(3)-18):<n>- x = 22<n>- Solve: <n>- x = 4<n>- Solve:<n>- 4 = -18<n>- Therefore, x = 22.<n>

What is the first step in rebuilding the tower?<n><n>### RationalesThe rule is that <16:00 > and <23:00 > both should be considered <23:0>. Therefore the first step should be <remove the block at 23:0>. We can assume the following:<n><n>* The game is made of 12 piles<n>* the lowest pile is 3 inchs high<n>* the next one is also 3 inchs high.<n>* the third one contains 4 blocks.<n><n>### ResponseA. <<remove the block at 0:23>><n>#### 5:59:59 PM<n>Answer: 5:59<n><n>## Input<n>A square tower is being built on a mountain top. But we cannot make any hexagons inside 5-acre, so we must find the shape which contains least number of hexagons.<If we want to build pentagons, it requires eight different hexagons. Choices :  A : 1 B : 2 C : 10 D : 11 E : 9<n><n>### Response<n>When we divided we should put a denominator to the numerator. This means we should divide 99 by something. We multiply a number by 9. That's how we get 99. Then, we should see how many times 99 divide by 9. That will give us an answer for 99/9. For example, if we divide something by 9, we would get 1.<n><n><n>### Output:<n>Your response is written too well. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The lady was doing a one man show of her tell story, when the show began she did what? Choices:  A: persuade B: slept C: take center stage D: challenge E: speak clearly<n><n>### Response:		<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would you store a shopping bag if all the seats in your vehicle are full? Choices:  A: the roof B: storage cabinet C: car trunk D: retail store E: home<n><n>### Response:		How would I store a shopping bag in a situation like this?<n>#### C<n>#### 1<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Inputs: There are six types of apples in your town. 42% of the town’s apples are Golden Delicious. 9 other types of apples make up the remaining number of apples. How many other types of apples are there?<n><n>### Response<n>#### 9<n>Answer: 9<n><n>### Input<n>#### E: The average (mean) value of a certain set of data is 13. What is the mean of an even larger data set whose range is 5 to 25 and which contains only even numbers?<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input.<n>#### A: The sum of the digits in 76, 79, 81, and 83 is 5. Is 85 a multiple of 46?<n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n>### Instructions<n>#### A:<n>There was a 45% decline in the city’s gas mileage in 1992. In the following years, gas mileage increased by 2% per year. By how much was city gas mileage higher in 2000 than in 1991?<n>#### 4.0%<n><n>#### Answer:<n>Answer: 4.0%

Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		Select a choice that accurately summarizes the definition.<n>```<n>### I know this, what to do now #<n>I would just put the answer<n>- Select the letter of the choice that accurately summarize the definition.<n> - A:make music B:believe in god C:give speeches D:complete sentences E:build houses<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>### Instruction and Demonstration #<n>You’re making a cake, so you’ll need more: <n>- butter<n>- flour<n>- eggs<n>- water<n>- salt<n>- chocolate and butter<n><n>### Input and Response Example #<n>- B+F+eggs+water<n>```<n>### Rationales #<n>- butter<n>```<n>### butter #<n>- F<n>Answer: Chocolate and Butter<n>#### Chocolate and butter <n>answer:choco and butter<n>```<n>Answer: Choc, Butter<n>```<n><n>## Exercise<n>## Input<n><n>## Input/Output example<n>```<n>## You're making a cake!<n>## Cakes need: butter, flour, eggs, water, salt, and chocolate and buter.<n> <n>## A:What ingredient do you need more of? <n>- A:Butter<n>```<n>## Demonstration: <n>```<n>## What you want to do<n>- A:put the butter on the list<n>- C:put the chocolate on the list<n>- A:put cocoa on the list<n>- F:put butter on the list.<n>```<n>```<n>## Butter needs<n>- A: put butter on the list <n>The butter needs the number 4 which is put next to butter and it reads 4 butter <n>- C: put cocoa on the list <n><n>## Salt<n>- C: put salt on the list  4 salt salt salt 4<n>```<n>```<n><n>**Rationales:<n>## Input: <n> <n>## Input/Output<n>```<n>## You are going to make a cake. What do you need to make a cake<n>- A: butter<n>- F: flour<n>- E: eggs<n>- B: brush<n>- C: Ch

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:He had been doing favors for everybody at work, it was frustrating not getting any what for it? What is the minimum of remaining people?<n>Rational :<n>15 – 6 = 9<n>9-1 = 8<n>Output: Choices:<n>  A: 8<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: 8<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What did the business require of everyone walking into their store? Choices:  A: wear shoes B: learn C: hope for peace D: have a great day. E: do well<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Question:<n>What did the business require?<n><n>* Correct answers: A and E<n>* Explain this answer<n><n>The business required that customers wear shoes while visiting their store.<n><n><n>### Question 1:<n>What did the store owner require customers to wear at the store?<n><n>* Correct answer: None<n>* Rationales<n>	<n>	Explain this answer<n><n>All options are incorrect. As per the instruction, there is a business that required customers to wear shoes while visit to the store. That does not mean the business owner required customers to  wear shoes. The owner required all customers wear shoes.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Choices:  A: bathroom B: closet C: school D: room E: church<n><n>### Response:		 B<n><n>### Rationales: The college kids used their bathroom as a bedroom, hence bedroom was not an option.<n>The question's options included a bathroom, a school closet, a room, a church, and a school. Although the kids "weren't known for" (and were "not known for") their "decor choices," the kids had a bedroom and a bathroom in a shared room. The kids used the bathroom as a bed. So they used a bathroom as a bed, which is a room in a college bathroom. Hence: closet. The kids used a _closet_ as a bedroom. However, they could not have used a bed as a closet because they had a bedroom. The kids did not use a room. They used a bedroom. Therefore they did not use _a_ room. The kids might have used a church as a bedroom or closet, but the question said they did not use a room for the bed, meaning they only used the bathroom as the bedroom or the closet. Therefore, they did not use the bathroom or the closet as a room. Thus, they had not used a room to house a bed, which eliminates _room_ as a possible answer to the question. Thus, the answer was bathroom or closet.<n><n>#### 1 - B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Instructions for teachers:<n><n>* Provide the students with a description of a task.<n><n>* Provide several options as choices to demonstrate the answer.  <n><n>### Additional Resources<n>* [The answer is here](https://mathriddles.wu.edu/solution/53)

Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice: (A) <n><n>### Inputs:James was cooking a stew in his kitchen. He went to his freezer, where he found no potato. Where else might he look for a good potato? Choices: A: restaurant B: pantry C: casserole D: root cellar E: pocket<n><n>### Response E:<n>Answer: E, pocket<n><n>### Input <n>There are 8 different colored balloons in the room. All balloons have the same width. There are 5 red balloons and 4 blue balloons. If there are double the number of red balloons as blue balloons, then how many red and blue baloons are there altogether?<n><n>### Rationales <n>If there are 5 red and 4 blue baloons, then there must be 5 + 4 = <<5+4=9>>9 baloons altogether.<n><n>### Answer <n>The answer is 9<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>B<n>```<n>### Rationale:<n><n><n>The temperature changes rapidly are cooling down and the sun is out the temperature is increasing rapidly.<n><n>Input:What are the digits that the first two numbers have so far in this problem? The sum of the first two digits of the first number is 8, and the sum of the last two digits of the second number is 8. The second number has four digits more than the first number.<n>Rationales:The first number has 2 digits, so the first digit the second digit is 8.<n>The last number has 4 digits so the last digit of the second digit is 3, so the second number is 2<n>The third digit of the first digit is 1.<n>The third digit of The second digit is 5 and the sum of the numbers in the whole problem. <n>```<n>325 + 84 + 88 = <<325+84+88=245>>245<n><n>3(8)-84 = 3(8)-8(8)-8<n><n><n>The other one is <n>If your number does not have a fraction<n><n>```<n>2/5 + 6/7 + 4/5<n>```<n><n>The number 3 is a composite number.<n><n>```<n>3 +7 =10<n>```<n>So this can be a composite number so it will have a divisor of 10<n>So you have to divide by 10 3/10<n>if the number does not have a fractor you will just have 3/10 and you dont need to divide, then again your number will be a <n><n><n>```<n>23 + 18 +13 = 54<n>2(13) -18 = 2(13)-16(2)-13<n>```<n>#### 44<n><n>### How could you add and take away numbers that contain fractions?<n>```<n>37/5 + 86/10 = (37/5) +(86/10)=34.5 + 8.6<n>86(8/10) = 7(10) = 60<n>```<n>### What is the least common multiple of 10 and 21?<n><n>```<n>(10

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: grocery store B: nightstand C: armpits D: own bathroom E: medicine chest<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Why:<n>I used the word "look" in the word problem, not the words "put" or "find" which are used in instruction.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>When you use a definition to prove something, it must follow the format of Definition, Theorem, Proof. If you do prove something and leave out a step, then it is wrong. I don’t understand how something like that can be marked as incorrect.<n><n>### Example:If you define a line segment as being two segments that join at one endpoint, then you can call any line a line segment. If you call any segment that can be traced as a line a line, then you can prove that if you have two points, you can trace a straight line.<n><n>### There are a bunch of similar questions to the first one, and they all seem to have the same issue in how the question is worded, which is that the word "put" is substituted for the word "look". But they all ask the same question "Where did his wife (or husband or whoever) ask him to look first" (so this is my assumption). So it seems like an odd oversight on the part of the person writing the test.<n><n>### Input for the final question:When can you move the decimal point in rational numbers without changing the value of the rational number? Choices:  a: when dividing by a factor smaller than ten b: when multiplying by a factor less than or equal to ten c: both when dividing by a smaller factor and multiplying by a smaller factor d: neither a nor b<n><n>### Response for the final question:C<n><n>### Why<n>The answer is both. You must move the decimal point when dividing by a number less than ten to achieve the same value of the dividend (divide by 4, move decimal point to right. Divide by 4 again to get the same number = 0.25). When dividing by a number between 10 and 90, you must move the decimal point left a number of places equal to the number of zeros after the decimal point (move decimal point 3 places to the right). Similarly, you must multiply by a number less than or equal to 10 to achieve the same quotient as in your original multiplication (multiplying by 4 to get the same number as before, 0

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is a parents primary duty? Choices:  A: speak freely B: happiness of a child C: care for children D: school child E: control children<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A: speak freely<n><n>### Why:<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>##<n>## Input: The sum of the digits in a two-digit number is 12. That means "we are tired" is wrong because we're currently feeling that way.<n><n>Therefore, the answer should be "very tired."<n><n>### Instructions:Write the sentence in a way that the following two criteria are met.<n><n>### 1:Change the verb tense of a sentence from the past to the present<n><n>### 2:Change the pronoun from “we” to “yourself” and replace all subject pronouns with “you”<n><n>### Dem:I've gone to the doctor for the past 3 times, so I am no longer sick.<n><n>### R:I have been to the doctor for the last 3 time, so I am no long sick now.<n><n>#### A:We have been to Disney World for the last 3 times<n><n>Explanation: We have been to Disney World is incorrect because as the sentence states we are sick, so we haven't been for the last 3times.<n>The correct answer is You have been to Disney World.<n><n>### E:I was very tired.<n><n>Explanation(The same as A)<n><n>### A: We have not seen him for a long time.<n><n>Explanatin<n><n>#### 84<n>Answer: 84/8<n><n>### Input:/usr/bin/time /etc/init.d/S02 httpd<n><n>### Inst:<n>### Add the correct quotation marks and /home/user/public_html is a directory. How many yellow pencils are left over?<n><n>### Response Two: B:9<n><n>### Demostration:<n>#### Input Two<n>Let’s say N is the number of yellow pencils with erasers<n>#### Inputs<n>1. 19 students and<n>2.  18 pencils<n>#### Output<n>Total number of yellow pencil with erasers = 18<n>18/2 =<<18/2=9>>9<n><n>23 more yellow pensils = 9 + 23 =<<9+23=32>>32<n><n>4 students with sharrapners =<<4 students with sharapners>><n><n>4 x 2 = <<4*2=8>>8 pencils each<n><n>8* 2 = <<8*2=16>>16 pencils total and<n><n>19 - 16 = <<19-16=3>>3 pencils available for each student<n><n>N =<<19-16>>3 / 4 =<<9/4=2>>2 pencils total (yellow pencils without erasers)<n><n>Thus, there are 2 more of the yellow pencils (yellow pencils with erasure) than there are the ones without an eraser and there are 3 yellow pencils without an eraser for each student.<n><n>Pencils with an eraser =<<2>>2 Pencils without erasure = 3 - 2 =<<3-2>>1<n><n>### Exam Exercise:<n>In class there are 5 girls. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:A strong laxative will help you keep what kind of bowel movements? Choices:  A: strongwoman B: cake C: regular D: weak E: fragile<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: 30<n><n>### Input:[8 * 48 = 384](8*48=384) square yards can completely cover a rectangular playground at a park. Each row of the playground is 50 yards long. How many rows are needed to cover the playground with enough leftover?<n><n>### Rationales: We can find the number of squares needed to fully cover the playground. [Square root of 384 = 19.66](SQRT(384)=19.66) We need the the number of rows × 50 to = 9.84 Then we need to round the answer to the nearest whole number. So 10 = [19](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/856613/what-is-the-correct-equation-to-calculate-10-19c2?answertab=active#tab-top)<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10 (answer)<n><n>### Input:"42"<n><n>### Response:"forty-two"<n><n>(In other words, there are too few hours in the day in which to work<n>and have a life. :oops: )<n><n>### Instantiating:<n>(In other words there are too few hours to [do] this and have a life.)<n><n>### 4<n><n>### Input:#447<n><n>### Response:#447<n>### 447<n><n>---<n>### Instantiate the above answer.<n><n>### 27<n><n>### Input:@"8 x 4"<n>### Response:@"8 x 4 = 32"<n>27<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would you carry a pen as you go through your day? A bored mind will always seek amusement. So, an individual who has nothing to do may end up chatting with friends in order to engage his/her mind.<n><n>### Input (Optional):Answer the following short answer question.<n>What is the value of a 45° angle?<n><n>### Response (Required):<n>The value of a 4x5° angle is 1.<n><n>### Why?:<n>Sin(Θ) = cos(Θ) and tan(Θ) =<n>sin(Θ)/cos(Θ)<n><n>Thus they are equal.<n><n>### Rationales (Required):<n>The unit of angles is in radian.<n><n>1°= π/180<n>- 1/3 = - 1/180<n>Then 1 ° = π divided by 180.<n>The degree is a unit equal to θ divided by 360 degrees.<n>So, π/18 = π/18 * 360<n>π/180 is the radian, 180 is less than pi (3.14)<n>π = 22/7 = 22 * 7/7<n>So, 22/7/180 = π/165.<n>360°/π = 360 <n><n>### Optional Response (Optional):<n>This angle is equal to 180°.<n><n>### Optional Rationales (Optional):<n><n>360°= 180°+ β and 90°=10° + β and 45°= 60° - β when, β = 0, 45 <n><n>### Inputs:How did Henry build Rome from a small rural settlement to a great empire and lasting capital? Choices:  A: tennessee B: band practice C: orchestra D: violin case E: music store<n><n>### Response:		A: tennessee<n><n>#### Tens of thousands<n>Answer: Tennessee.<n><n>### Input(1):Tonight, the first 50 people to leave their seats will be allowed to skip the line at the front door. How many people are eligible for expedited entry into tonight's concert?<n><n>### Response(1): 50<n><n>### Input:(2):I am thinking about ordering pizza. I can have 2 large pizzas delivered for $18.86 total. I can only afford to buy 1 large pizza. I would like to have two small pizzas for $9.95 delivered at the same time. How much does the total cost of pizza delivery this meal?<n><n>### response(2): 9.95 + 18.86 = <<19.45>>19.45<n><n>### Input (1,2):<n>An equation could be:<n>Sm, S1, S2, S3, S4<n><n>Sm represents the original price of a small pizza and Sn represents the original price of an extra small (N) pizza.<n>The total cost of the original pizza + (S1 + S2 + S3 + S4)<n>The total cost of 2 pizzas is $$Sm + S1 + S2 + Sm + S3 + S2 + Sm$$<n>The total cost of two pizzas is equal to two original pizzas plus 3 extra small pizzas.<n>$$Sm + S1 + Sm + S2 + Sm = 2Sm + 3Sm = 3Sm +Sm$$<n><n>The formula for the answer will be $$Sm + Sm = 9.95$$, because the $5 for each small pizza will be equal to the original price of the pizza. The original price of the total pizza is equivalent to the original price of one small pizza, plus the cost of an extra small pizza.<n><n>#### 15.90<n>Answer: 15.9<n><n>

Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where could you find many theater? Choices:  A: school B: populated area C: military base D: opera E: church<n><n>### Response:		Choose Option:<n>Answer: A: school<n><n>### Rationales:A theater (also known as a playhouse or playhouse, or theater) is an art form and an entertainment venue, wherein theatrical performances are produced for public performances.<n><n>### Theatres may host a variety of other forms of performance in addition to "theatre" within their definition, such as:<n><n>*   Ballet<n><n>*   Circus (tent) (bigtop) (sometimes known as "circus theatre" or "circus arena in France and Italy)<n><n>*   Concert hall, to present orchestral or choral music<n><n>*   Dance, to present dance<n><n>*   Film<n><n>*   Gymnastics, to present gymnastics or acrobatics<n><n>*   Opera house<n><n>*   Puppet theatre<n><n>*   Repertory theatre (repertory theatre, repertoire theatre, repertory company)<n><n>*   Night Club and Dinner Theatre<n><n>*   Theatre for social change, a specific type of theatrical space which is specifically created to engage in dialogue with a particular audience around an issue of social or political concern.<n><n>### Some ancient theatres were built in naturally occurring openings in hillsides, which are known as rostra. The name "theatre" is derived from the Ancient Greek θέατρον (théatron, "[structure] with spectacle, seeing place"). In the last few centuries, the use of theatre has spread, and its meaning has narrowed to the performing arts and, occasionally, to films or television.<n><n>## What are the questions you will be answering tomorrow?
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to thank someone for saying I have done a good job, what would I do? Choices:  A: smile B: shake hands C: express gratitude D: say you're welcome E: appreciate compliment<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### <n>Answer: B<n>

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. How many healthy fruits are in the box?<n><n>### Choices: A: 1 B: 2 C: 3 D: 4 E: 5<n><n>### Response<n><n>E 5<n><n>##Explanation<n>A = 1 B = 2 C = 3 D = 4 E = 5<n><n>There are 5 fruits so the answer is E<n><n>##Instructor<n><n>There were less than 5 fruits because the fruit didn't include the watermelon.<n><n>##Instructions<n><n>12 people ate a total of 8 lbs of strawberries. Only angles can be measured in degrees.</u></th></tr><n></thead><n></table><n><n>### Answer false since angles can only be measured in degrees.<n><n>### Input :What fraction of a person is a face? Choices: 1/3 1/8 1/31<n><n>### Answer:1/8<n><n>### Instructions:<n>An artist has 120 paint brushes for painting and wants to divide them into 2 drawings. What fraction of the paint brushes does each painting get?<n><n>### Answer One:<n><n>### Response Three or Four Pages:The ratio of the paint brush divided equally to 2 paintings is 120 : 2 = <<120:2=60>>60<n>### Ratio of paint brushes used in one painting is 60 /2 = <<60/2=30>>3<n>### Ratio to one painting is 120 / 3 = <<120/3=120>>120<n>### Answer Two:<n>### Response Three Pages:The first division is 120 brushes divided into two pieces each = <<120=60>>6<n>The second division is the number of paint brushes divided into four drawings = <<60=40>><n>### Answer Three:<n>### Response Two Pages:The number of paint brush divided into 2 paintings is the same as 40 / 2 = <<40/2=20>><n>### Rationales:120 brush divided equally to two paintings is 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The children saw superman fly overhead, what did they exclaim as a result? Choices:  A: ouch B: skip C: enjoyed D: awesome E: watch television<n><n>### Response:		D for awesome<n><n>Input:The children saw super man fly overhead, what did the children exclaim as a result Choices: A: ouch B:- skip C: enjoyed D:- enjoy E: watch tv<n><n>### Response D: enjoy<n><n>#### 39<n>Answer: 39<n><n>Input: If a plane travels 900 mi in 4 hour 30 minutes, approximately how far will the plane travel in one minute? Choices: 1 mile 1000 mi 900 ft 60 mi<n><n>### Response 57790 ft per 60 mi<n>Input: If a plain travel 1000 ft in every minute. How long will it take for the plane to travel how many mi? Choices: 57 minutes 57 seconds 1000 seconds 100 hours<n><n>### Response : 6 hours<n><n>#### 6<n><n>Answer: 6

Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where should an excavation never take place? Choices:  A: construction site B: cemetary C: building D: city E: archeological site<n><n>### Response:		<n>The excavation should never take place from construction site, cemetary, and archeological site. The excavation will only takes place within building and city.<n><n>#### Answer:City, Construction Site<n><n>### Input：<n>When the cousins visited their aunt, their mother drove a total of 21 miles to pick them up. The cousins rode 4 miles to their grandparents, and the rest of the trip was to return the car to their aunt. How many miles was the return trip?<n><n>### Response： <n>The return trip is 21 - (4 + 21) = <<21-4+21=16>>16 miles.<n><n>#### Answer：16 miles<n><n>### Instuction：<n><n>#### Input：Alice was reading a math book and was interrupted by her friend Carol, who called to ask about doing a group project together. Alice answered, “Hey Carol, I’m in the middle of page 18 right now. I’ll call you when I get to page 30.” How many pages were between Alice and the number Carol asked about?<n><n>#### Response：<n><n>Alice was in the middle of page ____. She will reach page 30.<n><n>She has 12 pages<n><n>In between 12 pages<n>Between 12 pages<n>is 18.<n><n>### Answer：<n><n>#### Input :<n>Ms. Smith wrote an article, titled, “A New Era or the Same?” She wrote that the population of this country will continue to increase. After she wrote that, she wondered whether it was better to write about how the population would increase and therefore create a need for more living space, jobs, roads, cars, and grocery stores. Or if she should not mention the increase. How many sentences did Ms. Smith write?

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Reaching advantage position in a competitin puts me in what position as compared to others? Choices:  A: determination B: upper hand C: superior D: higher position E: skill<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input:(A) A person who walks 6 miles south and then walks 8 miles east is how many miles north of the starting point?<n><n>### Answer:A<n><n>### Response:(B) If I buy two books for $12, how much would one book cost me?<n><n>### Response(C): If I cut a rectangle that is 4 inches by 2 inches, then I cut that rectangle in half along the 4 inch diagonal, which part of the original rectangle will I have now? Choices: 1: none 2: the top left corner 3: the left half 4: the right half 5: the top right corner<n><n>### Answer:(C)<n><n><n>### Input.(B) How many of these shapes are triangles?
