Choices:  A: wedding B: tennis C: closet D: left foot E: house<n><n>### Response:		A. <n><n>#### Explanation:  <n>White shoes must be worn on special occasions, and then only in combination with a white shoe.   <n><n>### Demomstration:A woman must wear white shoes on her wedding day.  <n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Question to Answer<n>Write a request to identify each of the following sets of fractions using a common denominator. Some answers will vary.<n><n>### Explanation for How to Find:<n><n>Answer:<n>`<n>8/24 + 9/9 = 17/24`<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Question: Write a request to find the solution to the following systems of equations.<n>Some solutions will vary.<n><n>`   1 = 0.9 - x/2`  <n>   2 = 0.8/4+y`<n><n>#### Solutions:<n>The number line is a tool that graphically represents all the real numbers. (Real numbers are whole numbers, fractions, and decimals.)<n><n>#### How to Find:<n>The number line can be divided into equal sections.<n><n>You can represent a one fourth on a number line in the following way.<n><n>The point below the one fourth on the number line that is represented above would be four fifths. The number that is halfway between twelve and eight represents one half, halfway between one third and one half represents two thirds, and halfway between four fifths and three fourths represents five sixths.<n><n>Each time you take the number on the number line divided by four and subtract one, you get one twelfth.<n><n>Example :<n><n>### Instructons:<n>Question:<n>`1 + 2x/4 = 6 - x/2`<n>`x = 2`<n><n>How did you find your answer?<n><n>### Solutions:<n><n>### Expected Answer:<n><n>Answer:x = 2<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What place of work might you find a hairpin? Choices:  A: hair salon B: hair of woman C: barber shop D: pincushion E: woman's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>\*This question does not require an answer### Explanation:<n><n>The answer is C. "Hairpin" sounds like "hair of a woman."<n><n>**Hint:**<n>The word "hairpin" is often used in the context of hair.<n><n>####<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Instructions:Look at line x in 52, where x represents an unknown number:<n><n>### Explanation:{line52;55:43;84;86;91}<n><n>###<n><n>### Exclamations:<n><n>####<n>Answer:/114-62<n><n>### Operations:<n><n>#### 2346.7 + 3.8 + 11.4 - 5.6 +4.38 - 2.9 - 6.77<n><n>Answer: 23467.42<n><n>###<n>Answer: [12 2 3] + [2 4 6]<n><n>### Input:{12}{2}{3}<n><n>### Operator:Addition<n><n>### Expected Output: 2<n><n>### Input:[2 4 6]:<n><n>### Operators<n><n>### Output: 1<n><n>### Expectation:<n><n>\*Question does not require an answer\*<n><n>### Explantion:<n><n>The number 5 is in both lists so it is subtracted from the larger list (3) and 2 is subtracted from the smaller list (1.)<n><n>#### 32 – 64 * 7 ÷ 3<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>####<n><n>Answer:<n>/50<n><n>__-0<n>

Choices:  A: radio station B: recording studio C: concert D: tv studio E: new york<n><n>### Response:		Choice C<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Choose the word that best replaces the underlined parts of the sentences.<n><n>### Task 1<n><n>The number of students in my class this semester has declined by 50 percent since last semester.<n>Since<n>When<n>During<n>As<n>While<n>### Task 2<n><n>I like to travel because I feel calmer and quieter during trips.<n>Since<n>When I<n>As long as<n>Since I<n>### Task 3<n><n>This cake has too much fat to be good to eat.<n>While<n>Since<n>When<n>Despite<n>Because<n>### Task 4<n><n>I can’t go to class until my stomach stops growling, and I haven’t eaten since 5:30.<n>After<n>When I<n>When<n>Even though<n>Because<n>## Task 1<n><img style="padding-right:82px; height=50px; " src="https://fds-static.flickr.com/3311/29211516525_552b9ff2c5_z.jpg"/><n><n>### Inputs: A, B, C, D are the choices<n><n>### Input C<n><n><img style="height=180px; " src="/images/b.jpg"/><n><n><br><n><img style="width:100%; " src="/images/c.jpg"/><n><n><n><br>	<n><img style="border-radius:50%; width:50px; "src="/images/d1.png"/><n><n><br><img style="border-right:1px solid #000000; border-left:1px solid #d2c4f0; border-bottom:1px solid #939393; border-top:1px solid #c1c1c1; height:1000px; width:1000.15px; border-radius:50%;; " src="https://www.sxc.hu/photo/1461401"><br><n><n><n><n><br><a href="https://www2.marshfield.wi.gov
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. They were really what? Choices:  A: personal B: special C: shiny D: rare E: irregular<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: In the 4 seasons, what are the 4 letters that do not change their name?<n><n>Demonstration:  Fall, Summer, Spring, and Winter<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: S, U, and T<n><n>### Input <n><n>Input: What happened when Daisy and Raspberry came to school late?<n><n>Demon Stration:They lost 20 minutes of class.<n><n>### Response <n><n>Response:Besides losing 20 minutes of school?<n><n>###<n>

Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n><n>### Response:		E = win.<n><n>#### Why?<n><n>In the following sentence, the antecedent of 'he' refers to the old man 'John'. So, it applies.<n>`John was retired and liked doing crossword puzzles simply just to pass time.'<n><n>B and D cannot apply since they are not given in the instruction.<n><n>A and C cannot apply since 'every morning' is not given.<n><n>### Input:(1+x)^3=25. What is the value of x?<n><n>#### Response:2.5607<n><n>#### Why?I'm just dividing 25 by 1+x to derive the answer.<n><n>### Output:1+x=3.25607 which is not the original input.<n><n>### This is the original input.<n>1+x = 25.<n><n>### My first try:<n><n>1+x = x^2 + x<n>x^2 = 25 - x<n>x^2 - x = 25 -x<n>x^2 - 2x = 25 - 2x<n>x^2-2x = 23-x<n>x^2 −2x = 24 - 2x<n>=>2x = 22<n>

He didn't want any meat for it.  Where might Simon be taking the cow? Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n><n>### Response:		<n>D: Simon wants to have the cow work, so he is taking the cow to a dairy farm.  He does not want any meat for it, so he is not taking it to a butcher shop, the cow is going to the countryside, and the cow is not going to Canada.<n>### Why?<n>He is planning to put the cow to use, and he does not want any meat from the cow.  He also is not going to use the cow to go to Canada.<n><n>### Input 2:A group of 14 students were in a classroom. There were 7 boys and 7 girls. The number of girls and boys that were the least were an odd number more the same. How many girls and boys were in the classroom?<n><n>### Response 2:    <n>14 students, 7 boys and 4 girls were in the room.  If there were 7 boys and an odd number of girls, then the number must be 3, 5, or something other than 7.  The odd number of girls must be 3, and there were not 3 girls in the classroom.  The difference between 17 and 7 is not an odd number, since there are 9 fewer boys than girls.  Therefore, the difference between an odd number and each other number is 2, except 7, so 7 - (odd number) = 1.<n><n>The final result of the calculation is 19 - 7 = <<19-7=12>>12 girls and 7 boys.<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input3: 1/8 of the money left in your mom's purse is $7.25. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What could happen after driving car that does not involve pain? Choices:  A: automobile accidents B: backache C: eye strain D: getting tired E: car crash<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>> **Answer:**E(1)<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n><n><n>### Demostration:<n><n><n>### Explanation:<n><n><n><n>#### Pain can happen after driving a car:Eye strain, Car crash, backache, getting tired<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>>Which choice completes the passage?<n><n>You can make a pot of coffee in your own kitchen faster<n>than you can go to a fast food restaurant and purchase the same.<n>You can prepare a home-cooked breakfast in half the time<n>required by stoping at fast food restaurants.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>*If I was home earlier, I could have made the food.<n>*I could have made the food and I could have done it earlier!<n>*I could have done it faster.<n>*Faster!<n>*I could make it faster!<n>*Fast!<n><n>### Multiple Choice:<n><n>> **Answer**:C(1)<n><n>1<n>### Explanations:<n><n>#### A:Faster than you can go to a fas...:This is not an example: A(1)<n>Eye strain,Car crash,backache,getting tired,<n><n>#### B:make the food.:This is not an example.B(1)<n>Home made food:fast,home made food,food,faster,<n><n>#### C:prepare.:This is not an exampel (1)C(1)<n>prepare:faster,cook at home<n><n>#### D:A lot of people will drive to a fast food restaurant instead of cooking at home even though it takes longer.:This is not an explanation.D(1)<n><n>#### E:You can make a pot o...This is not an explanation:E(1)<n>Coffee faster<n><n>1<n><n>### Answers:<n><n>*Faster:A(1)<n><n>*I could have cooked it faster:B(1)<n><n><n>### Instructon:<n><n>>Whcih answer best responds to the prompt.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>>I had to spend about two hours this morning cleaning my bathroom, and I'd rather have spent the time in the yard, but now that the work on the house is done
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The dog ran to the front window and barked, this is because of a presence at the what? It might be helpful for you to reread the question.<n><n>#### Why not: <n><n>Choice *B: go somewhere* does make it clear what the reader is doing. They're going somewhere. <n><n>Choice *C: knit* is not a verb of location or motion.<n><n>Choice *D: read book* is a verb of doing. When you read a book, you *do something to that book* and you are not moving, you have decided to stay for a duration of time. <n><n>Choice E *see particular program* also doesn't sound like a motion and doesn't make it clear what you're doing. <n><n>### Output: <n>Examine something, do something.<n>

There are 5 times as many oranges in Burt's basket than in Jane's basket. How many apples, oranges, and bananas are in both baskets?<n>Rationales<n>Burt and Jane both have 10 apples, so 7 more apples are in Jane's basket = <<7>>7.<n>There are 10 - 7 = <<10-7=3>>3 fewer apples in Burt's<n>25 oranges - 10-7 = <<25-10-7=8>>8 apples in total.<n>5 * 8 = <<5*8=40>>4 times more oranges are in Burt's!<n>There are 15 bananas in Burt's, so 7 more bananas > 7 more apples = <<7>>7 in Burt's and 3 more bananas in Jane's.<n>Finally, there are 21 more bananas in Burt.<n><n>#### 40<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Input : There are two more blue balls than green. She wanted to bake enough cake for 16 guests plus 2 extra pounds for later. If the party lasted for 2 hours and each guest ate 2 pounds of cake, how many pounds of cake did Lindsey have left over?<n><n>#### Rationales:16 guests + 2 extra pounds of cake = <<16+1.5 pounds of cake>><n>Each guest ate 2.0 pounds of cake<n>Therefore, Lindsey had 16 + (2.0 * (16/2)) = <<16+2*8>><n>16 + 16 + 2*8 + 2 extra pounds<n>=   16 + 26 + 16 =   58<n><n>#### 58<n>Answer:58<n><n>__  Note: 58 extra pounds of cake<n><n>__<n><n>#### Response: E<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input:<n><n>Lindsey wants to bake enough cakes to feed 18 people, plus 3.0 pounds for <n>extra.<n><n>Rationales:<n>She had 18 + (3.0 * (18/2)) pound for the extra = <<18+3*9>>9 is the number to plug in for the extra pound.<n>The answer is 18 + (18 + 2.7 pounds) = 18 + (27.7) = 46 ponds.<n>

Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is a great, but non-specific, overall benefit of exercise? Choices:  A: good health B: heart attacks C: relaxation D: rest E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		<n>####  E<n>Answer:  E<n><n>### Input :Which sentence includes a comma that helps the reader understand the meaning of the sentence? Choices: A: As he stared at the empty pantry, John knew that the time for a shopping trip had come again.B: As he stared, at the empty pantry John knew, that the time, for shopping, had comes.C: As he stared his empty pantry, John realized he needed go shopping again.D: As he stared into the pantry, John knew, that the empty grocery bags called for a shopping trip.<n><n>### Response :<n>####  A<n>Answer:  A<n><n>### Input:[ ] (5281208×120)<n><n>### Response:(3672960×120)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would you be going if using a parking lot near a roller coaster? Choices:  A: farm B: business district C: car D: amusement park E: urban area<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question.<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: Not B<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: Not C<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input<n>Where would you be going to next?<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where will a bullet projectile be found during a war? Choices:  A: battle field B: museum C: weapon D: canon E: tornado<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple response question<n>Where will a bullet projectiles be found during a war B,C,E<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Demonstrate how to answer this multiple choice question.<n>### Answered Correctly:<n>BCE<n>### Answered Incorrectly:<n><n>### Input<n>Where will a bullet be found during a war.<n>Choices:<n>A:Battle field<n>B:Weapon<n>C:Museum<n>D:Canon<n>E:Tornado<n><n>### Solution:<n>Let us assume the choices are: A,B,C, and D.<n><n>### Case 1(If the bullet is in battle field)<n><n>```python<n>battle_field= input('Where will a bullet projected be during a war')<n>if "battle field" in battle_field:<n>    print('A')<n>else:<n>    print("This choice is wrong")<n>```<n><n>### Case2(Otherwise)<n><n><n>```python<n>if "battle_field" not in battle_field: <n>    <n>    print('B')<n>else:<n>```<n><n><n><n><n>### Input A number<n>### Input b number<n>### Input c number<n>### Input d number<n>###Input e Number<n><n>## Question<n>```python<n>print("please enter a number")<n>num= input("Enter a number:")<n>print("Please enter another number:")<n>num2= input("Enter a Number: ")<n>print(f"Your First number is {num} and second number is {num2} ")<n><n><n>```<n><n>## Question answer<n>```python<n>print('')<n>num = input("enter a number")<n>num2 = input('enter another number')<n>print(f'Your First {num} and second {num2}')<n><n><n>```<n>

Choices...  E: 45 B: 42 C: 43 D: 44<n><n>### Demontration:<n>Input:- 6 + 5x3 = 7,3, 7 + 6 = 13.<n>6 x 3 = 18, 13 + 18 = 31.<n>#### 31<n><n>### Instructions :- What do you gain if you subtract 8 from -7 and add 9?<n><n>### Demontocration:<n>Input: If you subtract 8 from 7 and add 9, you will get 21.<n><n>#### 21<n><n>##### Solution :- What is the rule for -x + y = -a - b?<n>```<n>-x+y=-a-b<n>    y=x+a+b<n>```

In this task, the second reading will be 16°C cooler than the first reading. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is a place that could have hundreds of sporting goods store? Choices:  A: buy athletic equipment B: city C: espn D: town E: jerseys<n><n>### Response:		I chose option A<n><n>***<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question(s) below. Type your responses in the boxes (or use your document). The answer(s) for all questions should be given using fractions.<n><n>### When is the time between 7:00 AM and 5:00 PM?<n><n>Rational: 7:00AM = <7:00AM>=7<n><5:00PM>=<5:000PM>=<=5<n>Thus, time between 7: 00 AM and 7:00 PM is (7*12) hour; i.e., 84<n><n>### The time between 3:00 A.M and 7:05 P.M. was 6*13*4+4+11 hour. Write the time in a.m. p.m. format.<n><n>Rationals: 3: <3:00> = <2:00> <2:00 = 02 AM<n>02 AM <02:00PM>=7:05<7:05PM>=3:00PM <3:00PM=15:05> =15:05<n>Time in AM PM = 3:00 AM <3:00 AM> <6:00 PM>=<6:00PM>=11:00 PM <11:00=11:00><n>Thus, Time in PM is 11:00<n><n><n>### Three friends were born on the following dates: March 12, June 11, September 22. In what month the date is September 22?<n><n>### Four months have 31 or 30 days. What is the name of the fifth month?<n><n>Rationals for Q1: March = <March>=<3/12><n><3/12>=<5/12> = <5/12>=<F><n>=> <6/12>=<J> <6/12<=<June><n><6
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a light? Choices:  A: ocean B: desk C: universe D: attic E: chair<n><n>### Response:		<n>Light would go to C (the Universe).<n>Since it is a light we are going the Universe is the only answer.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is made out of only one piece? Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales: The puxxle is made out of only 1 piece.<n><n>### Input : There are m blue circles. There are k red circles.How many circles can someone color?<n><n>### Response : 120<n><n>### Rationale: there are 200 circles. each circle that can be colored is counted as 1. 10 times of 10, 10 times 20 and 10 times 30 is 300. 300 is a multiple of 10 and there are still 10 circles left. It is necessary to multiply 10 to get 120 circles<n><n>### Input<n>There are m blue squares.<n>There are k red squares.<n>How many blue squares can someone fill?<n><n>### Rationals<n>blue squares are number 1 2 3  ......  11  12  13   blue squares have at least 11<n>there are 12 blue squares<n>and 11+red squares are 12 so we can fill 23<n>we also can fill the holes that are left on the red squares<n>there are 24 red squares,<n>so in total we can fill 24+23=47<n>we can fill the holes that left on the blue squares<n>so in total we will have 47×12=574 to fill<n><n>### Response 574<n><n>### Input   Rationale<n>there are 14 apples. there are 12 cups. What is the amount of apples and cups of apples the person has to eat?<n><n>### Ans 14 cups<n><n>### Input <n>The difference of m and k is 15. <n>What is a larger number? Choices: A: m B: k C: (Answer: B(21).<n>(<n>### Ans 21<n><n>### Input    Rationale<n>what is the solution 5×2=30 there is 30 seconds and 15 minutes and 30 dollars (<n>### Ans 30<n><n>### Input Rational<n>There's a 27.3 kg dog. What should a person's weight be if that person wants to have the same

Which statement correctly expresses this relationship? <n>```<n>A. 4 <n>	B. 16x (2x - 1) <n>C. 3 <n>	D. 3 <n>```<n>Above answer is incorrect since 4 is not greater than m.<n>### Response: C<n>```<n>Why?: C) 3 because of 1 + x<n>```<n>### Instruction(1): If f(x) = -x2 - 8, and T(f) (t) = 6 - t4 + 16x, find the value of t when f(x) is a maximum.<n>```<n>Input: g(x) = -16x+8 						(1)<n>g '' (x) = -x^2 - 16x + 8 			(2)<n>g '' (1) = -8 			                (3)<n><n>t(g)(x) = 6 - x^4 + 16 x				(3)<n>t(g) (1) = 6 - 1/16 - 8+ 16 x 			(4)<n>t(g)(1) = 6- 16x+ 8 (16x+8=32; 32-8=24; 24-8=16; 16-8=8)<n><n>T(f)(t) = 6-t4+16x<n>t(f) (t)=6(t^4-16x+8)=6*(t^4-(-x-8))<n><n>Maximum value of g is the max of 24 when f(x) =-x2 - 8<n><n>Maximum value when g(x) = 24 when f (x)=-x2 - 16<n>```<n>### Response:C<n>```<n>Why?: 16x -8 = 32 - 8 = 24 <n>```<n>### Answer:B

Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n><n>### Response:		A: open meadow<n><n>### Reponse:B: arctic tundras<n><n>### Repsonse:D: great outdoors,England<n><n>### A:open meadow<n><n>##  D:great outdoors, England<n><n>### B: Arctic tundra<n><n>### C: Beaches<n><n>###  E: England<n>### Explanation:<n>A means "open meadow" which is not an answer for this task..<n><n>### B means "arctic tundra"<n><n>### C means "beaches"<n><n>### E means "England"<n><n>- C means "beaches", "england" is a choice but not answer<n>- D means "great outdoors"<n><n>### Explanaton:<n>1. arctic tundras are arctic<n>2. open meadows are wide grasslands<n>3. D means "great"<n><n>### A means "open meadows" which is not a valid choice for the answer<n><n>### D means "great", so England is the appropriate answer.<n><n>- C means beach<n>`The explanation of the last question will not cover that the answers will be C and D will be given`<n><n>## Explanation:<n>1. A: open meadow, C: beaches<n>2. D: great outdoore(s), England<n><n>### Explnation:<n>D: great outdoore, England<n><n>D: great outdoor(s), England<n>

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What cuisine is joked about eating small dogs? Choices:  A: backpack B: dog show C: chinese food D: french E: good hands<n><n>### Response:		<n>You should select D: French cuisine is jipped about eating small dogs.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The rowdy frat boys shouted they would have fun and do what tonight? Choices:  A: do enjoy B: get laid C: enjoyable D: work less E: enjoy living<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In the following multiple-choice question, choose the best response to each blank.<n>Input: The rowdy frat boys shout<n>"we'll do what tonight" tonight, we'll enjoy ourselves.<n>### Answer:<n>we enjoy<n>### <n>### Input:How many miles from Wichita Falls to Odessa, Texas, was a distance of 267 miles? Choices: a: 54 miles b: 30 miles c: 267 miles d: 321 miles e: 11 miles<n>### Questionnaire Input: We drove 267 miles. My friend drove part of the route and then I drove the rest of the route. My friend drove 341 miles ÷ 35 = 10 mi/hr My brother told me that he drove 267 – (267 × 0.8 )= 212 miles at 66 mi/hr. Finally, I drove 321-212=109 mils at 43 mi/hr <n>### Questionnaire: How much did I drive at 43 mi per hour ( mph 1 mi/hr = 1.61 km/hr)?<n>### Input:<n>### Answer: 52.2 km<n>### <n><n>### Dem:<n>Input:A new school<n>has 1270 students. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The master control for the Tardis is where in the main room? How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What often happens after a long day of traveling? Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		<n>You are correct if you chose "C: relocation" because jet lag is often the result of relocation.  However, "Jet lag" and "relocation" are not on the list choices.<n>#### Explanations:<n>You are correct because of the information "sickness" in the question statement.<n>The correct answer for Explanation A is "D: jet lag"because it mentions "relocation".<n>The correct answer for E is "A: sickness" because it is the only one that does not have "relocation" or "Jet Lag" as a subset.<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>You are correct answer for "Explanation AB" is "C: relocation".<n><n>#### Explanations A:<n>When you have two questions with "movement" and then "purchase" as an answer, you know that it is not A.<n><n>**Explanation CD**:<n><n>If you have "movement" and "purchase" listed, you know to eliminate them first and use the other two as a guide. The other two choices are "Jet lag" is the result of relocation and "Motion sickness" is a result of movement.  Therefore, "Motion sickness is the result of relocating".<n><n>If you have an answer that you believe is wrong but there is a word that is the same between the two, cross it off immediately with your response and then do a word study to make sure.<n>If there is a word that you feel might be a correct answer, then do a word study.<n>#### Explanation DC:<n>If you have a word that is the "same" or a synonym as between the two, it may not be a correct answer but can be used as a guide during your word study.<n><n>#### Examples Questions(Multiple Choice):<n>You can eliminate a lot of the words that are not on the list and then do a word analysis with the words that are on the list.<n><n>### **Question 1**:<n>The best answer is "D: Jet lag".  The first line in the question asks if " _often happens_ " after a long day of travelling and the second line talks about "the results of relocation" which is a synonym for Jet Lag.<n><n>### Qsution 2**:<n>For Question 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The color yellow is associated with the opposite of the characteristic, what is it? Choices:  A: fearless B: english carrier C: courageous D: brave E: achromatic<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is B= BRAVE<n>

How many pupae are in a colony?<n>2. How many worker-ants are in an anthill?<n>3. How many fire-ants live in a cave?<n><n>### Questions:<n><n>1 |Term|Answer|<n>------|:---:|:----:|  <n>1 |how many pupae are in an anthill|2000<n><n>1 |how many egg-laying worker–ants are in a colony|3,400<n>2 |What type of ant lives underground?|Mole ant<n><n>2 |how many white ant live in an ant farm?|200<n><n>3 |How many adult workers are in a colony of white, or gossamer ants?|400<n><n>3| How many pupae are under a house?|500<n><n>4 |Which term doesn't relate to ants?|A. How many fire-ant pupae|How many fire-ants fire.<n><n>Answers:<n><n>1. | How many pupae are there in a colony?| 200<n><n>2 |How many pupae do ant-farms have?| 250<n><n>3 |how many pupae live underground| 320<n><n>4 |there are 35 ants living in a cave|590<n><n>#### 2000<n>Answer: 2000

Choices:  A: joke B: humor C: frightened D: fight E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		The only choice that is not an adjective is the one that involves a laugh. A joke is an action where a person does something in a way that is comical. When a person is frightened and it is not planned, it is unexpected. A fight is something that does not have much laughter or excitement. The correct answer choice is laughter.<n><n>### Test your understanding:<n>```python<n><n>a = "dog cat cow" <n>b = "cat cow dog"<n>c = a[::-1] <n>d = "dog cat cow".split()<n>e = 3<n>f = "dog cow cat"<n>print(a[:e])<n><n>```<n>

Choices: A: Subtract B: Add C: Rearrange D: Shift<n><n>### Response<n><n>The best choice that can be a solution is C.<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Explained Request:<n><n>Input: How many times does 1 go into 20? Choices: A B: 4 C: 10<n><n>### Response <n><n>The only choices available in the request are A, B and C.<n><n>Since C means to do the same thing again.<n><n>Therefore, the numbers 100 and 20 have the same factors.<n><n>#### C <n><n>Answer: C<n>

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What gets rid of a mundane routine? Choices:  A: sophisticated B: imprevist C: arcane D: heavenly E: new<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n>Correct response: The root word imprevist, from this stem imprevisto means a suddenly expected and unforeseeable event.<n><n>### Input<n>#### Answer:<n><n>- What gets rid of a mun-daune  routine?<n>- C<n>- Imprevisto:<n>  - [suddenly expected event](http://dictionary.cambridge.org/de/worterbuch/englisch/impromptu)<n><n>- What gets used for decorating? Choices: A: ornamentation B: color C: style D: taste E: grip<n><n>- C<n>- Correct response: The root word decor, from this stem decorre means the act or art of embellishing<n><n>- What happens if an insect gets into a dormant plant? Choices: A B C: D E: F<n><n>- B<n>- Correct response: [Dormancy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dormancy_(botany)) is the state of inactivity, in a suspended state of metabolic activity<n><n>- What happens to our perception of time as we get older? Choices: A. slows B. speeds C: D E: None of the above<n><n>- C<n><n>#### Correct response: Time slows down, the older you are. [Scientific American](http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/do-the-years-go-faster-as-you-grow-older)<n><n>### Input What gets into the pond without a splash or ripple? Choices: A) duck B) beaver C) whale D) fish E: frog<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:David hurt all over. Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>| Choice | Rationales/Explanation | Answer|<n>| ------- | ----------------------------  | ----- |<n>| A question |If the reference questioned then the attempted confirmation would fail. |  |<n>| B  | If the reference dispute that would fail.  |  | <n>| C  | If the reference denied it would fail too.  |  |<n>|  D | If the reference contradicted it also would fail |  |<n>| D question  | If the reference contradict then it would also fail.  | 4 |<n><n>### Instruption:<n><n>```<n>Write a response that appropriately fulfills the request.<n>```<n><n><n>### Input | Rationales | Answer|  <n>####| Question|<n>I need help with this sentence:<n><n>I went to the store today and bought a 3-pound bag of flour and a two gallon jug of milk.<n>### Write: A complete sentence that properly uses each underlined word or phrase.<n>####|Write a sentence that includes your own thoughts:<n><n>I went into the store and bought a 3 lb bag of flour and two gallon jug of mikl.<n>##Input<n>An attempt to confirm an app. ref. would fail if the ref does what?<n>| | |<n>|:---:|:---:|<n>| (A) Question | Question |  |<n>| (B) Dispute | Dispute |  |<n>|   (C) Deny | Deny |  |<n>|     (D) Contradict | Contradict |  |<n>|    (E) Refuse Refuse | Refuse |  |<n><n><n>### Demostration: <n><n>Answer:<n>| | |<n>:---:|:--:|<n>|(A) Question |(B) Dispute|<n>|(B) Disputr |(A) Question|<n>|(C) Deny |(A) Question, (B) Disputr|<n>	|(D) Contradict|(A) Question,  (B) Disput, (C) Deny|<n>	|(A) Question, (B) Disputt |(A) Question,  (B) Disuptt, (C) Den, (D) Contrad

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where is a microphone boom likely to be covering a stock market event? Choices:  A: new york B: concert C: tv studio D: gig E: recording studio<n><n>### Response:		(A):new york<n><n>### Input:"The 1234567890" problem is used in the programming language Python."true" or "false"<n><n>### Response:(False)<n><n>### Input"Find the solution to the equation 3x + 7 = 7x + 8.<n><n>### Response(3x + 7 – 7x + 6 = – 3x + 1)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input:A basketball team scores 256 points in 127 minutes. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. If the size of the last box is 348 cubic inches, how large could each box be, in cubic inches, before the store is charged an extra $1000 in carrying cost?<n><n>### Solution 348 * 2 = 696 and 696 + 1000 = 1696<n><n>#### 1696

Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Correct answer:** Sally was a senior in high school.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Sally could be a member of a high school or college since she was a senior in high<n>school.  She could also be a member of an assisted living facility since she could<n>have been living in assisted living until her death.  She could also  be a<n>member of an old people's home if she was working in one.  Sally could be a<n>member of the republican party or organization since she passed on her rights to<n>be a member of these organizations to one of her great grandsons and left a book<n>about it.  She could not be in college anymore since she died in<n>1958. [HINT: Sally died in 1958 - so anything prior to that date cannot be<n>accurate - a college student is unlikely to be in the year 1958]<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Correct answer: House<n><n>### Input<n>We have a pile with 20 wooden blocks with a total of 21 pieces. How many pieces are in 15 of the blocks?<n>### Response: 17<n><n>### Rationale: We need to find 15 from 20. We can do that in 2 ways: 20\*20\*21 - 15; 20*\*15. We can also say: 15/20. This is like saying that we have 20 pieces, and we also have 15 - like we have 15 blocks out of the original 20 blocks. By taking 15 blocks out we are down 5 blocks - so we have 15 - 5 which is 10 pieces left over. <n>Correct answer: 15

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>John will end up in Oklahoma if he doesn’t stop.<n>### Rational:<n>If John lives in Texas and chooses A then he should land in Oklahoma.<n><n><n>### Input1: How many pennies are in 16 dollars? Choices: A: 16 B: 10 C: 15 D: 12 Answer: C<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Let us assume 20 cents is made up of 5 pennies.<n>If we have 16 dollars we need 16/20<n>which will result 8 dollars in 20 cents.This means we need 8 dollars<n><n>### Input2: A car is traveling along a road where the speed limit is 55. It takes 15 seconds to travel a mile, and it moves 63 miles on a tank of gas. What is the fuel efficiency of the car (round to the nearest mile per gallon)? Choices: A: over 47 mpg B: over 30 mpg C: over 20 mpg D: under 17 mpg Answer: C<n><n><n>### Rrationales:<n>speed of a car/distance travelled = (speed of a car/1 mile) * 55 = 8.5 miless per hour<n><n>8.5 hours * 1h = 8.5 miles ->distance travelled in 1 hour<n>A car travels 15 sec per mile -><n><n>1 hr * 15 sec = 3 sec/mi ->distance travelled in1 minute<n><n><n>(3 sec/mi ) * 55 = (3sec/mi)/55 =(0.55 mile/mi )/55 = 0.0101mile/min<n>which yields 1 mile per minute or 60 mi/h<n><n>If the milleage is say 60 mi/ h then the distance travelled in 1 gallon <n><n>= (60/1 mi)/gal = 60/1 gal= 60 gallon<n><n>16*64 * 0.101<n>= 9.65<n>```<n><n>### Input3: The sum of 7 consecutive even numbers is 74. What numbers are in this sequence?

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What happens to the next appointment when a grooming takes longer than expected? Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>Rationales: Choices A,B, and C: a grooming takes longer does not mean something serious happened.<n>The appointment will be cancelled, but the groomer still has to cancel that grooming.<n>Choice D means people could be annoyed because another grooming had been cancelled.<n>But the groomer will still be in his room.<n>It is impossible that choice Choice E: means nothing at all.<n>Since "Injury" and "cancelling" would disturb the groomer, or make the groomer late to another appointment.

Read the steps provided. Write a response that explains how to solve the problem.<n><n>**Input:** Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda. Marcia has 6 more cards than Janet. How many more cards than Brenda does Marcia have?<n><n>```<n>Steps:<n>Write an expression to represent each step.<n>Write a rule to express each operation.<n><n>1.	First, Janet has 5 more cards than Brenda so 5 must go into 12 (divide).<n>2.	Second, so Janet has 9 (remember 12 = 9 + 3, 13 = 10 + 2, 14 = 11 + 1, 15 = 12 + 0), more cards than Brenda and Brenda has 5 more cards so Brenda must have 5 + 5 = 10 more cards, so 10 goes into 12 (remember 15 = 9 + 6), so 12 - 10 = 2.<n>```<n><n>### Response First, Janet has 9 + 5 = 9 + (5 + 5) = 14, more cards than Brenda<n><n>Second, so Brenda has (9 + 5) + (14 - 9) = 6 + 5 = <n>```<n><n>## Answer<n><n>### Instructions: Answer all questions.<n><n>### Multiple-Choice:<n><n>### 1. Choices:  A: work hard B: slow down C: wear shoes D: sell products E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Input: Ali will not bump into you if he slows down <<Work Hard>> while walking.<n>However, he might bump into a person, place, or thing while walking <<Sell products>>.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: <n><n>### Input::<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: John has 60 pounds of potatoes. Ann has 80 pounds of potatoes, and Sue has 40 pounds of potatoes less than Ann. How much potatoes does John have in all, if Sue weighs 57 pounds?<n>Rationales:: Sue weighs 40 pounds less than Ann <<Less Than>>,<n>John has 60 pounds fewer potatoes than Sue <<Fewer Thant>>,<n>Ann has 80 pounds less than John <<Fewer Than>>,<n>Thus, for the given information, Ann has 30 pounds of potatoes more than John <<More than>>.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demosation<n>Input: Pete's cereal costs 44 cents a box. He buys 54 boxes and pays $24.50. If the tax is 13 cents per box, what is the tax?<n>Rationales : The tax is 54 times 0.13 cents <<10*0.13=1.30>> = 1.30 cents.<n><n>#### 1.30<n>Answer:<n>### Input<n>### Demosations<n>Input: John has a collection of 58 old pennies and 56 nickles. One hundred twenty three old quarters are in the whole collection. How many dimes, half dimes, and cents are in the whole?<n>Rationales :: A dime is the equivalent of 10 quarters and 100 cents. << 1000+1=1001>><n>Hence, there are no cents, half cents, or dime<n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the question.<n><n>## Demonstration: Write the 0-2 digit integer in different words.<n>Input: 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What do people do to pass time before they can use electronics when fly in airplane? The sun never rises is the meaning.<n>(2)<n>The sun always rises every morning, it always goes down for every day. The person who lives in the triangle house is more interesting than the 73 boring people who live in square houses.<n><n>### Input<n>The sum of the digits in a number N = 89 is?(A) 17 (B) 27 (C) 45( (D) 74(E) 15<n><n>### Response<n><n>A-17 <n><n>### Reason<n>If n is 1st digit of any number, then number N's sum of digits is: <n>(1 x 2^n )+  (2 x 2^n-1...nth term)<n><n>### Input : A large group is to be divided into 20 rooms, all of which must contain either an odd number of people or an even number of people. What is the maximum total number of people who could fit in less than 20 rooms?<n><n>### Response : 20<n><n>### Reasons<n><n>- If there are 19 people in the group, then all of them are odd, or all of them are even.<n><n>Therefore, all of them can be divided into 2 rooms, both of which are either odd or even.<n>This can be done by assigning the even numbered rooms (or their occupants) to even<n>numbers, and putting the odd numbered rooms (or occupants) in the odd numbered rooms. Then,<n>putting everyone in a room would be the same as putting them into 2 rooms. Therefore, if there are 19<n>people in the group, all of them can fit in 2 rooms. In short, if there are 20 people in the group, all<n>of them are odd, or odd and any even numbers, or even and any odd numbers. Each can fit in 2<n>rooms, making 20 people fit into 20 rooms.<n><n>- Otherwise, if there are 8 people then all of them are inevitably odd or even.<n>In this case, divide 8 into 2 and add 1 to keep any uneven room. If there are

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The child really wanted to teach his grandpa to read, he thought it was wrong that he had spent his whole life what? Choices:  A: ignore B: write C: learn new things D: illiterate E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>A) is correct.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input:{Mike and Jen both earned $20,000 in 2017. Jen earned $15,000 more than Mike in 2016. In 2019, Jen earned $3,000 less than Mike, but she earned $25,000. How much money does Jen earn in 2019?}?<n><n>### Response:{Mike and Jen were paid $20,050 in 20017. Jen was paid $15,050 more than Mike in the previous year.In 2019. Jen was paid $3,050 less than Mike, though she earned $25.000.Her total payment in2019 was $27,050.}<n><n>### Instructions:This question is about the above example.<n><n>### Write a response that appropriatelly completes the request.Input The cost of the item is $300.What fraction of the price is $100?<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>### Input1:<n>155 - 2 =153<n><n>### Input2:<n>A circle has a radius of 90. What is the circumference?<n><n>### Rationale1:<n>C = 2pr=2*36=72<n><n>### Rationales2:<n>C=2×3.14r=2×3.27=6.54<n><n>### Input3:<n><n>How many ounces of apple are there?<n><n>### Input4:<n><n>What is 10+4(10×10)÷10?<n><n>Rationale:<n><n>### Instructons:Write a response that appropriatley completes the request by using an appropriatly chosen rational(s).<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would a person expect if they are competent in their school work? Choices:  A: compliments B: passing grade C: intellectual challenge D: sticker E: avoid pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>Competency leads to accomplishing something. Therefore a person can expect to receive a passing grade, compliments, and intellectual challenge.<n><n>### Input<n>How would a person know that someone is incompetent in their job? There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: chemist's shop C: kitchen D: drug store E: bedroom<n><n>### Response:		You would store birth control pills in your medicine cabinet.<n><n>#### 1) A<n>#### 2) C<n>#### 3) B<n>#### 4) C<n>#### 5) D<n>#### 6) E<n>#### 7) A<n>#### 8) C<n>#### 9) A<n>#### 10) B<n><n>### Input Answers: medicine cabinet|bedroom, kitchen|bedroom, chemist's shop|bedroom, drug store|bedroom, bedroom|chemist's shop, chemist's<n><n>### Solution:<n>The bedroom has three options, namely C, B and A.<n>The chemist’s shop is A.<n>The kitchen is B, and the toothpaste was selected from the kitchen which means that the kitchen should not be answered for the fourth time. That means that if the bedroom was selected as the first option, then it will also be selected as the fourth option since only three options are available and the bedroom will be chosen.<n><n>### Input;<n>1) Mary left her house, and she walked 2 miles, then she biked 4 miles, and she finally drove 12 miles, so what is the total mileage that Mary traveled?<n><n>2) Mary walked to the post office and sent a package by air mail, and she needed 4 stamps (and she had 5 more stamps than she needed) so what is the total number of stamps that she needed?<n><n>3) Mary counted the bottles in her inventory and she thought 16 bottles were missing, so she made a list of them, and the list included 4 more bottles than Mary counted, so what was the last bottle in her inventory?<n><n>#### 11<n><n>### Input answers;10|16|14<n><n>#### 6|5|4<n><n>### Input Input answers;6|4<n><n>## Input Input answers;7|5<n><n>### Output;5<n><n>## Input;<n>4.5 gallons  of coffee were divided among eighteen  thermoses so that  genevive drank  three thermoses, and she drank 3 gallons, so what did genevive drink?<n><n>Answer: <<3>>3 gallons<n><n><n>

Is more money necessary for the state to adequately provide education for its citizens?<n><n>In conclusion, there are many students who are eligibile to be accepted to college but are not being admitted because of the rising prices of college tuition. <n>The increase in tuition should be stopped and the proper resources should be given to each institution to have a sufficient amount of money to be used on their students. <n>If the prices aren't controlled then students will be forced to drop out before finishing their major or simply not go to college at all when they could have been able to graduate and enjoy a better quality and more successful futures.<n><n>####2.
