Choices: <n>A: Have a majority vote done by the governor, the house speaker and the house and senate leaders each year <n>B: Create an even split on taxes between residents with lower income, mid-income and upper income<n>C: Allow any state agency to develop its budget without restrictions<n>D: Create a committee made up of equal numbers of members of all 4 houses of the legislature <n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n>The 5th grade class at your school is having an environmental project on endangered animals. <n>The class is interested in finding out the habits of these animals and raising awareness <n>of the public so that their habitat can be protected. <n>What species should the students choose to study? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a place to eat and places to buy items of many different kinds? Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		<n>Downtown. The shopping center is a part of downtown.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Below is an instruction that asks a "How Many" question. E: 16<n><n>### Rationales: There are twelve months in a year.<n>```<n><math>answer(months)=\frac{year}{\# months}==4.5\%</math><n>```<n>####  A: 12<n><n>### Input - What is the sum of the number and the number 36? Choicess: A: 8 B: 10 C: 11 D: 12 E: 13<n><n>### Dem: The number 4 has no letters in it<n><n>### Rationales: 6 + 2 = 8 there are no letters in 8<n>#### A: 8<n><n>### Dem Rationales: The number 9 is composed of 7 and 2 The sum of 7 and 9 is 16<n><n>#### B: 16<n>#### C: 19<n><n>### DemRationales: The number that comes after 322 is 324<n><n>#### 324<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is the result of instituting civil action? Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales: A, Bad feelings<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question:<n><n>### Instructor:<n>1. Choices:  A: fall asleep B: headache C: boredom D: relaxation E: sick<n><n>### Response:		I feel relaxed when I go to the opera<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Rationales:<n><n>The given expression does not have a solution as an integer, as<n><n>`5 ×     + 8   8`<n><n>`5 × (3) + 8 8`<n><n>5 × 3   5<n><n>has been obtained as a quotient.<n><n>##### The equation with 3 in x position can be expressed as 5 + 8 over  x .<n><n>The quotient for `5 + 8 8= `5+(8/8)= `5+1=`6`.<n><n>### So,  6  is the missing integer.<n><n>#### Input:2x - 2y = 1<n><n>#### Rationales:<n>As y = 2x, this must be true.<n><n>y/x = -1<n><n>Multiply 2 and -1 together.<n><n>The result is a negative.<n><n> 2×-1  = `1/2`<n><n>Since `1/2` represents negative 2/2, the given equation can be written as 2(-2) = 1.<n><n>#### `2(-2) =1`<n><n>Therefore, x = 1 since x is positive and 4 is positive.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer:1<n><n>#### Input:The product of three consecutive integers is 250. What are the integers?<n>#### Rationales<n><n><n><n><n>### Answer:<n><n><n><n>#### Input:Given that 9 is subtracted from a positive integer and the result is 80 more than the subtracter, what is the subtracter?<n><n>#### Rationaleses<n><n>Multiply one by the negative.<n><n>Multiply the result by the number that is negative.<n><n>Negate the result by taking the negative.<n><n>So,<n><n>`-9*(-1) = 9-9 = 0`<n><n>Since the answer is positive, the number is positive.<n><n>And,<n><n>`80+0 = 80`<n><n>The result is 80.

The first house is 1 block away on the right. The second house is 5 blocks away on the left. Which house is closer to the grocery story, the first one or the second one?<n><n>### Response <n><n> 1 Block - 5 Blocks=<<1 Block-5 Blocks=4 Blocks>><n><n>The first house is 4 blocks away and the second house is 5, so the second house is closer.    <n><n>### Input  <n><n>A number is 6 more than is predecessor. What is the product of the predecessor of 2450?<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>The predecessors of 2455 are 2450,2445,24...3....  <n><n>The predecessor of 3 is 2 so the predecessor of the number 2450 is 2 times 2 = 4.<n>Thus, The product of the predecessors of 4 to 6 is  4!  4!  5!  6!    so the answer should be 2450^6<n><n>### Answer 2450!<n><n>### Input    <n><n><n><n>### Rationales<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Input   <n><n>How many blocks to the right of 56 are 30? <n><n>### Rationals  <n><n>30 to the right of 2 = 30-10 = 20 blocks<n>30 to the left of 2 = 20 blocks  <n><n>30-30 = 0 blocks  <n><n>### Answer    <n><n>### Instructions: Choose the correct response. <n><n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What happens to people when they do not have enough food? Choices:  A: eat fish B: they steal C: talk to each other D: write stories E: die of starvation<n><n>### Response:		<n>B, D<n>#### A D<n>Answer: D, E<n><n>#### B A<n>Answer: A, D<n><n>###<n>Input: Janice collected 10 coins to give to the lemonade stand. She put away 5 quarters, 4 dimes, and 1 nickel. How many coins did Janice have altogether?<n>#### 6<n><n>Answer: 6

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What state shaped like a glove has a lot of farmland? Choices:  A: countryside B: farming areas C: michigan D: texas E: north dakota<n><n>### Response:		A:Countryside<n><n>### Input;The most important part of a skyscraper is at the core because the weight of the building is supported by it. Which part of a skyscapper is the core?<n><n>### Response;A:The bottom of the skyrscaper is the core.<n><n>### Input :How do you solve 26+22?<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>### Response : A.Add together 26 and 22<n><n>### Input A new state was established on March 4, 1859. Which state was it? Choices:A: Kansas B: Nebraska C: Indiana D: New Mexico E: New York<n><n>### Response A:Kansas<n><n>### Input In the diagram below, how many lines of symmetry are there, beginning at the vertical line? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If you harm property after starting a fire where are you likely to end up? Choices:  A: damage B: going to jail C: going to school D: burns E: destruction<n><n>### Response:		<n>*Answer A*<n><n>### Demostration:<n>#### Tanya sets fire to her room. She damages furniture and clothing, but does not injure herself. <n>Rationales: Tanya is likely to end up in jail or burn, or at least be destroyed if she gets hurt.<n><n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. Choices:  A: amount to nothing B: visit relatives C: charming D: doctor himself E: cross street<n><n>### Response:		I would say, D<n><n>### Instruct to Choose one of the four options that correctly match each of the following questions and statements. Explain your reasoning using mathematical or scientific notation.<n><n>### Input<n>  A: The speed of the wind is 3 miles an hour. B. The speed of light is three and a half miles per hour. C: The speed of light is 62340 kph D: The speed of speed limit is 25 miles per hour.<n> <n>### Response<n>For the first option, the speed of any object can be described by v = d/t, meaning that you take the total distance traveled over the total time this distance is traveled. From the equation, we know that v = d/t.<n>For the second option, the speed of light can be described the same way. When describing the speed of light, we are simply taking the total distance that light can travel over the time a single light ray covers that distance. So, the speed of light = d/t = light years per second For the third option, the speed limit can also be represented by v = d/T, meaning that you take a specific distance and then multiply that distance by the time it takes to complete that distance at a rate of travel. From the equation, you can see that v =d/t, but here, you have substituted miles/hour for t, since the speed limit refers to vehicles traveling at this speed. When describing the speed limit, the distance is taken is a single mile, meaning that the speed limit = d/t = miles traveled per hour<n><n>### Input A: how many minutes in a year B: how many miles in a year<n><n>### Response A: 60 minutes in a year<n><n>B: 525,600 miles in a year<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would a restaurant put a candle? There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:where do you store wine? Choices:  A: attic B: basement C: art show D: church E: bar<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input: I store it in my bar.<n> <n>### Instruction 51:<n><n>### Description:<n><n>Add a second step to your initial instruction.<n><n>### Exemplar Step Two:<n>Mary was given money to buy groceries at the store. She needs to buy 10 pounds of carrots costing $1 each, 11 pounds of onions costing $1.25 each, and 5 pounds of pineapple costing $2.50 each. How much money does she have to spend?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Your task is to modify this step and add it to the initial step. Be prepared to defend your response.<n><n>### Input for Step 2:<n>Mary was also given $20 to buy $100 pounds of groceries. How much money does Mary have left?<n><n>### Step 3<n>Mary is not going to get her $4 discount on her toilet paper. She must pay the listed price of $4 for 20 pounds.<n><n>### Step Description:<n><n>Add at least one variable in order to make the task easier to complete.<n><n>### Rationales and Exemplar Step 3:<n>An easier approach is to use a $4 discount to 100 pounds of toilet paper to make it easier to add $20 to buy other items.<n><n>### Initial Step:<n>Initial Step: Mary needs to buy food for dinner. She has $4.25, and has to spend at least $3.24 to meet her total. She has $0.75 in change.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>Input: Mary has $5 to spend on fruits and vegetables. How much money does her receipt list for her peach, cucumber, zucchini, spinach, and bell pepper at $3.99 each?<n><n>### Output Rationale:<n>Mary pays $21.83<n><n>### Output Exemplar:<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Input 52.<n><n>### Task<n><n>Write a step instruction.<n><n>## Task Criteria<n><n>-The step has one or more than one solution.<n><n>-The step involves mathematical operations, counting, and logical reasoning.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:A person with children might have a lot of plastic things in what place? Choices:  A: cupboard B: cabinet C: own home D: everything E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		<n>Correct answer:<n><n>#### A or B or C<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>#### Input:The answer to the multiplication problem is 75.<n><n>#### Response:<n>Select the statement that correctly states the answer to the multiplication problem.<n>#### 75<n>Answer: 75<n><n>#### Input:Katy had a box of chocolates, which weighed 5 pounds. She had three bags of chocolate. One weighed 6 pounds, the second bag weighed 4 pounds, and the third bag weighed 7 pounds. How much did the box of chocolat weigh?<n><n>#### Response:Select the statement that correctly identifies the answer.<n><n>#### 12 pounds<n>Answer: 12 pounds<n><n>#### Input:A car traveled ___ miles per hour during its trip.<n><n>#### Response<n>Select the statement that shows how many miles the car traveled.<n><n>#### 250<n>Answer:250 miles<n><n>#### Input:Cody has 45 fish in his aquarium. He has 2 fish in each tank and two tanks in the aquarium. How many tanks does Cody have in his aquarium?<n>#### Response:Select one answer that correctly answers the question.<n><n>#### 50 tanks<n>Answer:50 tanks<n><n>#### Input:Six times 16 equals ___<n>#### Response:Select all the answer choices that represent the equation six times 16 equals 96.<n>#### 96<n>Answer:96<n><n>#### Input:Two times three equals ___<n>#### Responses:Select all the answer answers that represent the equation two times three equals 6.<n><n>#### 6<n><n>#### Answer:6<n><n>```<n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:A bride and groom are taking care of proposals, what is the likely ceremony? It is the results of my hunger strike today before writing this instruction and when I did the above tasks.<n><n>### Input<n>Which is the correct number sentence for 3 × 5? A. 3 ÷ 5 B. 3 ÷5 C. 5 - 3 D. 52 4<n><n>### Response<n>A. 3 ÷ (5 × 1)<n><n>### Explaniations<n>Divide both sides by 5, result 1.<n><n>Divide both sides the other side, result:  3 ÷ 5 =  6<n><n>Hence, answer A.<n><n>### Question 6<n><n>##|<n>What is the smallest positive integer whose square root is in the range of 30 and 35?  <n>A. 8 B. 9 C. 10 D. 11<n><n>### Response <n>D. 11<n>D.<n><n>### Explantations<n>Closest to the square root of 34 is 11, which gives a range of 11 to 18. The square root to 35 is 5, which is between 11 and 18. The root of 37 is 5.29 and the root of 36 is 5.14, which are both greater than 5, which means the square root of 40 is bigger than 11, which means the answer is D.<n><n>### Answer 5<n><n>### Question<n>Which of the following is true: 32 - 4 = 26    <n>A) 4 is an even integer.  <n>B) 26 is a multiple of 8.  <n>C) 26 is even.  <n>D) All of the above.<n><n>### Response      <n>B. 26 is a multiply of 8.<n><n>### EXPLANATION<n>26/4 = 6 and 6 is even.<n><n>### 2<n><n>### Question    <n>Which is the largest positive integer whose square root can be written in the form n^(1/2)?  <n>A. 26 B.

Choices: A 6 B 30 C 18 D 20 E 15<n><n>### Response E = 15<n><n># Output<n><n>### Output4 is a multiple of 2, 3, and 7. How many times can the number 4 go into 262? Choices: A The number is even. C 2<n><n>### Demstoration<n>A * 4 = 8<n>B * 4 = 12<n>C - 4 = 2<n><n>## Expected Output<n>5 A The number is even..<n><n>### Demstration<n>4 even number: 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, 256......<n><n>#### 262 --> 64<n><n>#### 4 * 64 = 256<n><n>#### 256 / 4 = 64<n><n># Input<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instructions and Demonstrations<n><n>How many students can attend a birthday party if there are only 48 seats?<n>Idem: 48/4 = 12 (4 seats/kids)<n><n>## Output<n>Answer: B: 36 (4 times as many - and they will fit on the bus!)<n><n>### Demosration<n>1 = 1 - 4 seats<n>2 = 2 - 4 seats<n>4 = 4 - 4 seats<n>6= 6-4 seats<n>#### 48 / 4 = 13 (36/13)<n><n>### Expected Output<n>The answer is 48 kids can not fit on the bus<n><n># Expected Output<n><n>B: 36 (or 4 times
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The boy was too nervous to dance, so what was he doing progressively at the ball? Choices:  A: dance like crazy B: standing still C: wallflower D: stand still E: like dancing<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>#### A: dance like craxy<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the best response to the questions.<n><n>Demonstration:<n><n>Input: Choose the best response to: The boy was too nervous 135. to dance, 135. so what was he 135. doing 135. progressively at 135. the ball? 135. Choices: 135. A: dance like craazy 135. B: standing still 135. C: wallflower 135. D: stand still 135 E: like dancing 135.<n><n>### Rationales: Since the boy was too nervous and had a hard time dancing, he was doing wallflower 123. since he didn't dance or stand still.<n><n>Answer: <n><n>#### B <n><n>### Instructuion: <n><n>Demonstratiotn:<n><n>Input: The man got up, walked up the stairs, opened the door to his apartment, and walked in<n>Rationales: Get up = to get up<n>Walk up = to walk up the stairs<n>Opened the door to his apertment = to open the door to his apretment<n>Walked in = to walk in<n><n>#### <n><n>I understand that. It's been too long<n><n>#### I<n><n>### Input 2. If a car has a speedometer that measures speeds of 1 hour, 2 hours, 5 hours, 7 hours, and 8 hours, 3. how many 4 mins. would it take to measure 14 hrs. 7 6 mins. 38 secs, and 5 mins.? _____________________ A : minutes and 58 secs B : mins C : secs D : mins And 2 secs E: mins and 7 secs<n><n>### A:<n><n>Mins MinSecs<n><n>#### <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What does someone living life fully feel? Choices:  A: joy B: valuable C: happiness D: early death E: adventurous<n><n>### Response:		Included within the answer are all of the choices from the question.<n><n>#### B: Valuable<n><n>### Input<n><n>Liam bought two 1.5 liter bottles of water. He ate two bananas. He had 5 apples left. He had 17 grapes in all. How many of each fruit did he buy?<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>1.5 = <<1.5=10>>10 bottles<n><n>Liam bought:<n>bananas = 2 + 2 = <<2+2=4>>4<n><n>Apples = 2 × 5 = <<2*5=10>><n><n>Grapes = 2 × 17 = <<2*17=34>><n><n>Liam bought 10 bottles and had 4  +  10  +  34 = <<10+4+34=54>>54 grapes.<n><n>Liam bought all the food.

How old is Jo?<n><n>### Input <n>### A: I  B: II  C: III  D: IV  E: V<n>### A:15  B:17  C:19  D:23  E:25<n><n>### III<n><n>### 25<n><n>## Input: What is the sum of 1 + 2 + 3 +..... + 9?<n><n>### Response Choose from A,B,C,D,E or F.<n><n>### C:2020<n><n>### Answer <n><n>### What's 59 in numerals? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Society cannot exist without numbers.   They only rise up in what sort of spaces? Choices:  A: population B: populated area C: create government D: group of people E: make person sick<n><n>### Response:		<n>1<n><n>Society cannot exist.<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input and Rationales: A student read 896 pages in 9 hours.<n><n>How many pages of the book were read in each hour? <n>Rationales:<n>1. The student read 895/9 = <<895/9=99>>99 pages in each hour. <n><n>#### 99<n>Answer: 99<n><n>### Input;<n><n>A certain country has a population of 6.5 million.<n><n>How many more people live in France than in Belgium? <n><n>### Rationales;<n>A. 6.5 million = 60 <n>times more people live in France B. 0.058 fewer/more people live in France <n><n>###<n>Rationales: Answer; B<n>#### 0.057<n>Answer: 0.05<n><n><n>

I could find the address of someone or an establishment in the city I want to visit. It is more likely that MAPS includes tourist attractions than DISTRICT. 2. I could find where to get maps. Since MAPS is much more inclusive than DISTRICT, it would be easy to assume that MAPS includes maps. 3. I could look at a map to see how far I have to go. This makes MAPS again more inclusive than DOSTRIFT. This is why the response should be MAPS.<n><n>#### MAPS<n>Answer: MAPS or MAP<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Demostration<n>Input: I live in Squamish, but I can’t live downtown. What should I take to go from Squamish downtown on a bus for $4.34 or less?<n>Rationales<n>The bus routes from UBC to dowtown and from downtown to Squamish should be 4 + (4.35 – 4) = 4.35 since they are equal value.<n><n>Input: A subway fare costs $3. Janet has twice as many blue toys as green toys, while Sam has twice as many red toys as blue toys. If Janet has less red toys than Sam, how many toys does Jack have?<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>Sam: green + blue + red / blue (2x) + green (2x) = 3x<n><n>Jack: blue + red (assuming blue+ red = 2nd choice) or green (assuming 5 x green < red)<n><n>So if blue and green = 6 toys, green+red = 5, blue+red = 3,<n><n>red = 2 (2x)<n><n>12 (greatest) + 5 (option 2) = 17<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>8<n><n>## Input:What does Janet have now? Choices: 1 blue, 2 blue, 3 red<n><n>## Response:<n><n>3 red<n><n>## Explanation:<n>If blue = 1 (1x), blue + blue= 2 (2x), red = (2/4) 2x = 3 (3x)<n><n>#6<n><n>## Input:(2 of 2) How many blocks does Janet have?<n><n>## Response: 2<n><n>## Explanatioin:<n><n>##100/6 = 106.67<n>##66.65<n>##116.67<n><n>#7<n><n>##Input:Janet has a bookcase with 30 books. Choices:  A: very ugly B: appear beautiful C: free slaves D: pay bills E: suffering pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Rationale:<n>C is the only correct input.<n><n>### Input<n>1. How often does a woman who is 28 years old have a birthday? Choices: A: once or twice a year B: always C: never D: on Christmas Eve<n><n>### Rationales<n>A is incorrect because a woman would never be 0 or 128. It could go from 0 to 127, but not to 0 since we are using integers.<n>B can never go to -1, so always is incorrect.<n>D can never go from -1 to 127 so never is incorrect.<n>C would require us to say the year 127 is a woman's birth year. The year 1 is not a birth year so we cannot say it is never the birth year.<n>C is 28 because the woman ages 28 years before her next birthday and will age on her birthday.<n><n>Birthdays can go from 0 to ___.<n>127 years old is an age that can be represented by an integer with a 320 value.<n><n>### Cases:<n>Input: A woman is 78 years old on her birthday. She will age one year before her next birthday. Find the minimum number of years between her birthdays.<n>Rationales: A woman is 100-78 = <<100-79>=21>>21 years old,<n>so the minimum number of years is 2.<n>127 years is an age that can represented by an integer with 320 as the base.<n><n>###Input:<n>The number of students in a high school is represented by the fraction 7/16. The number of students drops by 2/5. What is the new fraction?<n><n>###Rationales:<n>The fraction drops to 7/16 /(5/5) = <<7/16/(5/5)=(7/16)/5>>7/16 since 5/5 is 1.<n><n>Output: 9/16<n><n>### Coding:<n>1. n = 7<n>3. f = 16<n>5. d = 5<n>7. j = 0<n>9. a
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Why would someone be wet after being full of fear? Choices:  A: run B: swimming C: calculate things quickly D: fight enemy E: urinate<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Answer: E, urinating<n><n>### Rationales:<n>#### <n>Answer: E<n><n>**A:** A student ran to a nearby water fountain to avoid getting wet. He was sweaty from the effort, but remained dry.<n><n> <n>__B:__ A student ran back to his or her classroom, which was filled with water in a previous science experiment. He remained dry.<n><n><n>__C:__ A student quickly calculated the answer to a math problem based on a video from a science class. The student remained dry.<n><n>__D__: A student fought off an angry teacher with water. The student was not wet.<n><n>__E__: A student was afraid of losing a baseball competition, so he had to urinate to remove the fear.<n><n>#### <n>Answer B, D<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: There were at least 11.75 kilograms, or 25.95 pounds of food. Mara ate a little more than half so that there remained about 7.5 pounds or 3.4 kilograms of food. What is the original weight of food?<n><n>Input: 26.5 pounds of beef are added to a 27-pound beef patty. About how much more does that make the total weight?<n><n>Rationales:The original weight of food is the current weight subtracted from the current weight + the start weight = 10.4 + 15.6 = <<10.4+15.6=26>>26.<n><n>Total weight is the original weight + the weight of additional: 26 + 16= <<26+16=42>>42 pounds<n><n>#### 42<n>Answer: 42<n><n>Input: The total weight is 42.79 pounds to 61.22 pounds. The next step would be subtracting 61 from 42.7. The remaining 8.63 pounds is then divided by 22 ounces to get 0.39 pounds per ounce.<n><n>Rationales 42.7 - <61.2 - 42.7 = <<42.7-61.2-42.7=27>>2.7 to

If all three work for the same company, in what fraction of each of their salaries are they saving up to replace their parents?<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>7/10<n>```<n>### Rationale<n>Janelle's pay is 5% lower ==> 100 - 5 = <<100-5=95>>95<n>Her sister's pay is 10% higher ==<<10%=0.10; 10/10=1>>10 so it is 110<n><n>Janelle, Janet(Janelle's sister) and Jack(Janelle's Brother)<n><n>Therefore they make <110/95 =<<110/96=0.83>>0.83 less than the sum of their parent’s salaries.<n>Thus saving: <1/1.83 =<<1/1.841=0.55>>0.55% each<n><n>So the fraction is: 1-[1/0.55] = <<1-0.946>>0.06<n><n>#### 0.06<n>Answer: 0.06
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Sally took her medicine and experienced strong side effects.  What did doctors say about the side effects? Choices:  A: great B: distinguished C: remarkable D: excellent E: peculiar<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input : What would we be if we were all perfect? Choices: <n><n>-A: a bunch of idiots<n>-B: a bunch of nerds<n>-C: a bunch of clones<n><n>-D: a bunch of dorks<n>-E: a bunch of robots<n><n>### Response : C<n><n>### Input<n><n>30 students attended a computer programming contest. There were 10 more female students than male students. Twelve males and six females did not attend the contest. What percentage of students did not attend the contest?<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>The number of females students was 2 times that of male students. so, there were 2 times 10 = 20 female students.<n><n>$$\text{Number of male} \ \text{students who} \ \text{attended the} \ \text{contest}$$ $\space=20-12$<n><n>So, the percentage is<n>$$\frac{\text{Number of male students who attended the contest}}{Total number of students} \ \ \space=\frac{20-12}{40}$$<n>$$\approx \ \ \space \ \ \ \ 27%$$<n><n>#### 27%<n><n>Answer: 27%<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of foolhardy? Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n><n>### Response:		I agree that discreet is the answer here, because although it may be foolhardy at times to act without caution, it isn't the opposite.<n><n>### Input<n>Janice lives on the 25th floor of a 30-story building. In which direction did she travel in order to walk to her mother's house, located 5 streets away on the 19th floor of a 20-story building? Choices: A: upB: out C: down D: in<n><n>### Answer:It would be down the building.<n><n>---<n>Copyright (c) 2017-present, David B. Zimmermann<n><n>The contents of this document are published under the MIT License (see LICENSE.txt file in the root of the project directory)<n>### What did Mara eat for breakfast?<n><n>### <n>### Breakfast:Marla wanted to eat a healthy breakfast. After sleeping poorly, she was too tired to cook, so she decided to eat cereal for breakfast. At the store, she selected 1 bag of apple cinnamon cereal, 3 bags of raisin bran cereal, and 6 bags of chocolate donut bites cereal. She was trying to eat at least 2 bags of each variety, since they had different amounts of fat, sugar, and protein. How many grams of fat, sugar, or protein does Marla's breakfast contain if she eats her preferred number of servings containing 32 grams of fat, 10 teaspoons of sugar, and 32 grams protein each?<n><n>### Rationales: Fiber is not included in this problem.<n><n>---<n>>Fiber:Fiber doesn't have any calories. But it is important to eat foods with lots of fiber because it helps the digestive system.<n><n>### Apple cinnamon cocoa krispies contains 4g of fiber per serving.<n>1g of fat 8g of sugar: Marla has 32g fat, 10 tbsp sugar, and 30g of protein.<n>So 3 bags would contain 99 grams of fat,150g sugar, and 90
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Fire houses, military bases, and police departments often have hydrants near and underground tanks for fire trucks.<n>Bus stops, apartments, and schools have hydrants for the community.<n>Water comes in on fire trucks to fire fights, and water flows out from bus stops.<n><n>### Input The city is having a construction competition. Choices:  A. Build a playground for public schools. B. Build a library. C. Build a fire station. D. Build a park. E. Build a homeless shelter.<n><n>### Response<n><n>C<n><n>### Explnation<n>Fire stations, police departments, bus stops, and apartments need hydrants because fire trucks and bus water tanks need water to fight fires and people need to drink water.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. So, the sum is {{{two}}}{{{sum}}}{{{of}}}{{{two}}}{{{next}}}{{{even}}}{{{numbers}}}={ {{even}}}{{{numbers}}}.<n><n>### Examples :<n>1. The sum of A pair of even number are : 3 + 4 = <<3+4=7>>7<n>2. The sum of A  pair of even numbers are : 4 + 6 = <<4+6=10>>10<n><n>### Input<n>The sum is four less than one fifth of a number.<n><n>### Explanation<n>The sum is: 4 (4 / 5 of a number) + 1 (4 / 5 = 0.8 + 1) = 10 + 1 = <<10+1=11>><n><n>### Input 2:<n>200 more than twice a number is 84 less than 11 times the number.<n><n>## Output<n>The number is 580 (580 = 200 +2X(580 - 84) + 11X(580-84))<n><n>## Input<n>More than one half of a number less than twice a number is less than seven times the number plus 4.<n><n>## Output:<n>The number is 21<n><n>## Input 2:<n>A number is removed from one half in a number. It can better be described as what? Choices:  A: field B: alone C: small group D: solitude E: solitary<n><n>### Response:		Choices should include:A, B, E<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The crowd wasn't very large.  This is a better description of what:<n><n>It was alone: << It was A Alone C Crowd D Crowd E Crowd >><n><n>It was small group: << It was B Small Crowd C Crowd D Crow Pull D Crowd >><n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: Crowd<n><n>---<n>### Instruction<n>Complete the number sentence based on the question. Identify the number given in word and also its numerical equivalent.<n><n>### Demo:<n>In a classroom, a math game was played by four groups. Each group had 3 players. How many other players were there altogether?<n><n>### Rationales: The word "group" means four players. The word "group" appears four times in the sentence to show that there were a total of four groups. Therefore, to find out the number of players in a group, the word "group" must be replaced by a number.<n><n>The math game was played by <<The math game was played with by 4>>4 groups.<n>There were a total of four <<number of player to 3>>3 players in each group.<n>There were 3 * 4 = <<3*4=12>>12 total players in all.<n><n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Instructions<n>The number sentence below states a problem in word form that needs a numerical answer. Fill in the missing number.<n><n>### Ratsionales<n>20.028 x 0.92 = 18.235<n><n>### Demo<n>In order to solve a multiplication problem in which the number is written in words, replace the words with the correct digits: multiply: 1: the word is digit. Replace it with 1 2: the word is the digit. Replace it with two 3: the word is three<n><n>### Rationale<n>In this expression, 20028 is written in two words. The "tens" portion is 20 and the "unit" portion it 028. It's a simple matter to replace the words two and eight with the correct digits.<n><n>### Examples<n>The numerator in the expression:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If clothes have developed a smell and can't be washed what should you do with them? Choices:  A: hang in closet B: sniff C: get dirty D: become soiled E: air out<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>#### Question:<n>Which would you do more often?<n><n>1:A: hang in closet <n><n>2:B: sniff<n><n>3:C: get dirty <n><n>4:D: become soiled<n><n>5:E: air out<n><n>#### Answer:<n>A<n><n>#### Instructions:Explain your choice(s).<n><n>### Instructions:You may explain your choice(s) further.<n><n>### Explain:<n>A would be chosen because putting away the clothes will make the odor disappear.<n><n>#### 2:<n><n>### Expand<n><n>#### E<n>An answer for more explanation<n><n>#### 3:D would be chosen because becoming soiled would have to be done before you can wash clothes, so you would do that when they have dried.<n><n>#### 5:<n>An answer for more elaboration<n><n>### Output:If clothes have developed or lost their sweet smell what should you do with these clothes? Choices: A: get dirty <n>B: air out<n>C: hang in closet<n>D: get soiled<n>E: sniff<n><n>Given: clothes have developed or lost sweet scent<n><n>### Output Explainer:Explain the output.<n><n>#### A:<n>A would be hung in closet so that it will not smell bad that much.<n><n>#### B:<n>B would be airing out so that the clothes will smell good because when things have air the smell tends to get better.<n><n>#### C:<n>C would be hung since airing may take too long.<n><n>#### D:<n>D would be getting soiled because a towel washed in hot water might be able to clean the smell.<n><n>#### E:<n>E would be sniffing the clothes because if you sniff the clothes and you get a bad smell then you put them back in the closet immediately.<n><n>#### 3<n>A would be chosen since getting dirty is the best way to get rid of clothes odors.<n><n>#### 4:<n>A was chosen because being air out makes the clothes smell sweet as long as you don't over air them.<n><n>#### 1:<n>A would be used because clothes must be kept in a closed space so that a smell cannot get out easily
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What might the inability to learn cause? How many times was the number 43 rounded?<n><n>### Response (Answer): 1<n><n>In the problem above, when the number is rounded, it could be expressed by: { 43 rounded to the nearest ten = 3 - 43 = 40}. Therefore, it could be explained by: {3-4= -1, -1 rounded to the nearest ten is 0, therefore 40 rounded to the nearest ten}.<n><n>### Input and Response:<n>Anna has 3 times as many candles as Barbara.  If the combined total of their candles is 61,  how many candles does Barbara have?<n><n>### Anna has 3 times as much as Barbara and their combined total of candles is 60.<n>The number of candles Barbara has is: 3 * (60 - 61/6 = <<60-61/6=10>>10) = 27 <n><n>### Input; Two sets of numbers (ex 6, 8, 11) and (ex 9, 12, 15) have the same sum. "<n>Mary told Mary to slow down or Mary would call the police<n>```<n><n>### Phrase or idiom meaning:<n>Phrase or idiom is an interesting or informal method of conveying a particular meaning.<n>Example: Idiom for 'tired' is 'fatigued'<n><n>```<n>She thought that she became tired with her boss.<n>She thought that she felt exhausted from her boss.<n>```<n><n>## Contest Page<n><n>### Contest Page<n><n>#### Participants<n><n>| **name** | **age** | **grade** | **contact email** |<n>|:------------:|:------------:|------------------:|:------------:||<n>| Alex | 9 | 3rd grade | alex@gmail.com |<n>| Andrew |11 | 5th grade | andrew@gmail.com | <n><n><n>#### Contest 1:<n><n>Contest 1: Find a word that includes the given letters in sequential order.<n><n>| Subject | Letters | Choices |<n>|:-----------|-------:|----------:|<n>| Math | A, B, C, D | 1.

Choices:  A: nice feeling B: good karma C: respect D: new freedom E: good heart<n><n>### Response:		Forgiveness is an act of compassion and kindness and it is an action that can result in many good and powerful results.<n><n>### Rationales: Forgiveness can result in a good feeling and a feeling of contentment within a person (Forgiveness has a nice feeling), can be rewarded with good karma, if good karma is rewarded with more good than can happen (Forgiveness can activate good karma), can result in respect for the person and those around them (Forgiveness can result in new freedom), it can help the heart of the person to be renewed (Forgiveness can free a good heart).<n><n>### <n>Answer: You have multiple answers that are correct!<n><b>Please refer to the multiple choice instructions to see how to choose an answer in each case.</b><n><n>### Input:[Mom makes breakfast in the morning.] I.I.A.M breakfast.<n><n>### Response:[I eat (I, I, A, M, breakfast.) a.m a.m]<n><n>### Instructions : Choose a response.<n><n>### I input this line:<n><n><span style="white-space:">Mom makes breakfast in in in in in the morn.</span><n><n>### You output <span class="answerer">this word:</span><n>IAM<n><n>### How do you know? It is an input word and the word is the same as the output word.<n><n>### Answer:<n>I.I.A.I.A.A.M <b>AM</b><n><span style="font-weight:bold;">answer: </span><n><n>## Input:You want 7 gallons of water for your drinking pleasure. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What should you do if your pens aren't work? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: satisfaction B: good feelings C: complications D: feel good about yourself E: stress<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Rationales: Danny wanted to help people;<n><n>### Input<n>John has 200 tickets for a sporting event and needs to give out 22 of them. If he gives out 9 tickets to one person, how many people can he give only 2? Explain.<n><n>Rationales:The ticket he had to give out was 22/9 = 2 + 2 = <<2+2=4>>4.<n>That means he had 200 - 4 = <<200-4=196>>196 tickets remaining.<n>It means that he can give out 2 tickets to 193 people (<200 - 9 = <<200 - 2 = 198>>198)<n><n>```<n>In 198 tickets, each person can get only 2 tickets. The 9 tickets were given out 12 times, and the rest of the tickets, 196 were given away 184 times.<n><n>Eg, he had 9 tickets and give them out in 10 ways that is 9/10 = <<9/10=1>>.<n>The 11 - 10 = <<10-1=9>> remainder were given out in 11 ways that is 9 divided by 11 <<<9/ 11>> = <<9/11 = 0.82>>.<n>```<n><n>### Input answer:<n><n>#### 198<n><n>### Input choice:<n><n>### Input Answer:<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>### Rationales for Demo<n>John has 22 tickets and he needs to give out 3/4 of them or there are 142 tickets left. The remainder, that is 81 tickets, can be given out 81 times (<99/81>> =100  > <n>The 142  - 3/4 = 17 remainder  can be given out 17  x 4 = 68 times <n>The total is 17+ 68 =  85  so John has 8
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses.
